DOC.HEAD: San Francisco, Charleston Stations Lead Peabody Winners
DOC.TEXT: San Francisco and Charleston, S.C., radio and television stations won Peabody Awards on Thursday for their coverage of two natural disasters _ last October's Bay area earthquake and Hurricane Hugo. CBS Radio News and Cable News Network also were honored for their reporting of the student uprising in China. The annual awards for distinguished broadcasting were announced by the University of Georgia College of Journalism and Mass Communication. The 27 recipients will be presented the awards, known as ``the Pulitzer Prize of broadcast journalism,'' on April 3 in Atlanta. KCBS-AM and KGO-TV in San Francisco were named winners for their reporting of the earthquake, which occurred just before the scheduled start of Game 3 of the World Series. ``We think it's exciting to receive an award such as this, which is really so prestigious,'' said KCBS-AM General Manager Frank Oxarart. ``I think we all knew that this was a once-in-a-lifetime story and we all felt that we had provided a tremendous service to the Bay area,'' said Arleen Bolton, assistant director of news and programming at the station. ``We managed to stay on the air when the earthquake hit. We were able to stay on the air and give the Bay area news and information immediately after the quake,'' she said. ``And, of course, everybody on the staff worked to the max and continued for days and days _ around the clock, full commitment to the story.'' ``We are absolutely thrilled with it,'' said KGO-TV General Manager Jim Topping of the award. ``The staff worked extraordinarily hard, and it was a time of great dedication. And, clearly, the success the station had is a huge reflection of the community's reaction.'' The Peabody judges called the KCBS coverage ``comprehensive, intelligent and useful,'' while KGO's reports were lauded for ``functioning as an information clearinghouse'' for viewers. WCSC-TV in Charleston covered Hurricane Hugo in a way that provided a ``lifeline for viewers deprived of water, communications and other essential services,'' the judges said. ``We're very honored. The award really goes to the people of the Low Country of South Carolina who withstood all this with us,'' said Don Feldman, vice president of news at WCSC-TV. ``We were homeless like other people in the area. We went through what they went through,'' he said. ``We felt like we were victims of the storm like everybody. So, we were in there with them.'' Other winners included broadcasting pioneer J. Leonard Reinsch of Atlanta, a former president of Cox Broadcasting, and veteran ABC newsman David Brinkley, both for distinguished careers in broadcasting. Awards for television drama went to CBS for its movie ``Lonesome Dove,'' to ABC for its series ``The Wonder Years,'' ``China Beach'' and ``Small Sacrifices,'' and to the Children's Television Workshop for ``Sesame Street.'' MTV won a Peabody for ``Decade,'' a look at the 1980s from the perspective of pop musicians and news makers. The winners were selected from 812 entries submitted by radio and television stations and networks around the world. A 15-member national advisory board judged the entries. The 50-year-old awards are named for George Foster Peabody, a Columbus, Ga., native who became a banker and philanthropist in New York.

President Says He's Ready for Talks with Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Mozambique's President Joaquim Chissano said Thursday his government is willing to start talks within several weeks with the RENAMO rebels on ending the country's 10-year civil war. Chissano said he was awaiting an answer from the rebels through mediators who have been trying to bring the sides together. He praised the United States for a seven-point proposal it presented both sides last year to help them overcome their reluctance to negotiate. ``We feel we can now go into talks,'' Chissano told reporters at a news conference summing up three days of talks with President Bush, top officials of his administration and congressional leaders. ``If RENAMO gives us a quick answer, we are ready to start,'' he added. Negotiations could begin as soon as Chissano returns from next week's ceremonies marking the independence of neighboring Namibia, he said. RENAMO had been reluctant to accept one of the points that deals with recognition of Mozambique's government and its constitution, Chissano said. But now, the rebels appear willing to recognize the government and recognition of the constitution can be worked out during the actual peace talks, he said. Mozambique, which in recent years has renounced its Marxist doctrine and shifted to a market-oriented economy, is drafting a constitution that would allow independent candidates to run in elections, he said. Individuals from RENAMO would be eligible to participate, Chissano said. The people of Mozambique will also vote this summer on a proposal to allow more than one political party. If that happens, RENAMO could compete in elections, he said. Mozambique has been devastated by the fighting with RENAMO, founded in the 1970s by white South Africans to counter the government's support for the guerrillas of the African National Congress. The group has been accused by U.S. officials and human rights monitors of savage attacks on innocent civilians. Chissano said he was satisfied that the South African government of F.W. de Klerk had stopped all assistance to RENAMO. He said South African authorities were cooperating with his government to stop aid for the rebels from inidividuals in South Africa. The organization also has wealthy right-wing backers in Portugal and Brazil. While praising de Klerk for progress he has made toward starting talks with his country's black majority about the future of apartheid, Chissano also urged the United States to maintain its economic sanctions against South Africa ``until everyone is sure the process is irreversible.'' Chissano said he had asked Bush for additional financial help to rehabilitate his country and help an estimated 5.6 million refugees and handicapped people. Mozambique receives more than $100 million annually from the United States, making it the largest aid recipient in sub-Saharan Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Congratulates Soviet Leader on Election
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent a letter Thursday to Mikhail S. Gorbachev congratulating him on his unopposed election as president of the Soviet Union. Bush wrote Gorbachev ``wishing him well as he leads the Soviet Union into the next stage of perestroika and democratization,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He added Bush is looking forward ``to their forthcoming summit in June as an opportunity to broaden the already considerable elements of cooperation between our two countries.'' The letter did not mention the Lithuanian parliament's vote Sunday to secede from the Soviet Unon, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed on Second Day of Local Polls
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of rival candidates for local elections fought with pistols and bombs Thursday, killing one woman and injuring 12 other people in southern Bangladesh, police said. The clashes occurred on the second day of 12-day-long polls to elect local administrative councils throughout the country. At least one person was killed and 50 people injured in clashes when balloting began Wednesday. Police in the town of Uttar Amirabad, 135 miles southeast of Dhaka, said a 40-year-old woman was caught in the cross-fire between rival groups and died of bullet wounds. The police officials, who were contacted by telephone, spoke on condition of anonymity. They said at least 12 people were injured in the clashes. The March 14-25 polls are being fought on non-partisan lines, but clashes erupt between supporters of rival parties because local voters know the political affiliations of the technically independent candidates. At least two people were killed in the campaigning for the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Destroyed 5,000 Computer Files, Witness Testifies
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter erased 5,000 computer files at the time he was resigning as national security adviser during the Iran-Contra scandal, a computer expert testified today at Poindexter's trial. Kelly Williams said Poindexter deleted the files from his computer, leaving just 50 of his own computer files behind when he departed the National Security Council in November 1986. Deleting the files would be comparable to ``taking a manila envelope and just throwing it away?'' asked associate independent counsel Louise Radin. ``Yes, that would be the effect,'' replied Williams, who was in charge of the computer software section at the White House communications agency in 1986. Under questioning from Radin, Williams noted that Poindexter was logged onto the computer system for a 15-hour span on Nov. 24, 1986, starting at 4:30 in the morning. That was the day before the national security adviser resigned. On Nov. 22, then-White House aide Oliver North deleted 732 notes from his own computer file, leaving a total of just one. Copies of some of the deleted computer files of Poindexter and Oliver North were recovered from back-up computer tapes kept at the NSC and have been instrumental in tracing the Iran-Contra affair. The deletions are part of a conspiracy charge against Poindexter. He is accused of working with North to destroy NSC records in an attempt to conceal the Iran initiative and North's military assistance to the Contras. Earlier today, Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb said North gave such valuable testimony that the government may conclude its case against Poindexter by Monday. Webb said North's testimony ``went well'' and that the government ``got a lot'' out of the former White House aide, who testified that he witnessed Poindexter tear up a politically embarrassing presidential document. Earlier, during North's four days on the stand, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene called North a ``hostile witness'' and said getting him to answer questions on the stand was like ``pulling teeth.'' But Webb said today that North's testimony ``cut off two or three weeks'' of the prosecution's work and that ``I could rest as early as Monday.'' During his testimony, North said Poindexter sent him to a meeting with members of Congress where North lied by denying he was assisting the Contras. Before the meeting, Poindexter assured North that he could ``take care of'' the matter. After Webb's remarks, the prosecution called as a witness the former general counsel to the CIA, Stanley Sporkin, who drafted the presidential finding that Poindexter subsequently destroyed. Sporkin explained how he was contacted in late November 1985 by the CIA's deputy director, John McMahon, and was briefed by agency staffers on a Hawk missile shipment to Iran that the CIA was assisting. ``It was my preliminary view ... that ... for the CIA to provide help that I would require that the president of the United States'' sign a document approving the action, Sporkin testified. Federal law requires that ``before the CIA can undertake'' such activity in a foreign country ``it must have a finding,'' said Sporkin. The document wasn't drafted until after the Hawks were delivered, so Sporkin included a sentence saying that ``all prior actions taken by U.S. ... officials'' in the operation ``are hereby ratified.'' The document, which depicted the Iran initiative as a straight arms-for-hostages deal, was torn up by Poindexter a year later when the arms sales were exposed. Sporkin is now a U.S. district judge serving in the same courthouse where Poindexter is on trial. The hurriedly drafted document, known as a ``finding,'' depicted the U.S. government as being involved in a straight arms-for-hostages deal with Iran. Poindexter presented it to President Reagan for his signature two weeks after the missiles were sent to Iran. Poindexter tore it up when the administration's Iran initiative was exposed a year later. He destroyed the paper the same day he told the House and Senate intelligence committees that he hadn't known about the Hawk shipment until five weeks after it occurred. The prosecution contends that Poindexter's knowledge that the document existed was his motive in concealing the U.S. role in the Hawk shipment from Congress. The former national security adviser also is accused of two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements by allegedly covering up North's military assistance to the Contras and concealing the U.S. role in the missile shipment to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet General Invited to Testify Before House Panel
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee has invited Soviet Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev to testify this spring on the rapid developments in the Soviet Union. ``The more we know about the remarkable changes going on in the Soviet Union, the better we'll be at deciding how to buy the right stuff for America's defense,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., who also announced plans to expand contacts with the Soviet Union's national legislature. The legislature _ formally known as the Defense and State Security Committee of the Supreme Soviet _ is the rough equivalent of the House Armed Services panel. Moiseyev's schedule calls for the chief of the Soviet General Staff to visit the the United States in May. Marshal Sergey Akhromeyev, an adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, appeared before the panel last year. Rep. William Dickinson, R-Ala., the panel's ranking GOP member, said that although the United States should base ``its military posture on Soviet capabilities and not intentions, meetings like this are always constructive in nature.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Says Libyan Plant Extensively Damaged, Denies Responsibility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 6-7 bgng, Bush was ... to UPDATE with Bush comment; picks up 6th graf pvs, Libyan leader ...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today a Libyan chemical weapons plant had been extensively damaged by fire and apparently was unable to function. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater denied anew that the United States was responsible for the blaze at the Rabta chemical plant. ``We don't know the origins of the fire,'' he said. ``We don't know if it was sabotage. We don't have any idea who did it. ... Somebody could have knocked over a kerosene lamp or something.'' Without revealing the source of his information, Fitzwater characterized the damage at the plant as extensive. ``Common sense would tell you it's not functioning,'' he said. ``We assume it's not functioning.'' However, he also said, ``The building is there but is it all burned out inside? We don't really know.'' President Bush was asked at a pre-St. Patrick's Day party thrown by House Speaker Thomas Foley what information he had on the chemical plant blaze. ``Not much,'' Bush said. Asked by a reporter if the United States had been involved in the fire, Bush said, ``No, but we've already said that.'' Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi threatened today to retaliate against West Germany if its agents set fire to the plant. West Germany denied responsibility. Gadhafi said the heavily guarded plant was designed only to produce pharmaceuticals, but said Libya would be willing to pay millions of dollars to any company that builds it a chemical weapons facility. President Bush said Wednesday the United States had heard rumors that the plant was on fire but that he did not know what had happened. Fitzwater said the United States was told of the fire by diplomatic sources, who also said Libya had sealed its borders. ``We just dare not speculate on the cause,'' Fitzwater said. Mahmoud Azzabi, press secretary at Libya's United Nations mission in New York, confirmed Wednesday night ``there is a fire'' at the Rabta plant 60 miles southwest of Tripoli. ``There is speculation that it was possibly sabotage, somebody coming in from Tunisia,'' which borders on Libya, he said. The British Broadcasting Corp. quoted an unidentified spokesman for the official Libyan news agency Jana as saying there had been a fire in some machinery at the plant but that the building had not been damaged. ABC News quoted unidentified Libyan security sources as claiming that the plant was burned to the ground by the action of U.S. and Israeli agents. ``We have no information to indicate that,'' Roman Popadiuk, a White House deputy press secretary, said of the ABC report. Fitzwater said last week the White House was seriously concerned by evidence that the plant was producing chemical weapons after a year of little activity. He said then that the plant ``is dangerous and becoming more so'' and called for ``vigorous efforts to stop the operation'' of the plant. He refused to rule out military action to close it. Despite Libyan denials, U.S. officials have said the plant has been producing limited quantities of mustard and nerve gases. In the past, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi has said the plant was designed to produce pharmaceuticals. The United States engaged in hostilities with Libya three times in the 1980s, twice shooting down Libyan fighter planes and bombing Tripoli in 1986 in retaliation for what then-President Reagan said was terrorism against Americans in Europe. Western journalists were invited to tour the plant in January 1989, but they were not allowed to inspect it after they arrived in Rabta. The Libyans built a small village of cement block apartment buildings, schools and community buildings about a mile beyond the gates to the complex to house the workers. The journalists did see that the area was protected with surface-to-air missile batteries, tanks and soldiers. A short distance away, a radar station operated on a high, barren ridge overlooking the highway that led to the industrial complex. The West German government has investigated allegations that a West German company helped build the plant.

DOC.HEAD: BIA Schools Held Not Helping Handicapped Preschoolers
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of handicapped preschoolers aren't getting the help the Bureau of Indian Affairs is required to provide, government investigators say. Only 838 of the estimated 3,000 handicapped 3-year-olds and 4-year-olds on reservations with BIA schools were getting special education in the 1988-89 school year, the General Accounting Office said in a report released this month. At least a fourth of the children who are receiving some services weren't getting all the help they need because of shortages of qualified teachers and the money to hire them, the GAO said. ``There are a tremendous number of Indian families who don't even know that the reason why their child is so slow is that they have a developmental disability,'' said Yvette Joseph, an aide to the Senate Indian Affairs Committee. The Interior Department contended in its response to the report that the department, which includes the BIA, had ``successfully implemented child-find activities for many years.'' Congress will consider legislation to require greater cooperation between states and federal agencies on special education programs for Indian children, she said Thursday. Congress in 1986 required the government to make sure all handicapped Indian children aged 3 to 5 on reservations with BIA schools get a ``free and appropriate'' education. The GAO cited an acute shortage of qualified teachers in many areas. For example, only eight of the 28 Head Start teachers for children on the Cheyenne River Reservation in South Dakota even had teaching credentials and none of them had training in special education. The other 20 teachers had only a high school diploma. Although the staff isn't qualified to teach handicapped children, ``there are no alternatives,'' according to the BIA coordinator. When the reservation tried to hire a speech therapist and special education teacher, the BIA contacted 27 colleges, universities and individuals without finding a single qualified applicant, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Hurls Truck Atop Roof; Heat Wilts Cherry Blossom Festival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `In Florida...', with 4 grafs to UPDATE with tornado today in Mississippi. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Near Columbia...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor WI4
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes in the nation's midsection tossed tractor-trailers around like toys and a record-breaking heat wave wilted plans for the annual cherry blossom festival in Washington. Heavy rain threatened flooding in the Midwest. On the heels of that heat wave, a snowstorm today closed schools in Minnesota and surprised western Iowa. Wyoming police closed sections of Interstates 80 and 25 because of blowing snow, and North Dakota expected blizzard conditions. In Florida, a bishop asked God for rain to relieve the region's 19-month drought. And in Indiana today, a tornado preparedness drill was called off to avoid confusion with the real storm front predicted to be heading into the state. More severe thunderstorms like those that have brought twisters to the Plains this week spread over Mississippi today in advance of a slowly moving cold front and spawned yet another tornado. The tornado cut a path of destruction across rural George County in the southeastern part of the state. Five people, including three children, were injured when it smashed their mobile home. ``It knocked my trailer over, picked it up and dropped it back again,'' said Rai Smith, 21, in a telephone interview from her hospital room in Lucedale. ``When it all stopped, the walls became the floor and the bathroom door was directly above me.'' Near Columbia, Mo., a tornado damaged five businesses Wednesday night, blowing tractor-trailers ``like matchsticks,'' said Richard Head. He said his auto dealership was damaged by an 18-wheeler dropped onto the roof. At least four tractor-trailers were blown about 100 feet across a road, said Mike Poe, spokesman for the Boone County, Mo., Fire Protection District. A tornado or high wind also damaged several mobile homes in the area. No injuries were reported. High water kept many roads closed this morning, but a cleanup was under way, officials said. ``I think we were very fortunate,'' Mike Sanford, the county's director of emergency preparedness said today after an aerial tour. ``These were, comparatively speaking, minor events.'' ``I was scared. Really scared,'' said Santiago Munoz, whose trailer was damaged. ``My wife, she said, `God, God, God, God, God take care of us.''' In Fordyce, Ark., about 40 miles southwest of Pine Bluff, five people were injured by a tornado Wednesday. Bill Setterman, chief sheriff's deputy, said three homes were destroyed and roofs and porches were ripped off other homes. He said rescuers found one of the injured ``wrapped up like a pretzel'' in his home. Two twisters in central Texas flipped mobile homes, tore off roofs and toppled utility poles Wednesday. In Nebraska and Kansas, volunteers spent Wednesday and today clearing up debris from dozens of tornadoes that ripped through on Tuesday. In one town alone, Hesston, Kan., twisters killed two people and injured 23. The 50 National Guard troops sent to help in Hesston were expected to pull out today. About 1,000 people, including volunteers from the Mennonite Disaster Service, helped the town clean up. ``We feel as Christians this is one way of sharing God's love with people who are hurting,'' said Marvin Toews, a farmer who coordinated activities. East of the Mississippi Valley, at least 31 cities reported record or record-tying high temperatures Wednesday, the third day of unseasonable warmth. The records included 85 at Baltimore, 75 at Detroit, 76 at Indianapolis and 86 at Washington's National Airport. The high at Indianapolis erased a record on the books since 1875. Buffalo, N.Y., registered 78 degrees. But the warm spell was definitely over on the northern Plains, where up to 10 inches of snow was forecast today in eastern North Dakota, with northerly wind blowing at 25 to 45 mph expected to create near blizzard conditions. Heavy, wet snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain socked southwestern Minnesota today, forcing the closing of at least 28 schools. Up to 10 inches of snow was possible. And up to 9 inches had already fallen by midday in western Iowa, where meteorologists said the storm caught them offr-guard. Farther west, the Wyoming Highway Patrol closed sections of I-80 and I-25 and some other highways because snow blown by 25 mph wind cut visibility nearly to zero. Cherry blossoms in the nation's capital will peak today and Friday because of the unseasonable warmth and will be gone by the April opening of the annual Cherry Blossom Festival, said National Park Service spokeswoman Marja Morris. ``They'll only last four or five days,'' she said. Tulips, though, are about three weeks ahead of schedule and will flower in time for the cherry blossom festival, she said. A cold front was expected to end the record-breaking warm weather tonight. Fruit farmers in New Jersey fear the heat may have fooled their blueberries, peaches and nectarines into budding before freezing temperatures end. ``The weather is making the peaches say, `Ooh, isn't it nice,'' said Genie DeCou, who runs a 500-acre peach, nectarine and apple farm in Shiloh. Thunderstorms in the Midwest dumped heavy rain, which was compounded in Wisconsin by a dam burst on a pond leading to the Trempealeau River. But Arcadia, Wis., Police Chief Patrick Grzadzielewski said the river was receding. ``Everything we've been doing up to this point has been preparing for the worst and, hopefully, that will not happen now,'' he said. In Vernon County in west-central Missouri, 8-year-old Travis Koehn of Walker was found dead Wednesday after falling into a swollen stream. In St. Petersburg, Fla., Roman Catholic Bishop John Favalora is praying for rain. ``I am confident that the Lord will hear our prayers,'' he said in a message broadcast every hour on the local Catholic radio station. The Indiana tornado drills had been scheduled for early afternoon and evening today. Warning sirens were to sound and schools and other public facilities were to conduct drills. But the same front that spawned the torndoes in the Plains was heading eastward, officials said. Steve Haines, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Indianapolis, said the drill was postponed until Friday to alleviate any confusion. ``They'll think it's the real thing,'' Haines said. ``We don't want to confuse the two.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Sudan Relief Depends on Warring Factions
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials said Thursday they hope food aid can soon resume flowing to Sudan, but they strongly criticized the government of the famine-wracked African nation. ``To put it bluntly, the relief situation has deteriorated,'' Assistant Secretary of State Herman J. Cohen told a joint hearing of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa and a task force on hunger. Cohen, who visited the African nation last week, said a civil war between the government and separatists in the south has blocked international relief agencies from shipping food into the country. ``Both sides in the current conflict ... say they want peace, but both continue to fight,'' he said. Three million Sudanese are homeless and 500,000 are at risk of death as a result of war and famine. Some 250,000, many of them children, died last year. The United States joined other nations last year in Operation Lifeline Sudan. Washington contributed more than 60 percent of the food delivered, at a cost of $72 million. The project succeeded in part because of a cease-fire between government troops and the Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army. But the SPLA broke the cease-fire last October and the fighting continued. ``A number of actions by the government have so far severely hampered a resumption of last year's successful operation,'' Cohen said. ``The SPLA must share the blame for this deterioration.'' Foreign donors are attempting to negotiate with the Sudanese government to begin another round of Operation Lifeline Sudan. ``While we cannot say that the relief effort is definitely back on track, we hope that it will be shortly,'' Cohen said. ``I am confident that the Sudanese government will fulfill its pledge to cooperate on Operation Lifeline Sudan.'' Andrew Natsios, director of the Agency for International Development's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, said the Sudanese government believes weapons were smuggled to rebels in the south in the food shipments. Natsios said Washington has assurred the gvoernment this is not the case. Cohen, meantime, said the U.S. government has told the Sudanese government, which was installed in a coup last June, that its ``human rights record needs improvement.'' There have been reports, he said, that prisoners have been mistreated and held for long periods of time. Washington has also pressed the Sudanese to return the country to representative government. Although the United States gives Sudan food aid, it has cut off all military and economic aid since last year's coup.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Parliament Votes No Confidence in Shamir Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Shamir losing no-confidence vote. Peres wins right to try to form a new government. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres won a parliamentary showdown with the rival Likud bloc today when lawmakers voted no-confidence in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's hard-line government. The 60-55 vote gave Peres a chance to form a Labor-led coalition. Shamir, the first premier to be turned out of office by a parliamentary vote in the history of the Jewish state, will remain as caretaker prime minister until a new government is seated. Peres won after Shamir rejected a compromise offered by the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party's spiritual leader Ovadia Yosef, who called for acceptance of U.S. peace proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. Five of the six lawmakers from Shas then failed to attend the vote, giving Peres the margin of victory. The compromise proposal was offered earlier today after more than five hours of angry debate in the 120-seat parliament. The debate was suspended to give the major political parties time to consider the compromise. The U.S. proposals would allow a deported Palestinian and a resident of Arab east Jerusalem to serve on a Palestinian negotating team that would meet with Israelis in Cairo. Shamir told parliament earlier today that the acceptance of Arabs from east Jerusalem in the peace process would compromise Israel's claim to sovereignty over the sector captured from Jordan in 1967. Under the proposed compromise, the two parties would have agreed that Jerusalem is not negotiable and that it would remain united under Israel's rule. Shamir also would have reinstated Labor ministers to the coalition in exchange for which the centr-left Labor would drop its no-confidence motion. Before the no-confidence vote, leaders of Labor and Likud both visited Yosef to discuss the proposed compromise, but to no avail. When Peres called for the no-confidence vote against Shamir today, he accused the right-wing leader of ``murdering the peace process.'' Shamir countered with an accusation that Labor made repeated concessions to Israel's Arab enemies, calling this a ``shameful act.'' The charge brought shouts of protest from Labor ministers including Peres, who angrily wagged his finger at Shamir and accused him of losing opportunities for peace. ``I propose voting no confidence in the man who ended two processes, peace and national unity,'' Peres said in a bitter speech. Shamir said he had been the driving force behind creation of the national unity government and that his party was just as interested in making peace as Labor. ``We are not afraid of peace or the peace process. We fear irresponsible concessions,'' Shamir said, calling for a defeat of the no-confidence motion. Shamir said the United States complicated the peace process by raising the sensitive issue of Jerusalem and suggesting Israel's claim to the captured Arab sector of the city should be a subject of negotiations. ``There is only one Jerusalem, Israel's,'' he said. Peres, during his speech, pointed a finger at Shamir and accused him of breaking his commitment to religious and secular parties: ``Who will believe you again in this country? You have broken every promise.'' Peres was interrupted frequently by Likud heckling, particularly from Likud Knesset member Yehoshua Matza who kept chanting, ``Subversive! Subversive!'' A Labor-Likud coalition, which has ruled Israel through eight stormy years of repeated crises, collapsed Tuesday when Shamir fired Peres and the other 10 Labor ministers resigned. Peres promised that a government led by his Labor Party would start peace talks with Palestinians. Shamir said a victory by his Likud bloc would delay if not cancel the Israeli-Palestinian dialogue proposed by Secretary of State James A Baker III.

DOC.HEAD: Syrians Soldiers Watch for Attempts To Move Hostages Out of Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with week's Shiite fighting; picks up 6th `Syrian soldiers'
DOC.TEXT: Syrian soldiers guard gateways of two Shiite Moslem slum districts in south Beirut in case kidnappers try to smuggle out Terry Anderson or other Western hostages, police say. ``I am sure they are all alive,'' Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddin, spiritual head of Lebanon's Shiite community, said recently. ``That much I can safely ascertain.'' Other senior Shiite sources said the captives were alive and most were in south Beirut. Police said the Syrians tightened their security net around the Hajjaj and Hay Madi districts after gun battles this week between rival Shiite militias for control of the densely populated southern slums. Shiite sources said none of the hostages was hurt in the fighting between militiamen of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, believed to be an umbrella group for the hostage-holders, and the pro-Syrian Amal movement. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Syrians moved rapidly to keep the battles from spreading through Hajjaj and Hay Madi. Police said the Syrians _ armed with rocket-propelled grenades and submachine guns _ threatened to kill any militiamen spotted on the streets. ``That did it,'' a police spokesman said. ``The guns fell silent.'' Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate issued in 1976, the year after Lebanon's civil war began. The police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing regulations, said the Syrians were ``searching everything coming out from both neighborhoods, where most of the hostages are thought to be imprisoned _ even funeral processions and caskets.'' Syrian soldiers have not tried to storm any suspected hideouts of kidnappers, apparently for fear of killing hostages. Seventeen Westerners are missing in Lebanon and believed to be hostages, including eight Americans. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, has been held longest. He was abducted five years ago, on March 16, 1985. The captives have been moved often, in car trunks or coffins, either to escape fighting among Shiite factions or to avoid detection. French journalist Jean-Paul Kauffmann, freed in 1988, said he nearly suffocated in a box that was slung beneath a truck. Anderson, 42, was said to have been chained to a basement wall of a ruined Beirut hotel during his early days as a captive. Freed hostages have said they, too, were held in basements, or sometimes in upper-floor apartments with no access to windows. All said they heard jet planes landing and taking off, which supports the belief that most hostages are in the southern slums near Beirut's airport. Shiites claiming to be close to the kidnappers often have approached news agencies in Beirutoffering to help free Anderson or Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, in return for as much as $1 million for each hostage. None of the offers was believed to be legitimate. Waite, 50, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel in Moslem west Beirut to negotiate for the freedom of Anderson and other Americans. President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has asked pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon grouped under the umbrella of Hezbollah, or Party of God, to free the hostages. But the Shiite sources in Beirut believe Rafsanjani has little influence with the militant Hezbollah wing that controls the hostage-holders. Hezbollah militants are loyal to Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the hard-line former interior minister of Iran, who helped found Hezbollah while he was Iran's ambassador to Syria in the early 1980s. Anderson is held by a group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. ``Rafsanjani's hostage behests are a cry without an echo,'' said a senior Shiite source. ``Rafsanjani wants a deal with the United States to unblock Tehran's frozen assests to cope with Iran's economic crisis, which is generating anti-government public sentiment. ``Mohtashemi and other hard-line opposition leaders have a stake in maintaining the crisis so they can agitate against Rafsanjani, so no hostages are likely to be released in the near future.'' The United States holds billions of dollars in Iranian assets that were frozen after the storming of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979. Fifty-two Americans were held 444 days. Rafsanjani and other Iranian leaders have said Iran would help get the hostages in Lebanon released if the United States freed the assets. This week, Mohtashemi said some of the captives were spies and argued against freeing any of the ``mercenary U.S. hostages.'' Support for the hard-liners came March 6 when a group holding American hostages Joseph Cicippio and Edward Austin Tracy broke a seven-month silence to say no captives were about to be freed. ``There is no intention to release hostages,'' said the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which also threatened suicide attacks on U.S. interests. Shiite sources said the next hostage release might come from Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which holds American college teachers Robert Polhill, Alann Steen and Jesse Turner. Hussein Mousawi, a pro-Syrian activist based in the Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon, now controls the group. The sources said Mohtashemi loyalists recently removed Mousawi from the Hezbollah leadership.

DOC.HEAD: White House ``Regrets'' Appeals Unheeded in Journalist's Execution
With AM-Condemned Journalist Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration expressed regret Thursday but did not join the strong European condemnation over Iraq's execution of a British-based journalist accused of spying. The White House, in a mild reaction to the hanging of of Farzad Bazoft, avoided further comment, saying ``we don't have any way to make a judgment on the case.'' Iraq accused the 31-year-old journalist of spying for Britain and Israel. Bazoft, who emigrated from his native Iran as a teenager in 1975, wrote for the British weekly The Observer and traveled on British documents. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``He of course was the subject of international clemency pleas. We regret those were unheeded. But we don't have a lot of details on the case itself.'' Asked if the United States shared the British government's view that this was ``barbarous,'' Fitzwater said, ``We don't have any independent conclusions about the case itself or the trial.'' He said he did not expect to have any further reaction to the hanging, saying, ``He was not a U.S. citizen.'' Bazoft was convicted Saturday by a revolutionary court in a closed trial. He was arrested in September near the the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad where ballistic missiles are reportedly being developed. He was investigating reports that hundreds of people had died in an explosion. The execution came despite pleas for clemency from Britain, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Amnesty International, the European Community and international press groups. Iraq said Bazoft signed confessions to being a spy. He had made six reporting trips to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Call on Bush to Send Aid to Anti-Apartheid Groups
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers from both parties urged President Bush on Thursday to provide aid to the African National Congress and other organizations in South Africa to help them prepare for negotiations to end apartheid. Bush met with eight House members recently returned from South Africa, where they met with President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela. House Majority Whip William H. Gray III, D-Pa., the delegation leader, said that the United States should aid the anti-apartheid parties in South Africa just as it has helped emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and elsewhere. Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, D-N.Y., suggested U.S. aid ``in the vicinity of $10 million.'' ``Clearly the African National Organization would be one organization that would qualify for such funding, but it wouldn't be the only one,'' Solarz said. ``Just as we've taken initiatives like this for Nicaragua, for Poland, for the Philippines, for Chile and other countries, the time has now come for us to act in a similar fashion in South Africa as well,'' said Solarz. The lawmakers, including such longtime advocates of stiffer sanctions on South Africa as Reps. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., and Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., said it was time to ``pause'' before imposing new sanctions on de Klerk's government. Mandela, freed from prison last month after 27 years, this week called on Western nations to intensify sanctions. ``We thought it was an appropriate time to pause in the effort at imposing additional sanctions,'' said Wolpe, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. ``But at the same time, we also felt it was very important to maintain existing sanctions in place.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III will leave on a trip to southern Africa on Sunday. He will attend a presidential inauguration in Namibia and is expected to confer with de Klerk in Cape Town. Baker is also seeking to arrange a meeting with Mandela. Rep. Dean A. Gallo, R-N.Y., the co-chairman of the delegation, said the lawmakers came back from Cape Town with ``guarded optimism'' about the future of South Africa. Gray said Bush ``reiterated that he wanted to maintain bipartisan foreign policy in southern Africa,'' but made no commitment to an aid package. Solarz said the United States should not have any compunctions about aiding the ANC, which advocates armed resistance. ``The commitment of an organization to the use of armed struggle as a tactic for the establishment of democracy has not precluded us from providing aid to UNITA in Angola or to the Contras in Nicaragua,'' said Solarz. ``I think the administration has crossed that conceptual Rubicon a long time ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Giving Up Jaguar Cubs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 5th graf, So on, to show message given to Rodriguez's aide, not Rodriguez
DOC.TEXT: With AM-Quayle

Vice President Dan Quayle found himself in a bit of a diplomatic pickle when the president of Paraguay gave him a pair of cuddly jaguar cubs _ members of an endangered species. It was decided that diplomatic protocol required Quayle to accept the cubs, which he was given while visiting Asuncion on Monday, and then try to give them to a zoo, said a Quayle aide speaking only on condition of anonymity. ``We learned about them three days before the trip started. We tried to discourage it. We were told the president had his heart set on it,'' the aide told reporters. But the National Zoo in Washington wouldn't take the jaguars because of their endangered-species status, and an environmental group called Quayle's office to protest their being taken from the wild. So on Thursday, at the presidential inauguration in Brasilia, Quayle sent Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson to give the bad news to an aide of Paraguayan President Andres Rodriguez. Aronson told the Paraguayan that Quayle ``would prefer that the jaguars be released into the wilds of Paraguay to benefit future generations of Paraguayans,'' the aide said. Why had Rodriguez insisted on giving the cubs as a gift? ``He knows they're extremely rare. They are prized in the United States,'' the aide said. However, the United Nations has passed a resolution condemning the use of endangered species as gifts. In Paraguay, Quayle's staff had set up a photo session for the traveling press corps to photograph Quayle and his wife Marilyn playing with the cubs at the U.S. ambassador's house in Asuncion. There was no indication of how Rodriguez reacted to having his present spurned.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Refuses to Comment on Interest in van Gogh's `Irises'
DOC.TEXT: ``Irises,'' the Vincent van Gogh painting that sold for a record $53.9 million in 1987, reportedly has been brought to the J. Paul Getty Museum, which is considering buying it. ``The museum isn't commenting,'' Getty spokeswoman Lori Starr said in response to Wednesday's Los Angeles Times report. Museum officials would say only that no agreement or purchase had taken place. The owner of the masterpiece, financially troubled Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, reportedly has turned down offers of $50 million to $60 million. The painting was delivered to the museum, 30 miles west of Los Angeles, last week, the newspaper said, citing an unidentified source who saw the painting at the Getty. The pating was last reported to be at Bond's office in Sydney. The New York Times on Thursday quoted museum staff members who declined to be identified as saying the painting remains at the museum while negotiations take place involving the Getty, Bond and Sotheby's auction house. Museums often receive artworks before a purchase so curators can verify the work's authenticity and examine it for possible damage. Major acquisitions must be approved by the museum's board of trustees, several of whom have viewed the painting, the Los Angeles Times said. With a $2.1 billion endowment from the late oil baron J. Paul Getty, the museum is the world's richest financial institution. The 1889 painting, characteristic of van Gogh's bold postimpressionist style, depicts a field of midnight-blue irises, except for a single white iris. The landscape is from a corner of the garden at the asylum of St. Paul de Mausole in St. Remy de Provence, where the artist committed himself in 1889-90. Bond acquired the painting Nov. 11, 1987, at Sotheby's, reportedly financing the record auction price with a $27 million loan from the auction house, which accepted the painting as collateral in an unusual transaction. The highly leveraged acquisition, similar to Wall Street takeover deals of whole corporations during the 1980s, was widely criticized for inflating prices in the international art market. The extraordinary prices paid for art in recent years also have placed many works beyond the acquisition budgets of art museums. Since Bond's financial empire began crumbling under the weight of more than $5 billion in debt, there has been widespread speculation among art curators, dealers and collectors about the fate of ``Irises.'' The painting was in private European collections until 1947, when it was purchased for $80,000 by New York philanthropist Joan Whitney Payson. After a version of van Gogh's ``Sunflowers'' sold for $39.9 million in 1987, Payson decided to sell ``Irises'' and use the proceeds to endow a charitable foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Student's Dies While Riding Atop Elevator
DOC.TEXT: A college freshman who fell to his death in a sport called ``elevator surfing'' was the latest casualty of a little-known but dangerous practice that has plagued high-rises for years, officials say. Sometimes called ``elevator action,'' or ``piloting an elevator,'' the hazardous exercise involves climbing atop elevator cars, either through a trapdoor in the car's roof or by jamming doors open from a floor above the car, and riding on the roofs. ``We've taken it terribly seriously. We've been fighting it for a long time,'' said Val Coleman, director of public information for the New York City Housing Authority. Ten deaths and more than 50 injuries have been reported in New York during the past five years, he said. ``It's a very serious problem in our high-rise buildings,'' said Coleman, who worked on a recently released cautionary videotape on the issue called ``Children are Too Young to Die.'' At Otis Elevator Co., the nation's largest elevator manufacturer, officials have known about the dangerous games for some time, said Michael Jordan-Reilly, spokesman for the Hartford, Conn.-based company. ``This is one of our major concerns,'' he said. At the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, 18-year-old Joel Mangion of Newton was found dead at the bottom of an elevator shaft Sunday. Friends said he had been ``elevator surfing,'' jumping from one car to another in the double shaft. About a year ago, a student suffered serious injuries after falling 30 feet in a shaft, university officials said. In the early 1970s, a student died after riding in a chair tied to the bottom of a car. Students said they have heard of the practice, although it isn't something most people try. ``Usually on the weekends when people are drunk, you hear about someone who went `elevator surfing,''' student Susan Beckett told the campus newspaper, The Collegian. Donald A. Robinson, director of environmental health and safety for UMass, said officials are looking for new ways to discourage elevator surfing. ``The message needs to be made very clear how elevators should be used and not misused and to really emphasize the obvious significant consequences,'' he said. ``We are really trying to take a hard look at all the issues and make all efforts to make sure it doesn't happen again.'' Industry officials said it's difficult to determine the extent of the problem because elevator deaths are not reported to a central agency. Jordan-Reilly said the problem has probably existed ``as long as there have been elevators and as long as there have been people who want to try something dangerous.''

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says No Need For Reforms in His Country
With AM-Brazil, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro said Cuba has no need for Soviet-style reforms but that relations between Cuba and the Soviet Union have not been hurt by his rejection of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ``perestroika.'' ``Cuba is not the Soviet Union. We are different countries with different origins,'' the Cuban president said Wednesday in an interview with TV Globo, Brazil's largest network. He was in Brazil for the inauguration of President Fernando Collor de Mello. Castro has remained adamant in his refusal to accept the reforms increasingly embraced in the East bloc, and he showed no sign of wavering in the interview. The revolutionary leader said he still has ``the most profound conviction that for Cuba there is no solution superior, or path better'' than socialism. Despite his differences with Gorbachev on reform, there are no fundamental problems in relations between the two countries, Castro said. ``I wouldn't speak of ideological differences, but different paths that respond to different situations,'' he said. ``Our economic relations with the Soviet Union are perfectly well,'' Castro added. Even if aid from the Soviet Union was reduced, Cuba's economy would not suffer seriously, he claimed. Castro also said he saw no need for Western-style elections in Cuba. ``We have our own type of election...It would take long to explain our (political) process, but we could have a debate to see which is more democratic, what we have in Cuba or another type,'' he said. Congresses of Cuba's ruling Communist Party choose the country's leadership. There are no popular elections.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brazil, Bjt
Quayle Indirectly Urges Castro to Hold Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Quayle leaves Brasilia 7 p.m. EST. top prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Thursday he wants ``anyone who has contact'' with Cuban President Fidel Castro to urge him to hold elections. Quayle also repeated his call for Cuba to halt arms shipments to rebels fighting the U.S.-backed government of El Salvador. But the vice president himself avoided contact with Castro at Thursday's inauguration of Brazil's new president. Quayle told a news conference he had discussed the matter of Cuba with other Latin leaders during his week-long trip through South America. ``We have encouraged all people who have any contact with Fidel Castro to urge him to stop the war in El Salvador, to stop funding'' the well-organized guerilla movement. Asked what he had discussed with Nicaragua's outgoing President Daniel Ortega the day before, Quayle said that the disarmament of Ortega's ruling Sandinistas when they leave power is a matter of concern to the United States. ``There are reports that many arms are being shipped out to the Sandinistas that are taking them to their homes or taking them to the hills, ready to fight again at another time. That would be a most unfortunate development,'' with the pending transfer of power to Violeta Chamorro, who defeated Ortega in the Feb. 25 election. At the inauguration, Castro entered the hall just ahead of Quayle and was immediately surrounded as he made his way up the crowded aisle to his front-row seat. Quayle trailed several yards back. He greeted a few people in the aisle and edged past the clot around Castro to his own seat four places down the front row. In his news conference before leaving Brazil, Quayle continued a drumbeat against Castro. ``We also urge anyone who is in contact with Castro to ask him when he's going to have elections. ... Elections have been held elsewhere in Latin America and Cuba should be no exception.'' Quayle spoke about Cuba in talks Thursday with Collor and with Bolivia's president, Jaime Paz Zamora, who sat next to Castro at the inauguration. Castro, flanked on the other side by a representative of the Vatican, chatted frequently with Paz Zamora during Collor's lengthy speech. Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said Quayle had asked Collor to urge Castro to bring democracy to Cuba. Quayle earlier won assurances from President Carlos Menem that Argentina would try to exert pressure on Castro as well. Quayle is due to return to Washington on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Marine Salvager Says Hazelwood Acted Professionally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony, salvager saying Hazelwood acted professionally, and to CORRECT 3rd graf pvs that ship sailed March 23 sted March 24. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `But Superior...'. DELETES 12-14th grafs pvs, `Hazelwood, 43,...', now redundant, picking up 15th graf, `Prosecutors maintain...'.
DOC.TEXT: The man who salvaged the Exxon Valdez said today that Joseph Hazelwood acted professionally after the tanker ran aground on a reef and was clearly trying to keep it stable until help arrived. ``What he did was very professional. It reflects his training,'' said Julius Leitz, a marine salvager from Portland, Ore. ``Everything he did was aimed at keeping the vessel on the rock, which was the prudent thing to do.'' Leitz, called by Hazelwood's defense team, disputed the testimony of several prosecution experts, including another salvager who said the ship would have sunk if it was extricated from a reef in Prince William Sound. ``I disagree,'' said Leitz. ``It wouldn't have sunk.'' He added that speculation on the subject was pointless, because, ``that's all assuming the ship would leap off the rocks. I don't think that would happen.'' The witness said the tanker would have required levitation to come off the rocks where it was impaled March 24. Defense attorney Michael Chalos led the witness through a series of questions concerning Hazelwood's immediate actions after his ship rammed the reef. After each question he asked whether Hazelwood's actions were prudent or inprudent. ``Prudent,'' the witness answered repeatedly. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is the only Exxon Valdez crew member charged in the grounding which caused the nation's worst oil spill. The tanker rammed jagged Bligh Reef, gashing its hull and spewing nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil in a spill which devastated fisheries, wildlife and the scenic shores of Prince William Sound. The former skipper is charged with a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted he could be sentenced to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. On Wednesday, an Exxon tanker captain who once sailed with Hazelwood gave him high marks for seamanship on the day of the grounding, but said he might not have imbibed as Hazelwood did before boarding his ship. Ivan Mihajlovic, testifying in Hazelwood's defense, said he found no fault with the skipper's navigation nor with his decision to leave the bridge while his tanker crossed Alaska's Prince William Sound. On cross-examination, Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole gave the witness a prosecution scenario in which Hazelwood had five drinks during seven hours ashore in Valdez on March 23, the day his ship sailed. The accident happened in the early morning hours of March 24. ``Do you have an opinion whether that is proper conduct for an Exxon master?'' asked Cole. ``That's probably something I wouldn't do,'' said Mihajlovic. Chalos objected to the question because of a dispute in testimony as to how much Hazelwood actually drank. But Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone said Cole was entitled to ask questions ``based on his view of the evidence.'' Chalos then asked: ``You said your own personal preference wouldn't be to drink ashore. Does the fact someone else would (drink) make it improper?'' ``No,'' responded the witness. Mihajlovic was among the final witnesses in the defense case, which is expected to conclude by week's end. Prosecutors maintain that Hazelwood was reckless in leaving the bridge in control of a third mate during a transit they claim was hazardous. But Mijalovic said he doesn't consider Prince William Sound hazardous and noted he has left the bridge of his own vessel in that area. He said there is no regulation requiring a captain be on the bridge for the transit and said the only such regulation in existence is for the Panama Canal. Like other seagoing witnesses, Mihajlovic was asked to assess the difficulty of a 10-degree right rudder turn, the missed maneuver that apparently let the Exxon Valdez drift into the reef. ``Oh, I'm sure nobody here could do that,'' the witness said, looking around the courtroom. ``Just put them on a ship.'' The judge recessed court a half-hour early Wednesday after hearing that Redoubt Volcano had erupted again and ash might be drifting toward Anchorage. ``We're going to let you get a jump on the volcano,'' he told jurors.

DOC.SECOND: Keating Lawyer Said in Letter That She Pressured Regulators
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for savings and loan financier Charles H. Keating Jr. bragged in a 1988 letter released Thursday that she had pressured federal regulators. ``You have the (Federal Home Loan Bank) board right where you want them and you should be able to reach an agreement ... which will completely satisfy you,'' Washington lawyer Margery Waxman wrote in the May 10, 1988, letter. Waxman, who was referring to an upcoming meeting with board officials, told Keating she had ``put pressure on'' M. Danny Wall, chairman of the bank board and then chief regulator of thrift institutions. House Banking Committee Chairman Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, who released the letter, said it strongly suggests ``the fix was in at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.'' Banking panel aides refused to say how they obtained the letter. Keating is chairman of a holding company that owned Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif. It failed in April and is expected to require the nation's costliest S&L bailout, about $2 billion. At the time the letter was sent, Keating was fighting federal efforts to rein in his institution. Bank board examiners based in San Francisco had recommended that the government seize Lincoln and Keating had appealed to authorities in Washington. ``As you know, I have put pressure on Wall to work toward meeting your demands and he has so instructed his staff,'' Waxman wrote. ``They all know the Wednesday meeting is crucial to their future. If they mess up this time, it is all over.'' The letter was written five days after a divided bank board decided to move the Lincoln case from the jurisdiction of its San Francisco office to Washington and on the same day Wall had a telephone conversation with Keating. Waxman outlined what she expected to be the result of the meeting, including a new examination of Lincoln and memorandum of understanding between the institution and regulators, which was executed five days later. ``San Francisco is finished,'' she assured Keating. ``There is no going back to San Francisco and nothing can be done to follow up their exam.'' In the new exam, she said, ``nothing will be done ... that you are not aware of in advance.'' Also, she told Keating that bank board personnel ``will not be able to enforce any violation (of the memorandum of understanding) ... without going to the board first. ... This will give you two bites at the apple _ before the board and in court if necessary.'' ``The letter, written in strong declarative language, tracks with amazing accuracy the actions taken by the board _ actions which were interpreted publicly as clamping down on Lincoln,'' Gonzalez said. ``In reality, as the letter carefully explains, the actions were to be shams designed not to punish but to allow Keating an escape route.'' Neither Wall nor Waxman immediately returned telephone calls seeking comment. Rosemary Stewart, enforcement director of the bank board, declined to comment immediately. The letter indicates it was telecopied to Keating in Phoenix. Its existence was first disclosed in stories in Thursday's editions of the San Francisco Chronicle.

DOC.HEAD: European Parliament: U.S. Must Pay Compensation to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament Thursday adopted a resolution calling on the United States to pay Nicaragua compensation for damage caused in attacks by the U.S.-armed Contra rebels. The decision was in support of a June 1986 ruling by the International Court of Justice in The Hague. That ruling said U.S. support for the Contra rebels was in violation of the United Nations Charter and constituted ``unlawful use of force.'' The court, also known as the World Court, called on the U.S. to compensate Nicaragua for rebel attacks but said the amount of payment should be decided between the two sides. At the time of the decision, Nicaragua said rebel damage amounted to $375 million. The U.S. has refused to accept the ruling, which is not binding. The European Parliament welcomed Wednesday's decision by President Bush to give Nicaragua $300 million in aid and lift a trade embargo, but it demanded the disbanding of the rebels. The U.S. moves followed the victory in presidential elections of the U.S.-backed candidate. The European Parliament called on the U.S. Congress to guarantee Nicaraguan exports access to the U.S. market. The statements were made in a resolution adopted by the 518-seat assembly of the European Community. The resolution was presented by all of the parliament's political groups, except for the extreme right-wing. It said demobilization of the Contra rebels was ``particularly urgent...in order that the largest possible proportion of available economic and human resources can be devoted to economic and social development.'' The parliament also called on the European Community to strengthen its political and economic cooperation with Central America to show ``our partners that the economic consequences of the current events in Central and Eastern Europe do not imply a reduction in European financial support for Central America.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Protests Soviet Refusal to Allow Use of Missile-Spotting X-ray Gear
DOC.TEXT: The United States is pushing the Soviet Union to allow X-ray inspections of sealed missile cannisters, as required by the treaty banning medium-range missiles, the State Department said Thursday. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that the Soviets are refusing to permit U.S. inspectors to use a ``Cargoscan'' X-ray device at the missile-production facility at Votkinsk and that some missile cannisters subsequently have been shipped without being inspected. She said U.S. inspectors at Votkinsk, nearly 700 miles east of Moscow, have declared the refusal an ``ambiguity,'' which she called ``the most serious action our inspectors can take'' under the on-site inspection provisions of the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which bans missiles with ranges of 300 to 3,400 miles. ``The U.S. regards any question of compliance with the INF treaty as a very serious matter,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We are continuing to press the Soviets to solve this problem by allowing us to use the Cargoscan system.'' American and Soviet technical teams have been dispatched to the plant to examine the Cargoscan system, which the United States says meets the treaty's requirements for a non-damaging X-ray device able to determine what is inside a missile cannister. The U.S. team hopes to demonstrate that the equipment works as specified and to answer the Soviets' technical questions, she said. Secretary of State James A. Baker has protested the Soviet action to Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who agreed that the issue needs to be resolved as soon as possible, Ms. Tutwiler said. Former President Reagan, who signed the treaty with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1987, earlier accused the Soviets of violating previous arms control accords. The INF treaty, therefore, contained a complex on-site verification system designed to respond to skeptics in Congress who said the Soviets were likely to cheat. Mrs. Tutwiler said the Soviets claim the Cargoscan equipment is not yet operating in compliance with the agreement. ``As a result, they (the Soviets) recently shipped a number of missile cannisters from the production facility at the plant without allowing U.S. inspectors to use Cargoscan equipment.'' She declined to say how many missiles had been shipped. The United States wants to examine cannisters said to contain SS-25 missiles, permitted by the treaty, to make sure they do not contain SS-20 missiles, forbidden by the pact. The SS-25 is a variation of the SS-20 and the scanning equipment is said to be able to tell the two apart. The Soviets do not have X-ray imaging equipment at U.S. missile production plants in the United States because U.S. missiles are not shipped in cannisters, she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Lodging Deduction When Doctor's Care Not at Hand
DOC.TEXT: Lodging expenses for health-related travel are tax-deductible only if necessary to obtain a physician's care, the U.S. Tax Court has ruled. Merely traveling on a doctor's recommendation to a more favorable climate to alleviate a specific ailment is not enough to justify a deduction, the court held; the travel must be essential to care provided by a doctor in a hospital or similar facility. The ruling earlier this week was the first time the court had considered a 1984 law that in certain situations allows lodging costs to be included in deductible medical expenses. The court case involved Earlene Polyak of Trenton, Mich., who suffered from chronic heart, artery and lung problems. Following her doctors' advice, she began spending winters in Florida, living in a travel trailer while her husband stayed at their home in Michigan. Her physicians did not refer Mrs. Polyak to any doctors in Florida, and she visited a doctor only twice during her five months there. She and her husband claimed a medical deduction for $1,426 they spent to rent a campground lot for the trailer but were turned down by the Internal Revenue Service. The new law was written to benefit people who must travel away from home because specialized care is not available locally or, in the case of some chemotherapy treatment for cancer, for example, may be obtained on an out-patient basis at a considerably lower cost. In siding with the IRS against Mrs. Polyak, Senior Judge William A. Goffe noted the new law permits deduction of transportation costs in such cases so long as it is ``primarily for and essential to medical care.'' But lodging expenses must pass a three-part test: _They must be primarily for and essential to medical care; _The care must be provided by a physician in a licensed hospital or equivalent facility, and _The travel and lodging must hold ``no significant element of personal pleasure, recreation or vacation.'' Goffe concluded that Mrs. Polyak passed the first and third tests but failed the second. ``Mrs. Polyak did not go to Florida to seek medical care from a physician,'' Goffe wrote. ``The medical treatment received by Mrs. Polyak was incidental and of routine nature.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pop singer Janet Jackson's benefit concert only raised $11,000 for charities because expenses ate up most of the proceeds, organizers said. The $11,000 was about 15 percent of the $76,000 gross and will be split between a soup kitchen and food bank that serve the homeless, said Doug Clouse, a spokesman for Ogden Allied Presents, which manages the Pensacola Civic Center. Other charities will get nothing, he said. ``The rest of the money went for expenses for the show: labor, staff, putting the tickets on sale,'' Clouse said Wednesday. Representatives of charities disagreed about whether they had been promised shares of the proceeds from the Feb. 27 $10-a-ticket concert. ``I don't want Janet Jackson to be perceived as going back on her word because she has not,'' said Lee Esckilsen, the civic center's executive director. ``They dropped close to a million dollars into the local economy. At least 8,000 people got to see a great show. Plus she's contributing to charitable organizations.'' Ms. Jackson started her world tour March 1 in Miami.

Britain's Prince Charles and his wife, Diana, arrived Thursday for a five-day visit to strengthen relations with Nigeria and its former colonial power. The couple were welcomed to the capital of Africa's most populous nation by Adm. Augustus Aikhomu, second in command in Gen. Ibrahim Babangida's military government. The Princess of Wales looked cool in a green dress as she stepped into the West African heat. The visitors were driven to State House, where Babangida was giving them a state banquet. Charles, the heir to the British throne, visited Nigeria in 1956 with his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, when he was 8. The prince and his wife will visit a large bronze statute of his mother scuplted during that trip.
