DOC.TEXT: New York Mets outfielder Darryl Strawberry has been ordered to pay $40,000 in back payments and $2,000 a month to support his son. The money will be divided between Lisa Clayton of St. Louis, the child's mother, and Thomas J. Frawley, who was appointed a conservator for the boy. St. Louis County Circuit Judge Philip J. Sweeney said the purpose of appointing a conservator was to assure that money would be available for the child's education. The child was born in June 1988. Sweeney's order noted that Strawberry earns $110,000 a month. Strawberry, 28, is seeking a new contract that would pay him $12 million over four years. The Mets have countered with $2.5 million a year for two years. At a hearing in January, Stuart Cofman, Clayton's attorney, introduced blood tests to support the claim that Strawberry was the father of the child. Strawberry did not contest the findings.

West German film director Werner Herzog's career is hitting a different note: He's planning to direct a new production of Mozart's ``The Magic Flute'' for the Metropolitan Opera. Herzog's version of ``Die Zauberflote'' is to open Jan. 10, Met officials said. It is to be conducted by James Levine and features Kathleen Battle as Pamina, Francisco Araiza as Tamino, Kurt Moll as Sarastro, Luciana Serra as the Queen of the Night and Manfred Hemm as Papageno. ``Die Zauberflote'' is one of four Mozart operas the Met is presenting in its 1990-91 season as part of the Lincoln Center's Mozart Bicentennial series, marking the 200th anniversary of the composer's death. The Met plans to perform seven Mozart operas in 1991. Herzog is known for such films as ``Burden of Dreams,'' ``Man of Flowers'' and ``Aguirre, the Wrath of God.'' Herzog, Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Volker Schloendorff were among the directors who helped make German cinema known internationally during the 1960s and '70s.

Composer Michael Tilson Thomas says he hears the sad but hopeful echos of the past in Audrey Hepburn's reading from the diary of Anne Frank. Thomas, whose grandparents Boris and Bessie Thomashefsky were founders and stars of the Yiddish Theater of America, said he used Miss Frank's writings as a framework for his newest composition, ``Concerts for Life.'' The first of four concerts, to benefit UNICEF, will be Monday night at Philadelphia's Academy of Music. The program begins with Brahms' ``Academic Festival Overture'' and ends with Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5. In between is Thomas' ``From The Diary of Anne Frank,'' narrated by Miss Hepburn, who is UNICEF's goodwill ambassador. The heart of the project is Miss Frank's diary, which chronicles the young Jewish girl's feelings as she and her family hid from Nazis for two years in the attic of an Amsterdam office building. Overall, Thomas said, he finds his own creation ``expressive, hopeful and the bright, shining spirit of the innocence of Anne Frank comes through.'' ``To hear them, to hear the fine, delicate phrasing she gives ... with the music providing the fabric, it's as if you were listening in to Anne Frank herself,'' Thomas said of Miss Hepburn. The program also will be performed in Chicago on March 21, in Houston on March 23 and at the United Nations General Assembly on March 25.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican and Soviets Forge Ties for First Time
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican and the Soviet Union established diplomatic ties Thursday for the first time since the founding of the communist state 74 years ago. The Vatican and Moscow said the two sides have agreed to exchange representatives with the rank of apostolic nuncio, or papal envoy, and extraordinary ambassador. The ties fall short of full diplomatic relations. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro described them as ``pre-diplomatic relations'' and said there was ``room for further development.'' He gave no indication when ties might be upgraded. There are a number of problems to be resolved, including the status of the Ukrainian Catholic Church. It was suppressed under Soviet dictator Josef Stalin and incorporated into the Russian Orthodox Church. Still, the move was an extraordinary advance in relations between the center of the Roman Catholic Church and a state that declared war against religion after the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. It also reflects the vastly improved climate in relations between the church and Soviet bloc countries since the collapse of hard-line Communist leaderships. Relations have steadily improved under Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The decision to establish ties came during his talks with the pope at the Vatican on Dec. 1. It was the first meeting between a Roman pontiff and a supreme Soviet leader. Initially, the two representatives will not have permanent residences. But Navarro said the papal nuncio could decide to keep an assistant in Moscow if he thought it was needed. The Vatican will be represented by Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno, an Italian prelate who has been a roving Vatican envoy to Eastern Europe. The name of the Soviet ambassador was not immediately announced. The Vatican and Moscow had diplomatic relations under the Russian czars, but those ties were broken when the Communists came to power. One of the main points of friction between Moscow and Rome has been the Ukrainian church. It would regain legal status under a proposed freedom of religion law promised by Gorbachev when he met with the pope. But as yet the measure has not been adopted. Gorbachev also invited the pope to the Soviet Union, but the Vatican gave no indication when John Paul would accept the invitation. The pope had previously been barred from visiting his flock in Lithuania. The situation could be further complicated by the republic's recent declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. Over the past few months, in a further sign of the improved Vatican-Soviet relations, John Paul has received a number of Soviet visitors. A Soviet journalist for the first time traveled on the pope's plane on an African pilgrimage in January. In the past year, full relations were reestablished with Poland, the pope's homeland, and Hungary. John Paul visits Czechoslovakia next month. On Wednesday, the Vatican restored the leadership of the long-persecuted Roman Catholic Church in Romania and revived the Eastern rite branch that was suppressed there in 1948. Its situation was similar to that of the Ukrainian Catholic church.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kidnappers Threaten Three American Professors, Soviet Jews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 7 grafs at end with more background on Soviet emmigration to Israel and on political struggle in Iran. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Moslem extremist group holding three American professors hostage threatened Thursday to kill them if the United States fails to meet its unspecified demands. The group, the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, also threatened to attack airlines that carry Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel. It said individuals and organizations who recently said the hostages should be freed on humanitarian grounds should stay out of the affair. The organization, believed made up of Shiite Moslem zealots loyal to Iran, made the threats in a statement delivered the independent newspaper An-Nahar. The statement was accompanied by a photograph of Professor Robert Polhill, one of three American educators kidnapped from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987. The other two are Alann Steen, 49, of Boston, and Jesse Turner, 41, of Boise, Idaho. Polhill, a New Yorker, is 54. The statement was the first from groups holding foreign hostages since March 6, when a group holding Americans Joseph Cicippio and Edward Austin Tracy broke a seven-month silence to say no captives were about to be freed. ``There is no intention to release hostages,'' said the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which also threatened suicide attacks on U.S. interests. There are 18 foreign hostages, including eight Americans. Friday marks the fifth year in captivity for the longest-held American hostage, Terry A. Anderson. The 42-year-old chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Thursday's handwritten statement in Arabic said: ``The organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine denounces media reports about humanitarian moves to free the hostages and close this file. ``It asks the authors of these moves not to interfere in this matter because we are holding agents and spies against our people, and they will be executed if the American administration fails to meet our demands.'' Iran's Tehran Times newspaper, which has close ties to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, said in two recent editorials that the hostages should be freed on Islamic, humanitarian grounds. Rafsanjani himself said he believed the issue was moving toward a solution. Sheikh Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual guide of Lebanon's Hezbollah, or Party of God, also said in a February sermon that a humanitarian means of freeing the hostages had to be found. Hezbollah is believed to be the Shiite Moslem umbrella organization for the extremist groups holding the 18 foreign hostages in Lebanon. The statement Thursday did not spell out the demands the kidnappers expected the Bush administration to meet. The group had previously offered to trade the three professors for 400 Arab prisoners in Israeli jails. Israel rejected the offer and the Reagan administration refused to pressure Israel to change its stance. ``We did not carry out the death sentences because we are waiting for the appropriate time,'' the statement said, without mentioning a specific deadline. The statement said: ``We have laid down the trap and are eagerly waiting for the promised American adventure to free them (hostages) by force. ``We announce that there is no solution for and no deal about this issue except within the framework of exchanges.'' The statement accused the United States of responsibility for the current emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel ``after pressure on the Soviets who succumbed and collaborated in this big conspiracy.'' ``Our people shall not stand handcuffed in front of this conspiracy. We shall not stand by watching, but shall begin taking the adequate measures to prevent the arrival of the Soviets,'' the statement added. ``All airports facilitating the transport as well as airlines, their jetliners and offices, will be direct targets for us. This is a warning and a threat,'' the statement said. Hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews are expected in Israel in the coming years as the Soviet Union has lifted all their restrictions on leaving. The influx has created an uproar in the Arab world. It caused fears that the Soviet Jews would settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians hope one day to create a homeland. The fate of the hostages has often been linked to developments in the Middle East in the past, but this was apparently the first time they were tied to the issue of Soviet Jewish immigration. The 18 hostages include eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, and Irishman and an Italian. Their fate at the hands of Iranian-backed groups is believed linked to a power struggle in Tehran between moderates who seek better ties with the West and radicals that seek to confront it. Rafsanjani, leader of the moderate camp, has made several statements in the past about wanting to see the hostages freed. But he is believed to have little influence over the extremist groups holding them.

DOC.HEAD: New Brazilian Leader _ From Silver Spoon to Social Democrat
With AM-Brazil, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello was born into a wealthy land-owning family in Brazil's near-feudal northeast, but in his inaugural speech Thursday he pledged to work for the poor. ``My first commitment _ inalterable _ is to democracy. I have a sacred commitment ... to improve social conditions,'' the tall, trim president said. Foreign dignitaries ranging from Vice President Dan Quayle to presidents Fidel Castro of Cuba and Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua looked on. Yet Collor de Mello, the first popularly elected head of Latin America's largest country in 29 years, won office speaking in favor of a free market, private ownership of state companies and an open door for foreign investment. During the election campaign, his leftist opponents called him a ``test-tube candidate'' and a ``mouthpiece for the right.'' They charged his candidacy was paid for by powerful Brazilian business and media interests. But Collor de Mello insisted he was his own man. He rejected backing from powerful Sao Paulo business group and tried to maintain a discreet distance from the massive Globo media empire, which nevertheless openly supported him. Collor de Mello was born Aug. 12, 1949, into a powerful media and land-owning clan in Alagoas. It is a poor state in northeastern Brazil dominated by sugar-plantation barons and still known for its bloody family feuds. His father, the late Arnon de Mello, a governor and senator, shot and killed a colleague on the Senate floor in 1963. Collor de Mello was raised in a wealthy neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro. When Brasilia became Brazil's capital in 1960, he moved there with his father, lived in a mansion and later became the city's karate champion. He earned college degrees in economics and journalism. In 1975 he married Rio heiress and socialite Lilibeth Monteiro de Carvalho. They had two children and later divorced. In 1984 he married Rosane Malta, a hometown girl from another Alagoas clan, then barely out of high school _ now Brazil's first lady at age 25. Collor de Mello entered politics in 1979 when _ thanks mostly to his father's connections _ he was appointed mayor of Maceio, the capital of Alagoas, under a right-wing military regime that seized power in 1964. Three years later he was elected to Congress on the ticket of the regime's official Social Democratic Party. Collor de Mello was elected governor of Alagoas in 1986. Last year he formed his own National Reconstruction Party and announced his bid for the presidency. Collor de Mello topped a field of 21 candidates in the Nov. 15, 1989, first-round ballot for president. He then was pitted against Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a union leader and former factory worker in a Dec. 17 runoff, which he won by 4 million votes in a registered electorate of 82 million.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Presses White House Effort for Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: The White House budget chief sought to lure Democrats into talks on deficit-reduction on Thursday, telling lawmakers he has ``tried to switch the emphasis'' away from President Bush's pledge to not raise taxes. Budget director Richard Darman told Congress' Joint Economic Committee the administration remains opposed to the tax increases proposed by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., last Sunday as part of a massive deficit-cutting plan. But he said he has tried in his appearances before Congress this year to avoid focusing on Bush's campaign pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``I've tried to switch the emphasis,'' Darman said. ``Let's talk about what helps provide economic growth.'' Many congressional Democrats consider tax increases vital to any serious effort to reduce the budget deficit, which the administration expects to be about $120 billion this year. Bush has repeatedly said he opposes higher taxes, but he and his aides have hinted in recent days at a possible softening of that position. Questioned by Democrats on the committee, Darman even conceded there are items in Bush's proposed fiscal 1991 budget ``that could be interpreted as tax increases in a narrow ... sense.'' Bush's spending plan called for $13.9 billion in new revenues next year. The new receipts would include extending the Social Security payroll tax to 7 million uncovered state and local government workers, by increasing taxes paid by airline passengers and by raising other fees. The budgets for the last three years have been shaped by talks between congressional leaders and the White House. Many leading Democrats, unhappy with the results, have said Congress should shape the spending plan itself this year. But Darman has been trying for weeks to get congressional Democrats to negotiate. ``I continue to believe that the only way to responsible deficit reduction is through bipartisan agreement,'' Darman said. Darman also said he believes Rostenkowski's deficit-cutting proposal ``would not contribute satisfactorily to economic growth.'' He added, however, that it would only ``marginally hinder'' the economy. Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, defended his plan, saying it was preferable to this year's two other prominent proposals. Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., has proposed cutting the Social Security payroll tax rate, while Bush has continued pressing for a cut in the capital gains tax rate. Critics have said both would ultimately boost the federal deficit. ``If we lack the collective guts to increase revenues to pay our bills, I only hope that we are responsible enough to avoid cutting them and making the deficit worse,'' Rostenkowski told the Mid-Continent Oil and Gas Association in a lunchtime speech.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Grants Seabrook License
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Thursday signed a full-power license for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, ending any chance opponents will be able to prevent it from operating before court appeals are completed. ``This is a major victory for New England consumers,'' said Edward Brown, president of New Hampshire Yankee, which operates Seabrook. ``Our 17-year licensing saga is over.'' But opponents said the legal battle to shut down the plant would continue. ``We have not yet begun to fight,'' said Scott Denman, director of the Safe Energy Communication Council, an anti-Seabrook group that has been aiding the legal battle. ``The lawsuit will go on and the final outcome is yet to be known.'' Thomas Murley, director of the NRC's Office of Nuclear Reactor Regulation, made the license official two weeks after the NRC voted unanimously to allow the New Hampshire plant to operate commercially. The commission placed a two-week hold on its vote to allow time for filing court appeals. NRC spokesman John Kopeck said Thursday that the license had been signed. The signing came a day after the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington refused to block the issuance of the license. Opponents argued that evacuation plans for the population around Seabrook are inadequate. The actual granting of the license sets in motion a months-long process of accelerating the plant to full-power. Brown said plant officials would need several days to review hundreds of pages of technical specifications accompanying the license before beginning the start-up process. The plant will generate electricity for the first time within a few weeks, Brown said. After between two to three months of increasing power and a variety of tests, the $6.5 billion plant would be ready to go into commercial operation. Located along the coast about two miles north of the Massachusetts border, Seabrook's 1,150 megawatt reactor can power about a million New England homes.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: It's not all pate and puff pastry when culinary professionals get together to nosh and share know-how, which is why their convention this year features country ham, barbecue and other Dixie delights. The International Association of Culinary Professionals, composed of chefs, cookbook authors and other food aficionados, is highlighting Southern cooking because the cuisine remains a mystery to most people outside the region, convention planners say. On the agenda for the four-day convention, which wraps up Saturday, was a workshop tracking the history of Southern food from South Carolina's Low Country to Louisiana's bayous; a seminar on creating new dishes from Southern basics with Southern food expert Nathalie Dupree; and an old-fashioned barbecue that dramatizes food's social function in the South. As cookbook author John Egerton put it: ``Life without a little South in your mouth ... is a bland and dreary prospect.'' To commemorate the 100th anniversary of peanut butter, conventioneers dined on peanut butter soup, beef with a Thai peanut sauce, and peanut butter cookies, among other dishes. A 12-foot jar of peanut butter _ enough to make 16,000 sandwiches _ was also on display, said Mitch Head of the Peanut Advisory Board. ``They were coming here to the peanut capital of the world. They wanted to recognize the peanut's importance to worldwide cuisine,'' Head said of the planners. Julia Child, Jacques Pepin and Paul Prudhomme were some of the cooking celebrities on hand. The IACP has 1,400 members in about 20 countries.

A pond fountain at the University Center at Tulsa apparently was not showering amour upon a pair of swans because the birds refused to consider mating until the water was turned off. Brad Buffum, chief engineer at the school, wondered why the swans failed to begin their mating rituals despite recent spring-like weather. Buffum checked with local swan experts and finally identified the problem _ a new fountain installed in the campus reflecting pool several months ago. When Buffum turned off the fountain, the swans revitalized their romance. The pair already are gathering materials for a nest, Buffum said.

Sharon Kopriva has seen her work _ papier mache representations of mummies _ on display at art galleries across the country, but never in a morgue. That's where one of her creations was taken by police. The mummy art apparently was picked up by Houston police when they helped a landlord enter a residence to find out why water was leaking into an apartment below. They found a leaking aquarium and the mummy-like figure, according to The Houston Post. The owner, who had purchased the piece from Ms. Kopriva in 1986, had left it there along with other property while moving to a new residence, Ms. Kopriva said. Harris County Medical Examiner's office investigator Cecil Wingo would say little about the case, other than that it was much ado about nothing. He said he did not want to embarrass the legitimate art collector. One official said the mummy was taken to the morgue to determine if it had human parts, and was merely a case where the police who found the figure didn't know anything about ``bone anatomy.'' Ms. Kopriva says people often mistake her artwork for real mummies, ``but not for a very long time.'' ``It's a very mummy-looking piece,'' the artist said of the 6-foot-tall figure.

DOC.HEAD: Three-Day Probe Uncovers 7,000 Minors Working in Violation of Law
DOC.TEXT: A surprise nationwide sweep of fast-food restaurants and other businesses found 7,000 teen-agers employed for too many hours or in dangerous jobs in violation of child-labor laws, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said Thursday. The three-day investigation, called ``Operation Child Watch,'' is expected to result in more than $1.8 million in civil fines against businesses, Mrs. Dole said. Fines totaling $2.7 million were assessed during all of 1989. The majority of the allegations involved firms in which 14- and 15-year-olds worked more hours or later at night during the school week than allowed under federal law, said William Brooks, an assistant labor secretary. But there were also more than 900 youngsters, mostly 16- and 17-year-olds, who were performing dangerous tasks or using hazardous equipment such as power-driven meat-slicing machinery, dough mixers and paper-balers. Mrs. Dole said labor shortages are tempting firms to violate child-labor laws in order to find enough workers. That problem will only worsen in coming years, she said, since the number of workers between the ages of 16 and 24 is expected to drop by about 2 million, or 8 percent, by the year 2000. She said businesses may need to consider offering better fringe benefits and higher salaries in order to attract workers. Federal law forbids 14-year-olds and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours during the five-day school week. Eight hours is permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during vacations. Those youngsters may not work outside the hours of 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., or 9 p.m. from June 1 to Labor Day. Brooks also said nearly 200 youngsters under 14 _ barred from most jobs, with a few exceptions such as certain farm work and newspaper routes, were found illegally employed. Most of the 7,000 alleged violations were at service businesses, such as restaurants, grocery stores, pizza and donut shops or dry cleaning firms, officials said. Mrs. Dole declined to name businesses involved, saying investigations are still going on. Brooks said one food store employed more than 20 minors whose duties included the operation of paper-baling machinery, which he called ``a particularly dangerous piece of equipment.'' Pizza shops in two states employed more than 50 youngsters to illegally drive cars, he said. Two 16-year-olds were found illegally employed at a roofing company, he said. One of the youngsters' fingers were crushed and nearly severed when a load shifted on the back of a truck; the other boy had fallen off a roof but did not sustain long-term injuries, Brooks said. The three-day probe, which involved 500 federal investigators who visited businesses in all 50 states, was intended to send a signal that the government is strengthening its efforts to protect children from exploitation in the workplace, Mrs. Dole said at a news conference. ``The cop is on the beat. Violations, whether motivated by greed or by ignorance, will not be tolerated,'' she said. Mrs. Dole said skeptics of the Bush administration's commitment to child labor enforcement are needlessly worried. ``I think the proof is in the pudding, as they say. There will be additional strike forces,'' she said. In a letter to Mrs. Dole this week, Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called for more money to combat child-labor violations. He noted that there are fewer than 1,000 federal investigators assigned to such matters. ``With so little oversight, it is little wonder than child-labor violations are becoming more widespread. ... In the absence of strong federal action, the future may be even bleaker,'' Schumer wrote. Rep. Don Pease, D-Ohio, said he welcomed Mrs. Dole's ``readiness to get tough with child labor scofflaws'' but said ``the situation calls for more than a finger in the dike.'' Pease and Schumer plan to introduce legislation next month to expand the definition of child-labor violations. It also may provide more funding for enforcement and increase the penalties beyond the current $1,000 maximum, a spokesman said. Mrs. Dole said the government should first make the most of current resources. ``Then if additional funds are needed, you can bet I'll ask for those funds,'' she said, adding that other proposed changes are under review. Of the 3,400 businesses visited during the three-day probe, about 1,400 were in apparent violation of child labor practices, she said. Last year, the Labor Department's wage and hour division, which enforces child-labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, found 22,508 minors to be illegally employed, an all-time high. Last Thursday, the department sued the Burger King restaurant chain in U.S. District Court in Miami, alleging child labor law violations since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Gorbachev `Reasonable Man'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 6 grafs; inserts byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today called Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``a reasonable man'' and said he was not troubled that Gorbachev has had his powers strengthened by the Soviet Parliament. ``They've come out of the totalitarianism of the past. I don't see it as a threat,'' Bush said. He said there was ``much less of a danger today'' from the Kremlin. Bush made his comments at a question-and-answer session with the board of directors of the National Newspaper Association. The president was not asked about a fire that caused extensive damage at a Libyan plant the United States suspects of making chemical weapons. Referring to Gorbachev, Bush said, ``I think he's a reasonable man. I'm not worried about the constitutional changes.'' The Soviet Parliament voted Tuesday to expand Gorbachev's authority and end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power. Bush opened the session by saying the U.S. economy ``remains sound and steady'' but ``not as robust as I'd like to see it.'' Responding to questions, Bush noted a wave of recent speculation suggesting the release soon of some of the American hostages in Lebanon. ``That frankly confused me,'' Bush said, because the U.S. government is not involved in any negotiations. He said the speculation had prompted him to wonder whether a private initiative had been undertaken on behalf of the hostages. ``I wish I could tell you there was a serious, immediate effort that would pay off, but that isn't the case,'' the president said. He said he was glad that he had accepted what turned out to be a hoax telephone call from someone posing as Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. ``I would do it again,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Afgan Coup Leader Joins Forces With Fundamentalist Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: The Communist leader of an attempt to overthrow President Najib of Afganistan said he has joined forces with Moslem guerrillas to fight the Soviet-backed government. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai, Afghanistan's former defense minister, said that despite past differences, he and the Moslem guerrillas share a common goal to overthrow the Najib government. As Najib's defense minister, Tanai was credited with successfully defending Jalalabad, which was attacked by U.S.-backed rebels when the Soviet Union withdrew its troops last year after a decade in Afghanistan. Tanai, 40, led a March 6 coup attempt in which 200 civilians died and 500 were injured. No military casualty figures have been released. ``The coup has not failed. It is continuing,'' Tanai told reporters Wednesday at a guerrilla base in northern Logar province. Tanai, wearing his Afghan military uniform, sat in a dimly lit, heavily guarded bunker dug into a mountainside. He talked for the first time about the coup attempt and his agreement with Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the leader of Hezb-i-Islami, or Party of Islam, guerrilla faction. ``For the national interest, there is a strategic cooperation with Gulbuddin Hekmatyar to remove Najib,'' Tanai said. Hekmatyar advocates an Islamic state in Afghanistan. Tanai said he instructed his soldiers to cooperate with Hekmatyar. He said ``a large number of soldiers'' remain loyal to him and that he is mobilizing and re-establishing contacts with them. When asked whether the number was tens, hundreds or thousands, he replied, ``More than that.'' ``With the help of the mujahedeen, the struggle against the regime is continuing,'' Tanai said. ``Najib is a warmonger. He claims he wants peace and national reconcilation, but he continues to burn the nation in the flames of war.'' During the almost 12-year-old civil war, Tanai took a hard line against the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, and had opposed Najib's overtures to guerrilla commanders. ``We accept the mistakes of the past and our coming here proves that,'' Tanai said. ``We have sided with the nation and our actions should make up for these mistakes.'' Hekmatyar has said he would support anyone who tried to overthrow Najib, including Tanai. But the six other parties in the guerrillas' Pakistan-based government-in-exile have sought to distance themselves from Tanai. Some moderate resistance leaders, however, have said the Tanai-Hekmatyar connection broke a barrier blocking a political solution to the war, which has claimed 1.5 million lives and destroyed tens of thousands of villages. ``Gulbuddin has removed the stigma, the obstacle of talking to the (ruling) People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan,'' said a member of the moderate National Islamic Front of Afghanistan. ``Maybe it's time for the rest of us to start talking to them _ not Najib _ but to other members of the party.'' Tanai was brought to a Hezb-i-Islami base about 50 miles from Kabul in a truck guarded by Hekmatyar's guerrillas. While he talked, dozens of fighters stood guard around the camp and on the hills that ring the base.

DOC.HEAD: INS Agents Detain More Aliens on Eastern Flight
DOC.TEXT: A raid on a jetliner Thursday netted 53 illegal aliens, including three Romanians, bringing to 98 the number of undocumented aliens seized from the transcontinental route in two days, authorities said. Those detained when Eastern Airlines Flight 88 made a scheduled stop in Atlanta also were from Mexico, Guatemala and Nicaragua. They were interviewed and photographed, and then fingerprinted, said officials conducting the raids known as ``Operation Red-Eye Replay.'' The overnight flight, from Los Angeles to New York is known as the ``red-eye.'' Its lower fares are attractive to illegal aliens. The undocumented aliens purchased their tickets in advance and apparently did not know of the previous day's arrests, said Neil Jacobs, the deputy agent in charge of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Atlanta district. The smugglers who booked the flight were paid in advance and probably didn't care if the aliens were caught, he said. ``(The smugglers) are dealing in human beings,'' said Thomas Fischer, agent in charge of the Atlanta INS office. ``They could care less about what happens to these people today.'' Agents checked manifests on Eastern Flight 88 for Friday and the weekend, but there was no indication of a large number of Latin Americans booked for those days, Jacobs said. Thursday was at least the fourth time an Eastern flight from Los Angeles was raided by INS agents _ three times during stops in Atlanta and once in Los Angeles as the aliens were preparing to board. The earlier two incidents occurred a year ago. Fischer said the Romanians on Thursday's flight went from Bucharest to East Berlin to Havana to Mexico City, where they worked their way to the U.S. border. Agents said it was not clear whether any of them would have a claim to refugee status that would allow them to remain in the United States. Refugee status generally is not given to those who flee their homelands only to improve their economic situation. Most of those detained Wednesday and Thursday were Mexicans who will be taken to detention camps in Texas and processed for return to Mexico. Those from other countries will go to the Krome Detention Center near Miami for eventual return to their countries.

DOC.HEAD: President Announces Salary Cuts
DOC.TEXT: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's government announced salary and benefit cuts targeting middle-level and senior government officials Thursday in a bid to appease critics and avoid bankruptcy. ``These measures have caused us much pain ... We cry with you in these sad and hard times,'' the president said in a televised address.``But if we do not take these measures, in four or five months ... we will not be able to pay salaries.'' Houphouet-Boigny said farmers already had to accept in October a ``brutal cut'' in government payments for their crops. In February demonstrations led by university students, protesters said the poor bore a heavier burden in the country's financial crisis. Houphouet-Boigny has blamed the problems on slumping prices of raw materials. Dozens were injured and arrested in the protests, which police repressed with tear gas and truncheons. Finance Minister Moise Koumoue Koffi said workers earning less than the equivalent of $350 a month would not be affected by the salary cuts. He announced cuts of 8 percent for government workers earning more than $350, 14 percent for those earning more than $700, and 17 percent for those earning more than $1,754. Cabinet ministers and presidents of state-owned companies would have their salaries and fringe benefits cut by 40 percent, and legislators by 25 percent, he said. Private sector workers would pay a ``solidarity tax'' of 5 percent to 10 percent, except those earning less than $350, Koffi said. The loss of income would be compensated by cuts in the cost of living, he said, including reductions in state-controlled prices of staple foods, fuel, electricity and housing. He said the government would also collect overdue debts, ``pitilessly combat'' fraud, and cut costs of import and custom duties. The duties are some of the highest in the world. ``The situation of private companies and banks is cause for grave concern,'' Koffi said. ``We need to work quickly to reassert confidence or the system of payment will be paralyzed and the country will be confronted with mass bankruptcy and increased unemployment.'' Corruption and extravagance in the government have exacerbated the country's economic crisis, Western economists and diplomats say. Protesters demanding the president's downfall accused him of contributing to the financial crisis by siphoning money from state coffers. ``We were surprised that a problem that was essentially economic and social has been politicized, casting doubt on those in charge, suggesting that for 30 years we have done nothing,'' said Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: She Says She Shaped History, Got Reagan to Warm Up to Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Astrologer Joan Quigley said Thursday that the star-gazing advice she gave Nancy Reagan during Ronald Reagan's presidency influenced the course of history in big ways and small, even steering the president away from his ``Evil Empire'' view of the Soviet Union. In a book giving her version of her eight-year relationship with the Reagans _ first disclosed in 1988 by fired Reagan adviser Donald Regan _ Ms. Quigley asserted that she set the times some presidential events would occur down to the minute and sometimes even to the second. When Reagan announced his selection of Anthony Kennedy for a seat on the Supreme Court on Nov. 11, 1987, she chose 25 seconds after 11:32 a.m. EST as the moment for the announcement. ``A man with a stopwatch'' gave Reagan the signal for proceeding, she wrote. She said she also delayed the timing of Reagan's first cancer operation in 1985 by three days and dictated when Mrs. Reagan's mastectomy would take place. Ms. Quigley says Reagan knew of her influence on his wife and gave her a thank-you kiss when he finally met her. Mrs. Reagan, in her memoirs, ``My Turn,'' wrote last year that while Ms. Quigley was ``helpful and comforting ... a kind of therapist,'' she had influence solely on Reagan's schedule. ``No political decision was ever made based on it,'' she said. However, Ms. Quigley said that before Reagan's first summit with Mikhail Gorbachev, she worked three hours to persuade Mrs. Reagan that her husband could trust the Soviet leader. She said she ``battled her to the mat'' to get Reagan's view of Gorbachev changed. ``The placement of his ruler, Mercury, in the 10th house of power and position convinces me that Gorbachev came to power ... because of his high degree of intelligence,'' she said she told the first lady. ``It symbolizes to me that despite his Russian training and origins, he has the instincts of a humanitarian.'' Finally, the president's wife replied, ``I know you are right,'' she said. ``Through Nancy, I had a direct line to the president,'' Ms. Quigley wrote. ``I was responsible for timing all press conferences, most speeches, the State of the Union addresses, the takeoffs and landings of Air Force One. I picked the time of Ronald Reagan's debate with (Jimmy) Carter and the two debates with Walter Mondale; all extended trips abroad as well as the shorter trips and one-day excursions, the announcement that Reagan would run for a second term, briefings for all the summits except Moscow, although I selected the time to begin the Moscow trip. ``I timed congressional arm-twisting, the second inaugural oath of office, the announcement of Anthony Kennedy's Supreme Court nomination.'' Ms. Quigley said her most tedious work was analyzing Reagan's horoscope ``on an hour by hour basis.'' Birch Lane Press said Thursday's publication date for Ms. Quigley's book _ ``What Does Joan Say?'' _ was selected by the astrologer. Vassar-educated and a San Francisco socialite, Ms. Quigley is the author of three books on astrology. Her form of astrology goes beyond sun signs and deals with the moon and all eight planets as well, according to her publisher. Ms. Quigley wrote that she did not intend to write a book, even after Regan disclosed her role when he wrote his memoirs as White House chief of staff. But she reconsidered, she said, when Mrs. Reagan's book came out last year. ``It reads like fiction and much of it is evasive,'' she wrote of Mrs. Reagan's account. ``What she has left out would fill a book.'' At the time Regan told of Mrs. Reagan's use of an astrologer, Reagan spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president had emphasized ``that he made no policy decisions based on astrology.'' Ms. Quigley's account differs. She wrote that Reagan asked his wife to ask her about going to Reykjavik, Iceland, for his second summit with Gorbachev. Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz ``followed my advice to negotiate there as long and as hard as possible, and following my advice they stayed later than planned.'' ``Ronnie asked Nancy, `What does Joan say?' when he wanted to know when the Irangate ordeal would be over,'' she wrote. ``And he phoned to thank me personally for a letter written at the end of Irangate, in which I described myself as his astrologer, addresing him as `Dear Ronnie' and signing it `Joan.''' Ms. Quigley was discreet about how much she had been paid for her efforts _ just as Mrs. Reagan was. The astrologer said she orginally was paid by the hour for time spent on the phone with Mrs. Reagan and time spent in preparation. She said when she raised her fee for other clients she kept Mrs. Reagan's at the old level. Finally, she charged Mrs. Reagan a fixed monthly fee ``because she needed much more of my time than she could afford. This was very generous on my part.''

DOC.HEAD: Rural Development Bill Stalled In House
DOC.TEXT: A fight over federal water and sewer money ended Thursday in the House with a vote that gutted a massive rural development bill and forced sponsors to stop floor action until they find a new strategy. Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, said many of the members didn't understand the killer amendment they approved because of inaccuracies he said were stated during debate. ``We can regroup,'' said de la Garza, D-Texas. He said the legislation's supporters would take some time to speak to their colleagues before continuing with floor action on the bill. After an hour of arguing, the members voted 204-193 on an amendment by Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., that killed a provision allowing about $500 million to $600 million in existing federal funds for water and sewer projects to be used for other local needs. The amendment also froze about $100 million appropriated for business and industry development and another $100 million for community facilities. The funds amount to the only significant money in the legislation which creates very little new spending. The idea was to pool the funds so that individual communities could decide for themselves where to apply federal money. ``If the amendment stays, it preserves the status quo,'' said de la Garza. ``Under the present system there has been a tremendous inequity,'' said Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., who authored the bill with Rep. Tom Coleman, R-Mo. He said that if a state doesn't use all of its share of water and sewer money, for example, the funds go back to the federal government and become available to any other states that apply for it. He said the aggressiveness of the local Farmers Home Administration directors has had a lot to do with how much of the money a state gets. ``There are some FmHA directors who philosophically don't like these programs so they spend very little of it (the available money),'' English said after the vote. Rose said the bill would give too much power to the agriculture secretary to decide where funds should be used. Under the legislation, state review panels would set priorities on projects, but the Agriculture Department would have the final say on use of the money. Rose said if his amendment were not adopted, the secretary would have ``unprecedent, uncontrollable authority to transfer money without input from Congress.'' But Rep. Jerry Huckaby, D-La., said ``the bottom line is that if we adopt the Rose amendment we really don't have much of a bill here. It makes sense to let the state determine how to use these limited resources.'' De la Garza said time has been set aside next week for further action on the bill but did not say whether sponsors would try again that soon or take more time to try to persuade members to change their opinions. The bill is designed to help decaying rural communities diversify away from farming as their main source of income. It is significantly different from a bill on rural development already passed by the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Denktash Resigns to Clear Way for Elections and New Mandate
DOC.TEXT: The president of the breakaway Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus resigned Thursday to clear the way for early elections that he said will be a referendum on the divided island's future. Presidential elections will be held April 22 and parliamentary elections May 6. Rauf Denktash resigned as president and later told a news conference that the presidential election would be a vote of confidence for his policies on Cyprus reunification talks. He said he would not run as a candidate of a specific party. Denktash complained that some Turkish Cypriot politicians had accused him of being too uncompromising in the Cyprus talks. ``In the talks (Cypriot President George) Vassilou keeps showing me copies of such statements,'' Denktash said. ``I could not carry such a responsibility in the midst of fluctuations like this. We must ask the people.'' In Ankara, the Turkish capital, Mehmet Yazar, state minister and government spokesman, praised Denktash and said support for him would continue. The latest round of U.N.-sponsored Cyprus talks collapsed earlier this month over Turkish Cypriot demands for self-determination on the eastern Mediterranean island. Cyprus has been split into northern Turkish and southern Greek sectors since Turkey's invasion in 1974 after an Athens-engineered coup. The Turkish Cypriots proclaimed full independence in 1983 but only Turkey recognizes the state.

DOC.HEAD: Parties Begin Final Campaign Push for Sunday's Elections
DOC.TEXT: Political parties began their final campaign push Thursday and Communist Premier Hans Modrow's caretaker government urged East Germans to avoid rushing into reunification with West Germany. The campaign for Sunday's parliamentary elections has been shaken by the resignation of a top conservative candidate who admitted he had worked for the now virtually disbanded secret police. As rumors swirled that other candidates may also have worked for the once all-powerful force, the leftist Social Democrats denied they had informants in their top ranks. Candidates for the 24 slates put forward by various parties were crisscrossing the country and holding rallies ahead of the nation's first free elections. Meanwhile, an opinion poll released by the government in Bonn showed that 90 precent of West Germans surveyed favor unification; the figure was 95 percent for East Germans. The poll was taken early this month by the respected Infratest organization for the West German Ministry for Inner-German Relations. According to the poll, 51 percent of the 1,030 East Germans questioned said they wanted unification ``soon.'' Of the 1,010 West Germans asked the same question, the figure was 40 percent, according to the poll. No margin of error for the poll was given. An estimated 12.3 million East Germans are eligible to take part in the balloting for the new 400-member Parliament. Wolfgang Schnur, leader of the Democratic Awakening party, had been one of the top candidates for Sunday's voting. But he quit Wednesday after admitting he had worked for the secret police. A citizens group investigating Schnur's case has secured file folders containing information he gave to officials, the state news agency ADN said Thursday. Schnur was expelled from the conservative party he headed and helped found. Party leaders named Rainer Eppelmann, an East Berlin pastor and Cabinet minister in Modrow's caretaker government, as acting successor. Eppelmann, 47, faces the challenge of keeping together the conservative Alliance for Germany, a coalition of three parties that Schnur helped build for Sunday's elections. The alliance has received enormous support from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The Social Democrats, another leading contender in the elections, denied rumors that one-time informers were in its top ranks as well. Party leaders, at a news conference in East Berlin, displayed documents they claimed proved there were no ties to the hated secret police. In East Berlin, the caretaker Cabinet held its last meeting before the elections. ``Overall, the government has been able to lead the German Democratic Republic onto the way out of its crisis,'' government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer told a news conference later. ``To some extent, people have become aware of avoiding a head-over-heels rush to unification.'' Modrow's government, which took office in November after the ouster of hard-line Communist Erich Honecker, also includes eight ministers from various pro-democracy organizations. Together they have been asking East Germans to slow the pace of reunification, arguing that there are still positive elements of the socialist system. Meyer said there was a ``light upward trend'' in the nation's economy, which weeks ago had reportedly been on the brink of collapse. East Germany has been shaken by the exodus of nearly 500,000 people, many of them young, skilled workers, since last year. West German officials are making plans to try to halt the influx by shutting down reception centers for the East Germans after the elections. The Bonn government says a democratic government in East Berlin and eventual unification should make such emigration unnecessary. But it also has acknowledged reunification could take several years to complete.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Busted the Speaker, Now Bucks the Machine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story listed as AM-Phelan on AM-News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: The attorney who helped bring down former House Speaker Jim Wright is involved in a heated battle of his own _ the race for president of the Cook County Board. Heading into Tuesday's primary, newspaper polls put Democrat Richard J. Phelan at even or slightly ahead of one of his three opponents, but well ahead of the Democrats' slated candidate. The son of a Chicago precinct captain, Phelan has been a behind-the-scenes player in local Democratic politics for years, serving as a fund-raiser in U.S. Sen. Paul Simon's 1984 campaign. Twice in the last year, however, Phelan has taken a public role. As in the Wright case, he has made ethics the battleground as he seeks the county board presidency, a post the party has long used to control thousands of patronage jobs. Wright, who resigned from Congress last year in the face of Phelan's investigation, ``wasn't part of my party'' because of the Texas Democrat's actions in skirting a congressional limit on speaking fees, Phelan said. Portrayed as an impartial outsider when retained by the House Ethics Committee, Phelan is using the same tack against the Cook County Democratic organization. ``When I say I'm an outsider I mean I'm outside the machine politics,'' Phelan said in a telephone interview. People supporting his campaign want ``to see an end to politics as usual'' in the president's office, run by the party, he said. When Cook County Board President George W. Dunne announced he would retire after 21 years, it set off a four-way race whose pitch has sharpened as each candidate has tried to stake the other to the ethical low ground. The other candidates are: _ R. Eugene Pincham, 64, a former Illinois Appellate Court justice trying to become the first black to hold the county president post. Recent polls by Chicago's two largest daily papers show Pincham and Phelan as leaders of the pack. _ Cook County Clerk Stanley T. Kusper, 55, a veteran of Chicago politics who was hand-picked for his current post by the late Mayor Richard J. Daley in 1973. _ State Sen. Ted Lechowicz, 51, like Kusper a bastion of machine politics, and the party's slated candidate. Trailing his rivals in polls by the Chicago Tribune and the Chicago Sun-Times, Lechowicz is counting on loyal precinct captains to get out the vote. Dunne has not been a factor in the race and Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley has refused to publicly back a candidate. A wide-open race for the post is another obituary for the machine the elder Daley controlled, said political analyst Paul Green, director of the Institute of Public Affairs at Governor's State University in south surburban University Park. The Democratic party no longer has a consolidated hold on power so the race is a battle, ``because there's no organization to prevent the fight from taking place,'' Green said. ``Ambition is no longer limited by party approval.'' Phelan, 52, worried party leaders last summer when he considered entering the primary for governor. He backed off, but jumped into the board president's race after Dunne's announcement. A partner in one of the city's fastest-growing law firms, he has given or lent more to his campaign _ close to $900,000 _ than any of the other candidates have raised, according to campaign finance records. A $1 million television campaign has put his face before TV viewers an average of three times a week.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Recent U.S.-Libyan Relations
With AM-Libya-Plant, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some highlights of recent U.S.-Libyan relations: Aug. 19, 1981 _ In an armed confrontation, U.S. F-14 fighters shoot down two Soviet built fighter planes over the Mediterranean in a one-minute battle off the Libyan coast. No Americans hurt, one Libyan pilot seen parachuting from his stricken plane. Jan. 7, 1986 _ President Reagan announces economic sanctions against Libya, freezing Libyan assets in the United States and forbidding certain dealings with Libya including oil production by U.S. companies there. March 24-25, 1986 _ U.S. planes hit Libyan ships, rocket base in the Sidra area. April 5, 1986 _ Bomb at West Berlin disco kills two, injures 200. The United States accuses Libya of the attack on the club frequented by U.S. soldiers. April 15, 1986 _ The United States planes bomb Tripoli and Benghazi, Libya's two main cities, in retaliation for what it calls Libyan support of international terrorism. Sept. 14, 1988 _ The State Department announces Libya can now produce chemical weapons and calls it a ``particularly worrisome development.'' Oct. 4, 1988 _ In a speech at the United Nations, the Libyan foreign minister demands compensation for the 1986 air attack. Oct. 25, 1988 _ CIA Director William Webster says the chemical plant in question is the largest of its kind the agency has detected. Nov. 15, 1988 _ A Libyan official tells Italy his country adheres to international prohibitions on the use of chemical weapons. Dec. 21, 1988 _ Reagan says the United States had discussed military action against the chemical weapons plant with allies and ``that's a decision that has not been made yet.'' Dec. 22, 1988 _ Libya denies it has built a chemical weapons plant and insists the factory for production of medicine. Dec. 28, 1988 _ Reagan extends for six months U.S. economic sanctions against Libya, first imposed in 1986. Jan 4, 1989 _ The Pentagon announces the shooting down of two Libyan fighters by U.S. planes. Jan. 4, 1990 _ President Bush extends economic sanctions, saying Libya ``continues to use and support international terrorism.'' March 7, 1990 _ The United States accuses Libya of manufacturing chemical weapons at the plant at Rabta. Asked if the United States might take military action to knock out the plant, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater replied, ``We don't rule out anything.''

DOC.HEAD: March Storm Buffets The Upper Midwest With Snow, High Wind
DOC.TEXT: More record high temperatures were reported Thursday across much of the East, and low pressure crossing the upper Mississippi Valley produced high wind from the northern and central Plains to the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes. The storm also produced unexpected snow across parts of Iowa and Minnesota. Wind in western South Dakota reached 75 mph at Rapid City during the morning, with gusts to 100 mph. Gillette, Wyo., reported wind gusts as high as 60 mph. Other high wind gusts included: 67 mph at La Crosse, Wis.; 65 to 70 mph at Macomb, Ill.; 64 mph at Dubuque, Iowa; 60 mph at Janesville, Wis.; 58 mph at Ottumwa, Iowa; 55 mph at Moline, Ill., and Green Bay, Wis.; 54 mph at Cedar Rapids, Iowa; and 52 mph at Chicago's Midway Airport. Snow accompanied the high wind in some areas of the northern Plains region and the upper Mississippi Valley. Five inches of snow fell at Omaha, Neb., during the night, and as much as 9 inches fell at Worthington in southwestern Minnesota. Western Iowa also got heavy, wet snow. A winter storm warning was issued for eastern and north-central North Dakota, where wind blowing at 30 to 40 mph and 4 to 8 inches of snow was expected to produce near-blizzard conditions. Snow and gusty winds also lingered in the northern mountains of Colorado, with up to 6 inches of snow possible by Friday morning. Rain associated with a cold front crossing the Mississippi Valley extended from the central Gulf Coast to Indiana and Illinois during the afternoon, with showers and thunderstorms over the central Gulf Coast states. Biloxi, Miss., got 4.3 inches of rain between 6 a.m. and noon and Meridian, Miss., got 1.1 inches. Flash flood watches have been posted into Friday for much of northern and western Alabama, and for central Tennessee and parts of eastern Tennessee. Unseasonably warm weather continued ahead of the cold front crossing the Mississippi Valley and high temperature records were posted in 38 cities. Temperatures were near 80 as far north as northwestern Pennsylvania, and were above 70 as north as southern New England. For some cities it was the fourth day in a row of record warmth. A reading of 78 at Akron, Ohio, was the warmest on record for so early in the season. Showers developing north of a warm front spread over Maine during the afternoon. Showers alwso were scattered from South Carolina to northeastern Florida. The low this morning of 63 degrees at columbus oh was the warmest of record for the month of march. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 above zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's First Task as President: Lithuania
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Congress on Thursday gave Mikhail S. Gorbachev his first presidential mission: deal personally with the defiant leaders in Lithuania who have declared the Baltic republic independent. Hours after watching Gorbachev take the presidential oath, the Congress of People's Deputies passed a resolution charging him with ``assuring the defense of the legal rights of every person living on Lithuanian territory,'' as well as defending Soviet interests there. Gorbachev himself, saying independence-minded republics were ``on the edge of a process that must be stopped,'' prompted the Congress to pass the measure after editing out sections that cast more blame on the Lithuanians. Lithuania, a republic of 3.7 million residents, declared itself independent from the Soviet Union on Sunday. Gorbachev said this week that the move was ``illegal and invalid,'' and the Congress' resolution Thursday echoed his rejection and pronounced the Soviet Constitution still valid there. Gorbachev told a press conference after the session ended Thursday night that he expected to hold ``a dialogue, a respectful dialogue, with the people of Lithuania'' and their government. He emphasized he would not consider the talks actual diplomatic ``negotiations'' between separate countries. Lithuanian deputies had largely backed Gorbachev's candidacy because they expected him to be a reasonable partner in such talks. But they did not participate in the vote. The Congress passed the Lithuania resolution with a 1,463-94 vote after almost three hours of often polemical speeches. Condemnation of the rebellious republic far outweighed support. Nearly 700 deputies did not vote, although many of those had left the late-evening session. Adm. Vitaly Ivanov, commander of the Soviet Baltic Fleet, accused Lithuanian leaders of ``betrayal of their own people and the people of the Soviet Union,'' and called the declaration of independence ``a stab in the back'' of the country. Yevgeny Kogan, a proponent for non-Estonians' rights in the Baltic republic of Estonia, called for Gorbachev to immediately impose direct presidential rule in the three Baltic republics, which include Latvia, to stop what he called a ``campaign of psychological terror'' against Russians and other minorities. His proposal was met with some applause from the hall, but Gorbachev ignored the suggestion. Most of the Lithuanian deputies who could have defended the republic's move were absent, either busy with a legislature session at home or unwilling to serve in the parliament of what they now consider a foreign country. The one Lithuanian who took the floor, Nikolai Medvedev, was met with scattered cries of ``Enemy of the People!'' when he spoke. The epithet was widespread during the witch-hunting days of dictator Josef Stalin. Medvedev accused Bolshevism of causing hundreds of thousands of deaths in Lithuania in Stalin's repressions and mass deportations. He warned that the original, more harshly worded draft of the resolution would only make the situation in the republic worse. Rafik Nishanov, chairman of one of the chambers of the Soviet legislature, said hundreds of telegrams had been pouring into the Congress with complaints about the hasty decision by the Lithuanian parliament. Army Lt. Col. Nikolai Petrushenko complained that wholesale draft-dodging had begun in Lithuania, and warned that Soviet troops might be sent to round up the recalcitrant conscripts ``in their farms and villages.'' According to reports from Lithuania, thousands of youths have handed in their draft cards and will refuse this spring's call-up. The Lithuanian parliament this week passed a measure removing penalties for draft-dodgers. For all their objections to Lithuania's declaration, none of the speakers proposed using force to solve the dilemma.
