DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Submitted to FBI Interview, Almost All Computer Files Destroyed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with FBI agent's testimony
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter told the FBI three days after resigning his White House post that he had ``no working knowledge'' of early Iran arms shipments and ``no direct knowledge'' profits had been diverted to the Nicaraguan Contras, an FBI agent testified at his trial Thursday. Agent Ellen Glasser also testified that more than 5,000 files were erased from Poindexter's computer system just before the national security adviser resigned as the Iran-Contra affair was coming to light. Six months after the Nov. 28, 1986, FBI interview at his home, Poindexter told Congress _ in testimony that cannot be used at his trial _ that he approved the diversion to the Contras at North's request and had been involved in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Glasser, in her testimony, spoke of a ``massive destruction'' of computer messages and provided details of the heretofore undisclosed Poindexter interview that she and another FBI agent conducted. She said that during that interview Poindexter was asked whether he knew of any destruction of documents pertinent to the investigation of the Iran-Contra affair. He ``replied that he did not,'' the agent recalled. Concerning the diversion to the Contras, Glasser testified that Poindexter said he knew ``Ollie North ... was up to something.'' She said she showed Poindexter copies of chronologies on the Iran initiative. The final version compiled by Robert McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor as then-President Reagan's national security adviser, and aide Oliver North concealed the U.S. role in the missile shipment. Asked whether the documents were accurate, Poindexter ``replied that they were,'' Glasser said. North was convicted last year of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in connection with the chronologies. Poindexter is accused of concealing from Congress the U.S. role in the missile shipment as well as the North-directed military assistance to the Contras at a time official U.S. aid was banned. Part of the indictment accuses him of purging his computer files between Nov. 22 and Nov. 29, 1986, in an attempt to conceal information from Congress. On Nov. 22, there were over 5,000 computer messages in Poindexter's terminal, but at 9 a.m. on Nov. 24 ``there were zero,'' Glasser testified. ``This massive deletion ... occurred in November 1986,'' she said under cross-examination by Poindexter lawyer Richard Beckler, who suggested the files could have been deleted at some other time. Poindexter was logged onto the computer system for a 15-hour span Nov. 24, starting at 4:30 a.m., testified Kelly Williams, who was in charge of the computer software section at the White House Communications Agency. That was the day before Poindexter resigned. Williams said Poindexter's identification code was the one used to gain access to the computer when the files were deleted. Prosecutor Louise Radin asked if deleting the files would be comparable to ``taking a manila envelope and just throwing it away?'' ``Yes, that would be the effect,'' Williams replied. A total of 732 notes were deleted from North's own computer files about the same time Poindexter's system was cleared out, Williams said. Only one of North's computer files remained. Copies of Poindexter's and North's files were recovered from backup tapes at the NSC's computer system and have been instrumental in tracing the Iran-Contra affair. Earlier in the day, prosecutor Dan Webb said he could complete his case against Poindexter as early as Monday because North's four days of testimony ``cut off two or three weeks'' from the prosecution's work. Webb said North's testimony, which ended Wednesday, went well and that the government got ``a lot'' out of the former White House aide. North testified that Poindexter told him he could ``take care of'' an upcoming meeting with members of Congress. North lied at the meeting by denying he was assisting the Nicaraguan rebels. North also testified that he saw Poindexter tear up a politically embarrassing presidential document. The document, called a finding, retroactively authorized the shipment of missiles to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Body Processes, Not Contamination, May Cause L-Tryptophan-Linked Illness
DOC.TEXT: Natural chemical processes in the body _ not contamination _ may be behind hundreds of cases of a rare, painful blood disorder in people who took the health-food supplement L-tryptophan, researchers say. The substance, sold as a natural relaxation aid, has been recalled voluntarily by several makers at the urging of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which suspected contamination. Fourteen people who took L-tryptophan have died in recent months and more than 1,200 others have fallen ill with eosinophilia-myalgia, a rare blood disroder which in milder cases causes aches, rashes and fever. The new study was conducted at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., and reported in Friday's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``Arguing against the contamination theory is that in spite of the fact that people have been searching (for the contaminant), it hasn't been identified,'' said one of the researchers, Dr. Paul Katz, chief rheumatologist at Georgetown. ``Also, the L-tryptophan implicated has been traced to three different manufacturers,'' Katz said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``That argues a little bit against there being a common-source contaminant.'' Chris Lecos, an FDA spokesman, said the research didn't change the agency's advice against taking L-tryptophan. ``It doesn't serve the public to come forth with speculation. What we're looking for is a clear-cut explanation,'' Lacos said. But he acknowledged in a telephone interview from Washington on Thursday, ``We've analyzed hundreds of samples (of L-tryptophan), including from victims themselves, and have failed to identify a specific chemical or microbial contaminant responsible for the outbreak.'' Lecos added, ``This is not a disease that should be taken lightly by anyone. People should stop taking this stuff.'' Katz and his colleagues at Georgetown believe L-tryptophan supplements under certain conditions may contribute to a build-up of a naturally occurring substance in the body called serotonin. Serotonin is a byproduct of the breakdown of L-tryptophan, which is an amino acid, or protein component, that occurs naturally in many foods but is usually present in greater concentrations in the dietary supplement. Some researchers believe abnormal levels of serotonin may contribute to syndromes similar to eosinophilia-myalgia, Katz said. L-tryptophan supplements have been sold over the counter for years to combat sleeplessness, depression, premenstrual syndrome, stress and other problems. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome _ which is caused by an excess of a certain type of white blood cell _ have been noted in people taking L-tryptophan supplements only in the last year or so. The disorder may have occurred earlier and been diagnosed as different but similar syndromes, Katz said. The researchers found seven patients at Georgetown who developed the rare blood disorder while taking L-tryptophan. All patients had the muscle pain and tenderness characteristic of the syndrome, and rashes, fever and breathing difficulty were common, the researchers said. Three of the patients had taken antidepressant medication, which inhibits the absorption of serotonin by nerve cells in the brain. Their use in conjunction with L-tryptophan probably resulted in an excess that the body was unable to chemically process, the authors suggest. In the other four cases, the patients' bodies for some reason may have been unable to metabolize L-tryptophan, Katz said. By mid-February, the national Centers for Disease Control had recorded 14 deaths and 1,269 cases of illness nationwide from eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome associated with ingestion of L-tryptophan supplements. The Food and Drug Administration on Nov. 17 requested a voluntary recall of L-tryptophan supplements and five days later extended that to include a ban on imports. Dr. Richard M. Silver, associate professor of medicine and pediatrics at the Medical University of South Carolina, who has studied L-tryptophan, said the Georgetown researchers ``may be on target.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Not Worried Gorby Will Be Another Dictator
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``a reasonable man'' Thursday and said he was not worried that the Soviet president would turn into a dictator as a result of new powers granted by his Parliament. ``They've come out of the totalitarianism of the past,'' Bush said, crediting Gorbachev with being a major force promoting peaceful changes in Eastern Europe. ``And I've consulted with him, had communications from him, for example, on the question of Germany,'' Bush said. ``And I think he's a reasonable man.'' The Soviet Parliament on Tuesday endorsed Gorbachev's proposal for a strong presidency and ended the Communist Party's long monopoly on political power. Before the final vote, Gorbachev granted several concessions that seemed to ease critics' fears that the new president might usher in a new era of Soviet dictatorship. Bush made his comments in a question and answer session with out-of-town news executives of the National Newspaper Association. The president used the occasion to express irritation with U.S. volunteers in Nicaragua who, he said, were intent on keeping the leftist Sandinista government in power. Without identifying anyone by name, Bush said, ``I am frustrated a little bit by some of the Americans that have gone down to Nicaragua, been there for two years allegedly to help the people of Nicaragua, and then Nicaragua has a free and fair election, and it turns out these people were interested in helping the Sandinistas, the Sandinismos. ``And now they're picketing ... in front of the U.S. Embassy because in their view the wrong people won the election.'' In a major upset, the U.S.-backed opposition candidate, Violeta Chamorro, defeated President Daniel Ortega in presidential elections Feb. 25. Dennis Marker, director of a church-based group known as Witness for Peace, said Bush apparently was talking about his organization, which is dedicated to changing U.S. policy in Central America. ``We have had U.S. citizens demonstrating in front of the embassy since 1983,'' Marker said. ``The reason people are demonstrating is not because of who won the election. We are demonstrating against continued U.S. interference in Nicaragua.'' With the election of Mrs. Chamorro, Marker said, ``The president's trying to say Nicaragua should be closed to views that are different from his own.'' On other subjects at his second news conference in three days, Bush said he: _Wishes the deficit were lower so that more funds would be available to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe and Latin America. _Opposes suggestions that U.S. aid be cut to Israel and Egypt to make money available for those democracies. ``I don't want to suggest cutting to good friends,'' Bush said, adding that he would like greater flexibility to disburse foreign aid. _Rejects the notion that America is in decline, saying, ``We still have the highest standard of living in the world. ... So I am not that pessimistic, and yet I don't want to stand here with some Pollyannnish attitude about the economy. There are some signs that worry me.'' _Is ``frankly confused'' by last week's speculation that an American hostage in Lebanon might be released because there are no negotiations going on involving the U.S. government. ``I wish I could tell you that there was a serious, immediate effort that would pay off, but that isn't the case.'' _Is ``very pleased with the way the Lithuanian situation is developing'' in the wake of its declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. ``We will encourage the fundamental principles of self-determination, and we will encourage the concept of peaceful change.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Chemical Plant Knocked Out, Denies Involvement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``There was,'' with intelligence confirmation that the plant inoperable; INSERTS graf 21: ``Fitzwater's comments,'' to note the intelligence information becamse available after Fitzwater spoke
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Thursday that a Libyan plant suspected of making chemical weapons had been knocked out of commission by a serious fire. ``We don't have any idea who did it,'' President Bush's spokesman said. From Bush on down, the administration denied any involvement in Wednesday's blaze, which occurred one week after the White House said the plant posed a serious danger and called for ``vigorous efforts'' to stop its operation. ``We don't know the origins of the fire,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We don't know if it was sabotage. We don't have any idea who did it. ... Somebody could have knocked over a kerosene lamp or something.'' The plant, located at Rabta, about 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, was heavily guarded by surface-to-air missile batteries, tanks and soldiers. It has been a point of aggravation in the deep diplomatic split between Washington and Tripoli. CIA Director William Webster once described it as the world's largest chemical weapons factory. There was some uncertainty during the day about the extent of damage to the plant. But in the early evening, a senior U.S. official said the United States had used its ``intelligence resources'' to be able to conclude that the plant was inoperable. U.S. ``intelligence resources'' are known to include satellites capable of high-resolution photography. Asked if the United States was pleased the plant had burned, Fitzwater said, ``We aren't going to express an opinion one way or another. For one thing, we don't know what the results are. We don't know what's happened there.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said CIA Director William Webster, in testimony to Congress a year ago, had reported that ``one serious toxic chemical spill had already taken place (at Rabta) and that such problems were likely to continue.'' Ms. Tutwiler added, ``We have had various other reports of accidents at the plant before the current fire.'' She said the plant appears to be out of operation now. ``However we remain concerned about Libya's chemical weapons plans and capabilities.'' She quoted the Libyan news agency JANA as reporting that at least two people had been killed. ``We cannot confirm the extent of casualties,'' she said. Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, asserted anew Thursday that the plant merely produced pharmaceuticals. However, Gadhafi said Libya would be willing to pay millions of dollars to any company that would build it a chemical weapons facility. Bush was asked at a pre-St. Patrick's Day party thrown by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley what information he had on the fire. ``Not much,'' Bush said. Asked by a reporter if the United States had been involved, Bush said, ``No, but we've already said that.'' Without revealing the source of his information, Fitzwater said damage at the sprawling plant was extensive but that it was still standing. ``Common sense would tell you it's not functioning,'' he said. ``We assume it's not functioning.'' On the other hand, he said, ``We don't have the kind of definitive information that would define the damage. ... The building is there but is it all burned out inside? We don't really know.'' Fitzwater's comments were made before the use of ``intelligence resources' referred to by the senior official became known. Ms. Tutwiler reiterated the longstanding U.S. accusation that Libya promotes terrorism and is harboring Abu Nidal, a suspect in several terrorist incidents. Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, D-N.Y., told reporters at the White House, ``It's the first fire I've heard about in a long time that I'm pleased with. I only hope it all burned down.'' He commented after meeting with Bush about South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Little Rock Case Prompts Infant Formula Warning
DOC.TEXT: Babies should not be given soy-based beverages other than infant formulas as their only source of nutrition, the Food and Drug Administration warned on Thursday. The FDA said the soy-based drinks, sometimes called ``soy milk,'' do not have the nutrients needed for infants. A 5-month-old baby girl, whose parents bought the product in a health food store, was in critical condition at Arkansas Children's Hospital in Little Rock because of malnourishment, the agency said in a statement. It did not identify the girl or her parents. The parents, according to the statement, erroneously believed that a soy beverage sold in a health food store could be used as infant formula, and had fed it to their daughter almost since birth. Soy beverages analyzed by the Little Rock hospital were found to be lacking in calcium, niacin and vitamins D, E and C, the agency said. The FDA said children and adults can drink the soy beverages as long as they are part of an otherwise balanced diet. There are soy-based infant formulas that are ``complete and appropriate,'' and these formulas are not involved in Thursday's warning, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Granted New Presidency, Warns of Hard Times Ahead
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with news conference quotes, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS11; LaserColor MOS10
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, granted a new, more powerful presidency on Thursday, said his immediate tasks were to prevent the Soviet Union from breaking up and to promote free-market reforms. In assuming powers as the Soviet Union's first Western-style president, Gorbachev warned in a speech at the Congress of People's Deputies that the reforms required to right his country's woeful economy would be painful. Mindful of his nation's history of dictatorship and terror, Gorbachev promised legislators he would nurture the Soviet Union's ``young and not fully developed democracy.'' Gorbachev, who ran into surprisingly strong opposition in the Soviet Congress before assuming the new presidency, will now have wide powers to propose legislation, negotiate treaties, veto bills, appoint the Council of Ministers and void its decisions. Significantly, he also has the power to declare war if the country is attacked and under certain conditions impose direct presidential rule. This means he could overrule a local government. He has shifted his formidable powers further from the Communist Party leadership to the government. On Wednesday, the Congress struck the party's constitutional monopoly on power to permit development of a multiparty system. Gorbachev mentioned specifically the need to overcome the irresponsibility that was a byproduct of collective leadership, saying, ``An increase of responsibility is the main thing on which we rely.'' He said in his speech at Congress, ``Our country is living through difficult times. But if we act together we will overcome the difficulties. We must shake off fears and dejection, gain a confidence in our strength and possibilities, which are truly great. The Russian people and all peoples united with it in a great multinational state will succeed in reviving their common homeland, and will surely achieve that on the roads of perestroika and socialist renewal.'' He added, ``I see my role and task as the president of the U.S.S.R. in affirming national harmony in the country and a spirit of mutual respect, consolidating the principles of civil peace and harmony, protecting the interests of the people.'' Voting results announced Thursday at the Congress indicated a significant drop in support for the Soviet leader since he was chosen chairman of the Soviet legislature in May. That position was essentially a weak presidency. Congress elected Gorbachev to a five-year term by a vote of 1,329-495. He was the only candidate. His total was 800 votes less than what he received one year ago, and not much more than the 1,123 needed to win. In a separate ballot, the Congress chose Gorbachev's former vice president, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, as chairman. The Congress chairman holds many of the responsibilities of vice president, including the right of succession if the president cannot continue in office. Yegor K. Ligachev, characterized by reformers as a conservative power on the Communist Party Politburo, praised Gorbachev's election as ``a truly positive development, especially at a time of party and social renewal, when both the party and society are undergoing transformation.'' One reform-minded deputy, Igor Shamshev, said Gorbachev had lost the support of extreme conservatives and radical reformers, but held the moderates. On Wednesday, several deputies called for Gorbachev's defeat. Teimuraz Avaliani of the western Siberian mining town of Kemerovo accused him of leading the country to the brink of collapse, and said, ``I ask you not to vote for Gorbachev under any circumstances.'' Yevgeny Kogan, a representatives of Russians living in the Baltic republic of Estonia, accused Gorbachev of being soft on separatists. Estonia is pressing for independence. ``What would you do if a state decided it was leaving, and the president didn't take any measures to stop it?'' he asked reporters. Despite the opposition, Gorbachev received a standing ovation in the Congress after results were announced. He stood with his hands folded before him at the dais inside the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. He then moved to a wooden table, and with his hand on a red-bound copy of the Soviet Constitution, took the first presidential oath of ffice. On Wednesday, Gorbachev won a key procedural vote in which the Congress agreed to elect the president in emergency session rather than turning it over to a nationwide campaign. In the future, the Soviet public should be able to elect the president. President Bush called Gorbachev ``a reasonable man'' and said he was not troubled that Gorbachev has had his powers strengthened. ``They've come out of the totalitarianism of the past. I don't see it as a threat,'' Bush said in Washington. Gorbachev closed the day by giving a news conference, his first in the Kremlin. Spokesmen said he would meet with the press more frequently as president. Some deputies from Lithuania, Estonia and other republics boycotted the Congress proceedings because they consider their republics independent rather than part of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev said he would work to keep the Soviet Union from breaking apart and would be the president for all of the more than 100 nationalities living in the country. ``The president must feel and act not as a representative of a certain layer of society or political leaning, but as a person trusted by the entire nation,'' he said. ``As president now, I reaffirm my adherence to the territorial integrity of this country,'' he added. Gorbachev said he intended to work to conclude a new agreement binding the Soviet republics together in federation. Soviet law should allow for republics to seceed if they wish, Gorbachev said, but he did not specify under what conditions. He promised more radical economic reform, and said some of the steps would hurt. ``The necessity for a more radical perestroika policy is obvious, and it is for these purposes above all that I am going to use my powers as president,'' he said. New reforms ``may, in the initial stages, be accompanied by painful phenomena and affect some people's interests,'' he said. Promising to to cut the Soviet budget drastically and attack inflation he otherwise offered few details except to say, `We urgently need to pass laws aimed at de-monopolizing the economy.'' Gorbachev said he would work to create a ``viable market'' economy, governed not by bureaucrats but by taxation, bank control of balance of payments and adjustable interest rates. Only months ago, Gorbachev believed that the Soviet Union did not need a presidential form of government, his close Politburo adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev told a Soviet newspaper this week. In December, he fought a drive in the Congress to strip the party of its constitutional right to rule. Two months later, however, Gorbachev persuaded the party to drop its monopoly on power. He told reporters he changed his positions because his reform program is changing the Soviet Union so quickly. ``What was right a year or several months ago, in these conditions is insufficient,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Communists Agree to Give Up Long Monopoly on Power
DOC.TEXT: Official newspapers Thursday said the president and prime minister had offered to resign, and the Communist Party of this Kremlin satellite agreed to give up its nearly 70-year-old monopoly on power. ``This is the beginning of real change,'' Foreign Minstry spokesman Tepbishiin Chimeddorj said of his country, which strategically borders both the Soviet Union and China. The changes, including a call for a contested elections this year, came at a three-day meeting of the party's decision-making Central Committee. The actions met nearly all the demands of opposition parties that have led thousands of people through the capital's streets in demonstrations against the government. President Jambyn Batmonh, 64, and Prime Minister Dumaagiyn Sodnom, 56, had already stepped down this week as members of the party's Politburo, and Batmonh quit as party leader. Official newspapers said they have offered to quit their government posts when the national legislature holds its annual session next week. In another dramatic repudiation of its past, the Central Committee voted to expel former party leader Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal from the party. Tsedenbal, 73, presided over purges in the party during his 31 years in power that ended in 1984. He now lives in Moscow. The Central Committee Thursday appointed former trade union leader Gombogavin Ochirbat as the party's new general secretary and named the party's youngest, most reform-minded Politburo in decades. The five-member Politburo includes Foreign Minister Ts. Gombosuren and L. Tudev, the director of the leading official newspaper, Unen. Mongolian sources said the five met privately today to set the party's course in the face of the challenge from increasingly vocal urban intellectuals demanding democracy. The intellecturals already have formed three oppositon parties to contest elections. Unen reported today that the 174-member Central Committee ``took note'' of Batmonh's and Sodnom's offer to resign from their government jobs. ``I support some proposals for my resignation as prime minister and am willing to discuss another candidate from our party to replace me. This question should be resolved at the Great People's Hural,'' the legislature, Unen quoted Sodnom as saying in a speech Wednesday. He made no apologies for his performance during six years as prime minister. Batmonh has been president since 1984, when he also became party general secretary. Sodnom told the Central Committee that Mongolia's debt to the Soviet Union has more than quadrupled since 1975. The heavy indebtedness to the Soviet Union, which backed Mongolia's 1921 Communist revolution and stations soldiers here, is a major cause of dissatisfaction with the ruling party. Anti-Soviet nationalism has been a major theme of pro-democracy protests that began in January and precipitated the ruling party shake-up. The Soviet Union pledged this month to withdraw all of its estimated 60,000 soldiers by 1992. Unen said 13 elderly Central Committee members, all of whom have retired in the past few years from state or party posts, also resigned their Central Committee membership. Mongolian sources described the 13 as conservatives who worked closely with Tsedenbal. The Central Committee expelled him from the party but did not strip him of his state honors. It rehabilitated four party officials who were purged in the early 1960s for criticizing Tsedenbal. The four were sent to the countryside as punishment for nearly two decades and allowed to return only when Tsedenbal was ousted.

DOC.HEAD: Pre-Election Ennui Prevents Large Turnout at 1848 Commemoration
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people gathered Thursday to commemorate the 1848 democratic revolution against Austrian rule, and some politicians used the occasion to campaign for Hungary's first free elections in 40 years. The anniversary has in recent years become a symbol of resistance against Communist rule. But the Communists will not have a monopoly on power following the parliamentary elections March 25, and the 15,000 who turned out for the anniversary in Budapest was a much smaller number than in past years. Communist supporters were down to a trickle. The Hungarian Socialist Party, the majority faction of the former Communist Party that disbanded in October 1989, is expected to do poorly in the elections. Last year, more than 100,000 demonstrators surged through the streets of the capital on the anniversary of the revolution against Austrian rule, the first truly legal opposition rally on that date. Participants called for democracy and the withdrawal of the Soviet occupation troops. These demands have since been fulfilled to a considerable extent, with the coming elections and a Red Army withdrawal that began March 12. Only about 2,500 people converged on the National Museum to listen to a speech by Imre Pozsgay, the top reformer in the Socialist Party. After the low-key rally he repeated his party's pledge that it is ``prepared to honor all consequences of the elections.'' He predicted his party ``will be among the top four parties and it will be a decisive force in parliament.'' A Gallup poll published Monday gave the Hungarian Democratic Forum, one of the most influential opposition groups, 21 percent of the popular vote. The Free Democrats had 20.3 percent, the Smallholders Party 15.7 percent and the Socialist Party 8 percent. Newspapers publishing the poll did not give details on how many people were questioned or what they were asked. The reports also did not provide a margin of error. Pozsgay has suffered a serious setback in popularity polls because a close associate, former Interior Minister Istvan Horvath, was implicated in a scandal involving illegal police surveillance and because of controversial decisions made by a media panel he instituted. About 15,000 supporters of the Free Democrats and other opposition parties rallied around the monument to poet Sandor Petoefi, a leader of the 1848 revolution, which was suppressed more than a year later with Russian help. Imre Olah of the Entrepreneurs Party, reciting Petoefi, said: ``We swear to God that we will never again be prisoners.'' ``We swear there will never again be a dictatorship by any party,'' Olah added. The most popular speaker appeared to be Viktor Orban, the dynamic leader of the League of Young Democrats, who said, ``Hungary has still not gained the stage of full independence.'' ``We won't have democracy as long as ministers of state, party leaders and other top officials violate the constitution without punishment,'' Orban said. He apparently was referring to the scandal involving Horvath. Orban also ridiculed Foreign Minister Gyula Horn, like most other government leaders a member of the Socialist Party, for a recent suggestion that Hungary might become a member of NATO. The idea later was politely dismissed by defense and other officials. ``Two years ago he did not even suggest a pullout of the Soviet troops from Hungary, and now he is acting as an Atlantic hawk,'' Orban said, drawing laughter from the crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Refuse to Restrict Flow of Jewish Immigrants to Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with comments from Israel, PLO, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Thursday condemned the settlement of Soviet Jewish immigrants in the Israeli-occupied territories but said it will not restrict the flow of Jews to Israel. Israel rejected the criticism by the Soviet Union and Arab states and said their real objective is to halt all Jewish immigration because it fortifies the Jewish state. The heated debate came in the 15-member Security Council as it took up a Soviet complaint against Israel's settlement of a small number of Soviet Jews in the occupied lands and its reported plans to locate tens of thousands more immigrants in the territories, claimed by Palestinians as a future homeland. The United States did not ask to speak and the meeting was adjourned until various draft resolutions criticizing Israel could be reconciled. Soviet Ambassador Alexander M. Belonogov said most emigrating Soviet Jews want to settle in the United States, not Israel. He said if the U.S. eased its entry reguirements for Soviet immigrants, it would help reduce the concerns of Palestinians and defuse tensions in the region. ``One sometimes hears appeals to the Soviet Union to stop Jews leaving for Israel,'' Belonogov said, speaking in Russian through a translator. ``But we cannot possibly undertake such a step because it would be contrary to our overall course and policy of assuring all Soviet citizens equal rights and freedoms, regardless of nationality or ethnic origins.'' ``The question is not for the Soviet Union to impose any probitions,'' he told the 15-member council. ``The question is that of Israel not allowing its ... citizens to settle in the occupied territories.'' Other nations and groups that spoke against Israel included the Palestine Liberation Organization, Jordan, the Arab League, Senegal, Malaysia and Cuba. They argued that Jewish settlement of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip violates the principle of trading land for peace, which they called vital to a Middle East settlement. Farouk Khadoumi, head of the political department of the PLO, said Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel was organized by ``world Zionism,'' while millions of Palestinians remained homeless and stateless. Khadoumi called on the Security Council to impose sanctions against Israel, like those against South Africa. The United States has also opposed the idea of settling Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying it is an obstacle to making peace with Palestinians. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has suggested the occupied territories are needed to accommodate Soviet Jewish immigrants. Israel expects a wave of Soviet immigrants this year. Up to 500 have been arriving daily since the beginning of the year. But Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein, the acting permanent U.N. representative, said Israel does not have a policy of directing Jewish immigrants to the territories. ``Arab states have conjured up a major diplomatic storm in a worldwide effort to block the flow of Jewish immigrants. The real objective behind this campaign is to halt all Jewish immigration to Israel. Period,'' Bein told the Security Council. He said those who oppose Jewish immigration to Israel refuse to accept the reality of a secure and developing sovereign Jewish state ``and persist in the dream of overrunning it.'' In a related development Thursday, a Shiite Moslem group holding hostages in Lebanon threatened attacks against airlines that carry Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine group made the threat in a statement released to a Beirut newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Council to Have No Army Representatives
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The army has chosen not to be represented on a 19-member State Council that will govern Haiti along with provisional President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, a political leader said Thursday. Louis Roy, main author of the 1987 constitution, said that instead a representative of The Women's Movement will be appointed to the council, which will have veto power over the president's decisions. Roy said the army voluntarily chose not to take a council seat, even though the civilian political opposition had agreed to one military representative. ``The army has decided to return to quarters and to remain there,'' said council member Ernst Malebranche. This means the provisional government will be fully comprised of civilians. Haiti has been ruled by the military since the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship in 1986. The State Council, representing such interests as human rights, labor, civic organizations and the country's eight provinces, is to be sworn in Friday at the National Palace. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court judge and Haiti's first woman president, was inaugurated Tuesday, one day after deposed ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled into exile in the United States. At her inauguration, Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, declared that the 6,000-member army was under her command. Roy, a member of the State Council, said the body would be installed even though only 14 of its 19 members had been named as of Thursday. ``We can't wait any longer,'' he said. ``The president has to form her ministerial Cabinet and submit nominations to us for approval.'' A 12-member coalition of political leaders known as Unity Assembly was considering potential Cabinet ministers to recommend to Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot. Avril, who ruled Haiti for 18 months, resigned Saturday after five days of violent protests nationwide. More than 25 people have died and scores have been injured in violence before and after his resignation. Port-au-Prince, the capital of more than 1 million people, was relatively calm Thursday. Independent Radio Haiti Inter said an army sergeant and two civilians were killed in an early morning shootout between an army patrol and unidentified gunmen. Hundreds of government workers seeking the removal of corrupt bosses returned to work after staging a series of brief walkouts Wednesday that disrupted some public services and closed the capital's airport. Hospital workers also were demanding the firing of corrupt administrators. Both groups of employees remained on the job, however.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters in Anderson's Boyhood Home Plan 24-Hour Fast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with service. Picks up 6th graf, `Anderson, 42,...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Friends and relatives of Terry Anderson lit candles, prayed and began a 24-hour fast Thursday to commemorate the journalist's fifth anniversary in captivity. About 180 people attended an interfaith service at Our Lady of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in this Buffalo suburb, 40 miles from Anderson's boyhood home in Batavia. They signed pledges to sacrifice food or something else of importance in honor of Anderson and the 17 other Western hostages. ``Our commitment is to see the hostages released from their captivity and reunited with their families without any further delay,'' the congregation recited from a handout. ``We grieve for the sufferings and fears which oppress people in the Middle East and elsewhere in the world and we join them in their yearning for peace and freedom.'' Penny Anderson, The Associated Press correspondent's sister-in-law, and Carl Anderson, a cousin, were among those who attended from Batavia. Also present was Anne Zickl, a Batavia resident who has never met Anderson but has become a leader of local efforts to secure his release. A procession of 60 children, one for each month of Anderson's captivity since his abduction in Beirut on March 16, 1985, carried paper cranes, a traditional Japanese symbol of peace. ``The peace crane has been a symbol of peace going back to the time of Hiroshima,'' said Sister Pauline Petruzzella of the Sacred Heart church. ``Tonight we gather with our lighted candles and our paper cranes and we pray ... that these would be the words that could free the hostages.'' Other observances were planned Friday in New York City, Washington, D.C., and Cyprus. Anderson, 42, AP's chief Middle East correspondent, is one of eight American hostages. Ten other Westerners are held by kidnappers in Lebanon. The Batavia group planned to break its fast at a Friday evening service there, at which a new 15-minute music video to benefit the Journalists' Committee to Free Terry Anderson would be unveiled, Mrs. Zickl said. A Friday service also was scheduled in Orchard Park. Mrs. Zickl said the idea to fast 24 hours in support of Anderson was conceived by Buffalo Area Metropolitan Ministries, an ecumenical group, and was adopted enthusiastically by Peggy Say, Anderson's sister and the leader of efforts to free the Western hostages in Lebanon. Say will conduct her fast Friday in Washington, where she and other relatives and families of other American hostages will gather at noon in Lafayette Park, across from the White House. Scheduled speakers include Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y.; NBC News anchorman Tom Brokaw; CBS News anchorman Dan Rather, broadcast personality Larry King and AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi. Say promoted the idea of a fast during her recent trip to the Middle East on the hostages' behalf. ``It was received favorably most everywhere she went, particularly by the foreign minister of Syria. She said his eyes misted over,'' Mrs. Zickl said. ``In Islam, fasting is a major part. It's a link between us.'' Fasting, in Western religions, is a traditional way to focus one's concerns on others, said the Rev. Francis Mazur, a Roman Catholic priest who heads the ecumenical group's committee for the Anderson ceremonies. ``We want to have some sort of self-denial to be in communion with those who are less fortunate,'' Mazur said. Organizers learned from the Rev. Lawrence Jenco, a former hostage, ``that there were days when they went hungry, and days when they hid bread under their mattresses.'' Mazur said the group was encouraging all to join in, in one way or another. ``People could just drink some kind of liquid fluid during this period,'' he said. ``They could abstain from two full meals and just eat one. They could abstain from caffeinated drinks if they're heavy coffee drinkers.'' Other commemorations Friday: _In Nicosia, Cyprus, the AP's Mideast hub, the multidenominational Nicosia Community Church will conduct a 40-minute prayer service. _In Lorain, Ohio, Anderson's birthplace, supporters plan a ceremony in front of city hall, and another at a Veterans of Foreign Wars hall. _In New York City, an AP-arranged Mass will be conducted at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DOC.HEAD: West German President Visits on 51st Anniversary of Nazi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The president of West Germany assured officials here Thursday, the 51st anniversary of the Nazi invasion of Czechoslovakia, that his country has no territorial claims on its neighbors. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel welcomed the visit of his collegue Richard Von Weizsaecker as a ``sign of great hope'' and a counterpoint to the 1939 invasion. Havel made his own contribution to reconciliation by traveling to East Germany and West Germany for his first state visits following his election Dec. 29 as president. Weizsaecker is the first leader to pay a state visit to Czechoslovakia since Havel became president after the peaceful revolution that ousted the hard-line Communist leaders who had ruled practically since the end of World War II. Recalling Germany as a ``messenger of war'' whose troops invaded Czechoslovakia March 15, 1939, Havel said Weizsaecker was by contrast a ``messenger of peace ... of glad tidings that violence must nevermore prevail over freedom, lies over truth and evil over human life.'' ``Together we can strive for a democratic Europe, a Europe of unity in diversity,'' Havel said. The invasion occurred after the Munich agreement of Britain and France, which hoped to appease Adolf Hitler by giving him the German-speaking part of Czechoslovakia. Hitler decided to invade on March 10, 1939, and German troops were ordered to take up positions by the evening of March 12. When the Nazi troops had taken over, an ecstatic Hitler ordered his two secretaries: ``You kids give me a kiss here and here,'' pointing to his cheeks, one of the women later recalled. Weizsaecker's visit came two days before a Prague meeting of foreign ministers from the seven Warsaw Pact nations, called to discuss the reunification of the Germany and its possible effects on neighboring countries. ``From the ages we were closely united; we want to be again in the future,'' Weizsaecker said. He talked of the dramatic democratic changes that have forced Communists from power in most East bloc countries and led to the fall of the Iron Curtain that divided Europe in the Cold War. ``Walls have fallen, fences been laid down, barbed wire cut. The borders are open. We respect them without any restrictions and have no territorial claims whatsoever towards any neighbor.'' His remarks were intended to placate fears of Germany's neighbors, particularly Poland, that a strong united Germany could reclaim prewar territory. ``The whole of Europe must be grateful to Germans because they began to tear down the wall which divided them, because by doing so they started the tearing down of a wall which divides Europe,'' Havel said. He was referring to the Berlin Wall, which began to fall in November with the East German revolution. But Havel also advised the Germanys to dispel European fears of a united Germany. ``If, for example, they manage to unequivocally confirm the final validity of existing borders, including those with Poland, or if they manage to finally deal with those who still have the nerve to flirt with Nazi ideology, they will do a lot to free Europe from fear,'' Havel said. ``It is apparent that the fate of us all depends today again predominantly on the development of Germany. ``I understand today's visit by President Weizsaecker as a true counterpart of the old and painful visit that we remember today. While that visit was an omen of terror and deepening despair, today's visit is on the contrary a sign of great hope for us all.''

DOC.HEAD: Peres Topples Israeli Government to Achieve `Momentum for Peace'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with King Hussein's comment, minor editing. Picks up 7th graf, `Peres won ... editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1,JRL5
DOC.TEXT: Labor leader Shimon Peres toppled the coalition government of hard-line Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Thursday and declared that with his action, he had created ``momentum toward peace.'' Peres drove a no-confidence vote through Parliament after Shamir had balked for weeks at U.S. proposals to get talks started with the Palestinians. Shamir, the first premier in Israel's 42-year history to be turned out of office by a no-confidence vote, listened to the vote tally with his head down, glumly shuffling papers on his desk. ``We are not surprised ... and I am not sorry,'' he told reporters later. Said Peres, who is likely to be picked to form a new government, ``Parliament has shown that there is a majority for peace. I believe we can form a government that will reach a dialogue with the Palestinians.'' But little headway is considered likely in peace efforts as long as Israel is consumed with internal poltics. Fashisoning a new coalition government may take months. In London, visiting King Hussein of Jordan said Thursday the United States must take more responsibility for Middle East peace because of Israel's political crisis, and he warned that extremists on both sides could endanger world peace. ``Something needs to be done and fast,'' he told a luncheon of the Association of American Correspondents in London. Peres won on a 60-55 vote after a vitriolic debate and intense behind-the-scenes bargaining that lasted 10 hours. The victory came from a majority of those present and voting in the 120-member Knesset, or parliament. The political crisis comes during a continuing Palestinian insurrection in the occupied lands against Israeli rule. At least 663 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt that began in December 1987. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain in the violence. As a result of Thursday's loss, Shamir, 74, a former underground leader and spymaster for the Mossad secret service, could face an uprising in his own Likud bloc. Trade Minister Ariel Sharon and Housing Minister David Levy, both hawks who want to abandon the U.S. peace effort, have repeatedly sought to oust Shamir from the party leadership, which he assumed in 1983. Starting Sunday, aides said, President Chaim Herzog will canvass parliament members as to who should form the next government. He is expected to give the nod to Peres, who would have a maximum of six weeks to assemble a coalition. In the interim, Shamir will stay on as head of a caretaker government in which no ministers are allowed to resign and none can be added. If Peres fails, Shamir or another Likud leader may be chosen to form a government. If that fails, new elections may be called. The past two elections, in July 1984 and November 1988, ended in virtual tie votes that forced the two big parties into coalitions. For Peres, trying to mesh leftist secular parties with conservative religious factions will be a major test. In the past, Orthodox parties have demanded tougher laws to deal with restaurants and stores that open on the Sabbath, a major source of friction with liberal factions. Peres won primarily on a stay-away vote by five of the six members of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, which allied with Likud in the past. Shamir might have avoided the no-confidence vote if he had gone to Herzog and resigned the government or survived it by agreeing to a last-minute compromise from Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, Shas' spiritual leader. Yosef proposed acceptance of U.S. proposals for starting a dialogue with Palestinians. Shamir stuck to his belief that the U.S. ideas would give the PLO a role and jeopardize Israel's claim to sovereignty over the captured Arab sector of Jerusalem. Shamir insisted his party was just as interested in making peace as Labor. In unusually tough language, he accused Peres of making concessions that benefited Israel's Arab enemies, such as his endorsement of an international peace conference. Peres scoffed at Shamir's concerns, saying Shamir was the victim of ``antiquated ideas'' and that the right-wing premier's foot-dragging had been ``murdering the peace process.''

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Hanged For Alleged Spying; Britain Recalls Ambassador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf `President Hussein' to insert dropped word `not.' Picks up 13th, ``It seems...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON3,15
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Thursday hanged a London-based journalist it accused of spying, touching off a storm of protest from European governments. Britain recalled its ambassador from Iraq and halted ministerial visits. ``Thatcher wanted him alive. We sent him in a box,'' Information Minister Latif Nassayif Jassim said in announcing the execution. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher led the campaign to repeal the death sentence imposed on 31-year-old Farzad Bazoft. Bazoft was working for The Observer, a London weekly, investigating reports of an explosion at an Iraqi military facility when he was arrested. Iraq accused Bazoft of spying for Israel and Britain, charges Bazoft and his colleagues denied. Observer editor Donald Trelford and about 200 journalists held a vigil outside the heavily guarded Iraqi Embassy in London. Journalists left a single candle burning in Bazoft's memory in St. Bride's church, Fleet Street, London's former newspaper row. ``It is an awful day for the newspaper,'' said Trelford. ``We have had one of our number killed for simply being a reporter.'' Arab governments stayed silent. Even Jordan's King Hussein, who joined the Palestine Liberation Organization in appeals for clemency, would not condemn President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The British domestic news agency Press Association late Thursday quoted unidentified British government sources as saying Bazoft served a jail term in Britain for robbery. The sources were quoted as saying Bazoft was convicted at Northampton, central England, in August 1981 of robbing a savings and loan office of $765. He was said to have walked into the office carrying a fake bomb and threatened to blow up the building unless he was given the money. He was sentenced to 18 months in jail but with good conduct time got out after a year, PA quoted the sources as saying. The agency quoted the sources as saying the jail term had no bearing on diplomatic decisions taken by the Thatcher government Thursday. President Hussein had said repeatedly that Iraq did not fear Britain's anger, and the information minister repeated this after the execution. ``It seems the British could not understand our psychology that we are not intimidated,'' Jassim said. Hundreds of journalists from government-run Iraqi media applauded. Jassim said Bazoft's body was handed over to the British Embassy. In London, Mrs. Thatcher said, ``This is a very, very grave and serious matter. The Iraqi government's action is an act of barbarism which is deeply repugnant to all civilized people.'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd announced that Ambassador Harold Walker had been recalled from Baghdad. Hurd called off a trade mission to Iraq and said all ministerial visits had been halted. Hurd also said all six Iraqi military trainees in Britain were being ordered to leave the country. But he said there were no plans to implement trade sanctions. Britain has a trade surplus of about $648 million with Iraq. Bazoft, an Iranian-born journalist, was detained in September near a military industrial complex south of Baghdad. He was investigating reports that hundreds of people had died in an explosion at the complex in August. A British nurse, Daphne Parish, 52, was convicted on charges she drove Bazoft to the Al-Iskandaria military complex and was sentenced to 15 years in prison. Ms. Parish had been working as a senior nursing administrator at an Irish-run hospital in the Iraqi capital. Robin Kealy, the British general consul in Baghdad, visited Bazoft shortly before his hanging at Abu Ghraib prison in Baghdad. In a British Broadcasting Corp. interview, Kealy said Bazoft looked ``hollow-eyed and subdued'' and repeated that he was not a spy. The first news of the execution in Iraqi media came on the evening television news program. The broadcast include a televised statement first broadcast in October in which Bazoft said he was a spy for Israel. He reportedly said in court during his trial last week the statement was made under duress. The television report said Bazoft was disguised as an Indian doctor when arrested and was carrying maps he had drawn. Last year, Western diplomats in Baghdad confirmed there had been an explosion at the Al-Iskandaria complex around Aug. 17. The London newspaper The Independent quoted unidentified diplomats and Middle East sources as saying 700 people were killed, including Egyptian engineers helping the Iraqis to develop a ballistic missile. The Iraqis have said there was an explosion and fire at a fuel depot in the area Aug. 17, 1989 and that 19 Iraqis were killed, mainly firefighters. Bazoft, a stateless Iranian, was the son of an Iranian National Oil Co. manager. He never returned to Iran after coming to Britain as a teen-ager and was traveling in Iraq on British papers. As a journalist, he specialized in Middle East affairs. The European Parliament observed a minute's silence in Bazoft's memory. Amnesty International said the execution was the latest in a long list of ``severe and systematic human rights abuses,'' in Iraq. The International Press Institute based in London and Zurich sent a cable to Hussein expressing ``outrage and shock.'' Britain's National Union of Journalists said Bazoft paid a terrible price for ``the freedom of information.'' In Paris, the Reporters Without Borders said Iraq had committed a ``state crime.'' The Bush administration expressed regret Thursday but did not join the strong condemnation. On Bazoft's computer terminal in the Observer news room Thursday were the words, ``May he rest in peace.'' His clippings lay nearby.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Threatens Retaliation Over Chemical Plant Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th `The plant' with U.S. official saying plant inoperable, according to its intelligence resources. Picks up 7th graf, `ABC News...'
DOC.TEXT: A fire caused extensive damage to a chemical plant outside Tripoli that is suspected of producing poison gas, and Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi on Thursday threatened to punish West Germany if its agents set the blaze. West Germany, whose companies helped build the plant, denied the accusation and filed a protest with Libya over an angry demonstration outside Bonn's embassy in Tripoli, the Libyan capital. Gadhafi insisted that the heavily guarded plant in Rabta, 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, was designed to produce only pharmaceuticals. But he said Libya would pay millions of dollars to any company willing to build it a chemical weapons facility. ``In such eventuality, I will sign the contract myself unhesitatingly,'' Gadhafi was quoted as saying by Libya's official JANA news agency, which was monitored in Rome. He said Libya would not hesitate to manufacture weapons of ``total devastation'' if it had the ability, but he said it would take 20 years for Libya to develop such weapons. Libya was accused of using chemical weapons in its war against Chad. The plant, once described by CIA Director William Webster as the world's largest chemical weapons factory, caught fire Wednesday. There were conflicting reports about damage and how the fire started. Late Thursday, a senior U.S. official in Washington said the United States had used its ``intelligence resources'' to conclude the plant was inoperable. U.S. intelligence resources are known to include satellites capable of high-resolution photography. ABC News quoted unidentified Libyan security sources as claiming the plant was burned to the ground by U.S. and Israeli agents. The United States and Israel denied involvement. A previously unknown group of Libyan dissidents, the Organization of the Patriotic Wing of the Libyan Army, claimed responsibility for the blaze in a statement sent to West Germany's ARD television network. The White House said last week the plant posed a serious danger and called for ``vigorous efforts'' to stop its operation. From Bush on down Thursday, the administration denied any involvement in the blaze. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't have any idea who did it. ... Somebody could have knocked over a kerosene lamp or something.'' He said damage was extensive, but the building still stood. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said, ``We have had various ... reports of accidents at the plant before the current fire.'' Mahmoud Azzabi, press secretary at Libya's U.N. mission in New York, said there was speculation saboteurs infiltrated Libya from neighboring Tunisia. A journalist for JANA, reached by telephone from Cairo, said he was unsure whether there were casualties in the fire but said the plant was badly damaged. ``You may consider it has been burned down,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Yitzhak Rabin, who resigned as Israel's defense minister Tuesday, denied Israel was involved in the fire and called the speculation ``nonsense.'' The JANA report quoted Gadhafi as saying that the cause of the blaze was under investigation. He said if investigators prove West German intelligence services were involved, ``the presence of Germany economically will be eliminated and the country involved in espionage and subversion for imperialism and Zionism will lose.'' West Germany's ambassador in Tripoli was summoned to meet with Libya's Foreign Office, but no threats were made during the meeting, according to a West German government official in Bonn. In Bonn, the Foreign Ministry summoned a Libyan diplomat to protest a demonstration by about 800 Libyan demonstrators who temporarily blockaded access to the West German Embassy in Tripoli. Charges by the United States that German companies helped build the Rabta plant caused a major scandal in West Germany slightly over a year ago. West Germany at first denied the claims, but later acknowledged them and launched its own investigations. For more than 14 months, the United States has accused Libya of using the plant to make chemical weapons, including mustard and nerve gases. When Western reporters were taken to the chemical plant in January 1989, they found it guarded by soldiers, tanks and surface-to-air missiles. The journalists were not allowed to inspect the plant. Libya's Radio Tripoli urged Arab support for Libya in the face of ``an aggressive campaign of American imperialism.'' ``The American campaign against the pharmaceutical factory at Rabta is a conspiracy against this important strategic achievement, which should furnish medicine for the entire Arab nation and break the foreign monopoly in this area,'' said the broadcast, monitored in Tunis. The United States engaged in hostilities with Libya three times in the 1980s, twice shooting down Libyan fighter planes and bombing Tripoli in 1986 in retaliation for what former President Reagan said was terrorism against Americans in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Wyoming Becomes 46th State To Honor King
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS overline, lead to CORRECT that Wyoming is 46th state, sted 47th state to honor King. ADDS 1 graf at end to give four states without holidays.
DOC.TEXT: Wyoming became the 46th state to honor Martin Luther King Jr.'s ideals when Gov. Mike Sullivan signed legislation Thursday creating a state holiday dedicated to equal rights. Although Wyoming calls itself the Equality State because it was the first to give women the vote, it took years for lawmakers to agree to set aside the third Monday in January in King's honor. Legislative leaders opposed to the holiday questioned whether King should be singled out, noting that many other Americans also fought for civil rights. The legislation Sullivan signed into law creates ``Martin Luther King Jr. Wyoming Equality Day.'' Championing the measure for the past eight years has been state Sen. Liz Byrd, the Legislature's only black. ``It was a real disappointment each year to watch the failure of the Martin Luther King Jr. legislation in the Wyoming Legislature,'' she told the crowd jamming the Statehouse rotunda for the signing ceremony. ``Those years of trying to get this legislation passed were trying times. But today is a happy day. Today is a historic day. ``What a wonderful centennial gift to be here today and to have this bill,'' Byrd added, referring to Wyoming's 100th birthday this July 10. The King holiday did not come easily. Senate opponents urged the body to reject a holiday in King's name and support one simply commemorating equal rights. The House also was uneasy with the holiday in King's name only and added the Wyoming Equality Day provision to the legislation. The four states that do not recognize the King holiday are Arizona, Montana, Idaho and New Hampshire.

DOC.HEAD: More Tornadoes And Snowstorm Suprises Upper Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``Temperatures,'' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Ferguson comment on size of tornado, Ala. storms; and inserts 4 grafs after 13th graf pvs, ``Biloxi got,'' to UPDATE with Okla. flooding.
DOC.TEXT: Relentless thunderstorms that have hammered the Plains with tornadoes set off another twister attack Thursday in Mississippi, and a snowstorm suprised the upper Midwest and closed schools. The heat wave that has gently toasted much of the eastern half of the nation continued to set high temperature records. Thunderstorms have spawned damaging tornadoes this week in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas and Illinois. This week's unusual winter heat wave and storms began with a strong low pressure system that moved through the Rockies onto the Plains, explained Ed Ferguson of the National Severe Storms Forecast Center in Kansas City, Mo. ``In advance of that, we had a strong flow of warm air move through the Plains. These strong southerly winds brought a lot of warm temperatures and high humidities,'' Ferguson said. ``In fact, that strong flow of air existed from the Gulf of Mexico to the Great Lakes. ``Those warm temperatures and high humidities set the stage then for strong thunderstorm development because warm, moist air from the Gulf of Mexico was colliding with cooler, drier air from the northwest.'' As for the snow in the north, he said: ``The parent low pressure system is still moving slowly. Up north, we're still dealing with what the system can produce.'' Ferguson said the tornado that devastated Hesston, Kan., on Tuesday ``was a history-maker.'' ``That tornado was head and shoulders above the ordinary tornado. It was very violent,'' he said. ``It had abnormally high wind speeds, probably in excess of 250 miles an hour. It was the longest tracked tornado in recent years and maybe stands out among the top 10 since records were kept since 1950.'' Temperatures hit record highs in the 60s, 70s and 80s again Thursday in Ohio, Michigan, New Jersey, Maryland, New York, Massachusetts, Vermont, North Carolina, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Rhode Island, Delaware, Connecticut and the District of Columbia, the National Weather Service reported. For some cities it was the fourth consecutive day of record warmth. Thunderstorms dumped more than 6 inches of rain on parts of southwestern Alabama on Thursday, causing some street flooding that threatened homes in low-lying areas. A tornado in a sparsely populated area of Baldwin County flipped two mobile homes off their foundations. Severe thunderstorms pounded Mississippi in advance of a slow-moving cold front and a tornado smashed a path of damage through rural George County, injuring five people, including three children, whose mobile home was smashed. ``It knocked my trailer over, picked it up and dropped it back again,'' Rai Smith, 21, said in a telephone interview from her hospital room in Lucedale. ``When it all stopped, the walls became the floor and the bathroom door was directly above me.'' Smith, who is four months pregnant, said she managed to climb up to the bathroom door and ease past a washing machine ``before it fell down into the area that I had just left.'' George County authorities said two mobile homes, including the Smith family's, were destroyed. In addition, Sheiff Eugene Howell said two houses were damaged and several roads were blocked by downed trees. Biloxi got 4.3 inches of rain between 6 a.m. and noon. Several sections of the state suffered power outages. The sky was mostly sunny Thursday across Oklahoma, but two days of steady downpours swelled creeks and rivers and threatened some parts of the state with flooding. Okmulgee County appeared to be in the most danger. Flood stage for the Deep Fork there is about 18 feet, and the weather service said it probably would crest at about 31 feet by Friday morning. Okmulgee Sheriff Jim Hart said several residents who live near the river had already evacuated but two families waited too long and deputies had to evacuate the families from their homes on horseback, leaving their belongings behind. ``The water was up to the horses' bellies,'' he said. To the north, a storm plastered western Iowa with up to 9 inches of sticky snow Thursday and brought minor flooding and gusty wind to the rest of the state. ``It was pretty much of a surprise,'' said weather service meteorologist Jeff Hutton, adding that heavy snow had been forecast for eastern Nebraska and instead fell much further east. He said the snow in western Iowa and rain elsewhere was brought by a vigorous low pressure system racing north directly over the state. ``It's an intense surface low that pulled down the cold air and wrapped it around,'' he said. The storm socked southwestern Minnesota with heavy, wet snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain and forced the closing of at least 28 schools. Up to 10 inches of snow was possible. North Dakota was under a winter storm warning as snow and gusty north wind threatened the state with near blizzard conditions. Snowfall amounts were expected to range from 4 inches in the west to 10 inches in the east, the weather service said. Wind gusted to 100 mph at Rapid, S.D., and high wind blew across Minnesota and Wisconsin. In Wyoming, wind blowing at more than 25 mph whipped up snow and cut visibility to zero along slippery highways, forcing the Highway Patrol to close a 45-mile stretch of Interstate 80. Traffic also was kept off 14 miles of Interstate 25 from Cheyenne south to the Colorado line off and on because of accidents. No injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Truckers Reach for the Stars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: During his 16 years on the road, trucker Roosevelt Jones had to rely on telephones to contact his company, often phoning dispatchers thousands of miles away to report trouble or receive instructions. Now, without leaving his rig, he can send and receive messages in seconds using a satellite system that is revolutionizing the trucking industry. Besides providing speedy communications, the system features special truck transmitters that enable dispatchers to monitor each vehicle's travels and pinpoint its location. Customers can get hourly updates on the status of shipments. ``All the folks that have them in their trucks seem to like them,'' said Jones, a driver for Wingate-Taylor Maid Transportation Inc., a subsidiary of Burlington Motor Carriers. Burlington, the nation's fourth-largest truck load carrier, is installing the satellite system in 2,000 trucks operated by its four subsidiaries: Wingate-Tailor Maid of Albany, Ga.; Stoops Express of Anderson, Ind.; Monroe Trucking of Monroe, La.; and Monkem of Joplin, Mo. Joanne Rang, executive director of the American Trucking Association, said satellite tracking is still relatively new and represents a substantial investment for companies. Firms willing to make the investment should be able to monitor shipments more closely and provide better service to their customers, she said in an interview from her Alexandria, Va., office. Mike Hodson, Burlington's vice president for quality, said the company evaluated several systems before selecting one developed by Hughes Network Systems of Germantown, Md. During an eight-month study, Burlington trucks equipped with satellite communications ran more miles, ran fewer empty miles and ran the most direct routes, Hodson said in a phone interview from his Hurst, Texas, office. The system proved it could reduce waste, lower operating costs, give Burlington a competitive edge and improve its drivers' quality of life, he said. Drivers who rely on phones have to interrupt trips to check in with their companies. They call from truck stops, rest areas or any other place with safe parking. After delivering their cargos, they often have to phone dispatchers repeatedly, sometimes for lengthy periods, for instructions on picking up new loads. ``He ends up at some truck stop drinking coffee, smoking cigarettes, shooting the breeze,'' Hodson said. ``Now he can sleep and wait for a beeper to go off. We think it's going to create a safer fleet because the guys are going to be better rested.'' The Burlington drivers communicate via a small keyboard that displays messages on a tiny screen. They can select routine messages and fill in blank spaces with details, or type in special messages. For safety, the truckers can't send messages while driving. The message is beamed to a satellite and then down to a dish antenna in Washington, D.C., where it is decoded. It then is sent back to the satellite and down to Burlington's message center in Joplin, Mo. From there it is relayed to the subsidiaries by telephone line. Dispatchers sitting at computer terminals can communicate with drivers or ask the computer to list the locations of all trucks they are supervising. ``It's going to improve our efficiency,'' said Mike Driggers, Wingate-Tailor Maid's vice president of operations. As driver Jones prepared to make his first trip with the new system, he met with instructor Rodney Hogan to learn how to operate the keyboard and transmit messages. ``It seems kind of odd to me because I never used it before,'' he said before pointing his white Freightliner toward Amarillo, Tex. ``Once I get used to it, I think I'll like it better than a phone.''

DOC.HEAD: Coming to America: Japanese Becoming Partners With U.S. Colleges
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In a remote little patch of Iowa, where soybeans are hot and sushi is not, the new talk of the town is teikei. That's Japanese for partnership. Two cultures and two countries are coming together in Le Mars, Iowa, in the marriage of two schools: cash-hungry Westmar College and Teikyo University in Tokyo. ``Our community just got bigger and the world just got smaller,'' said Arthur Richardson, president of the new Teikyo Westmar University, after a plan was approved this month that will bring new dollars and new students _ from Japan _ to the Iowa school. Across America, the Japanese are investing hundreds of millions of dollars in a small but growing number of colleges and universities, many struggling for survival. Some are joint programs or mergers. In a few cases, they're building from bottom up; a $250 million school is planned near Washington, D.C. ``It's a win-win situation,'' Richardson said. ``They win an accredited, four-year education in the States. We win the student population, the market niche and the dollars to improve salaries and facilities.'' Teikyo, which has 26,000 students in Japan and branches in Britain and the Netherlands, already has links with schools in Colorado and West Virginia. Another Japanese investor has bought a share of an Oregon college. Though the entry into higher education isn't big _ only a few thousand students will be added to the 24,000 Japanese students already here _ or as splashy as the sale of New York's Rockefeller Center, it stirs the same divided sentiments. ``It's good in that the Japanese really want to be international because they're stung by charges they're too insular and unknowing of the outside world,'' said John Sylvester, director of the North Carolina Japan Center at North Carolina State University. ``If you're putting a bad spin on it, you'd say the Japanese are trying to go out and conquer foreign markets in just about everything.'' Some, however, insist this isn't business rivalry. ``It isn't a market Japan is taking away,'' said Michael Young, a professor of Japanese law at Columbia University, now on leave at the State Department. ``We should be tremendously flattered.'' Indeed, Sylvester said, the Japanese respect the American university system. Japanese education through high school is generally tougher than in this country, he said, but ``our universities as a rule are more rigorous than theirs.'' Education isn't the only lure. Teikyo's ties here make it ``much more prestigious,'' said Robert Helmick, legal consultant to the Japanese school. And Japanese colleges can make money by having the attraction of a foreign campus, Sylvester said. But educators also note most Japanese schools involved aren't first-rate institutions. ``You're not going to find the really fast-track males coming here,'' Young said. Still, the American partners aren't complaining. They receive money, students and, they hope, a better image. Take Salem College, a poor school in West Virginia with no endowment and 400 students, until last summer's merger with Teikyo. An initial $12 million investment erased the school's debt and raised faculty salaries an average of 27 percent, said Ronald Ohl, president of the new Salem-Teikyo University. ``Being debt-free and having some financial stability in and of itself is just a novel experience,'' he said. The school expects to spend $40 million to $60 million on improvements, equipment and staff, he said, and boost average SAT scores from about 700 to 1,200 in four years _ by being more selective in admitting U.S. students. Thousands of miles away, Geos Corp., a Japanese company operating English-language schools around the world, has bought a 49 percent share of Warner Pacific College in Portland, Ore., for $6 million. The 450-student liberal arts school will buy back its assets after 30 years. Last year's deal improved the school's finances and ``more doors have opened to us in the business community and economic community,'' said administrative vice president Arthur Kelly. Money isn't always the motive. Regis College, a Jesuit school in Denver operating with a balanced budget for 14 years, sold one of its seven campuses to Teikyo for a reported $6.5 million and will develop an American-style curriculum for Japanese students. Not everyone is as receptive. Phillips University in Enid, Okla., wasn't interested in a tentative $24 million purchase offer made by the head of the Kyoto Institute of Technology. ``It's like trying to sell the congregation of a church,'' said President Richard Peck. ``How can you sell 51 percent of the board of deacons of a church? It doesn't work.'' The offer was withdrawn, but Phillips, with Kyoto's owner, established two satellite campuses in Japan and soon will open a third. The Japanese also have other plans here, including a two-year college in Maryland and Washington International University in Loudoun County, Va., a $250 million project. Both are for American and Japanese students. On a much smaller scale, Tokyo International University has built a branch adjacent to its sister school, Willamette University in Salem, Ore. ``This is a start for our students to learn the American way to do business, their education and lifestyle,'' said Ryuji Torihara, dean of administration of the one-year program. In Le Mars, an agricultural community of about 8,000 people, up to 200 Japanese students arrive in April. Formal classes start this fall at the school, celebrating its 100th birthday. The chairman of the board of trustees resigned, protesting the Westmar president's secret discussions with Teikyo and arguing the decision was reached too quickly. And the United Methodist Church, which provides $90,000 to the college, has raised questions about future ties to the 566-student school. But the trustees approved the deal and Teikyo's gift _ Richardson says it's several million dollars _ has provided security and double-digit raises in a school that was near financial collapse in the mid-1980s. Much remains to be settled, including the makeup of the new board of trustees. Helmick said he'll recommend the majority be American, though in Salem it's the reverse. The school plans to have an exchange work program, which Helmick said will give students an edge. ``Companies in the United States and Japan are spending a lot of money learning how to do business in another country,'' he said. ``We think our graduates will already have that knowledge.'' Richardson sees one obstacle: cultural adjustment. ``That's where the hard work and long haul takes place,'' he said. But Mayor Bonnie Dull noted the English, Germans and Dutch all settled in the area and ``assimilated very well. I can't see why there would be a difference.'' ``A lot of it depends on the students,'' said Kathy Faber, news editor at the Le Mars Daily Sentinel. ``If they're willing to come out in the community and say, `Here I am,' folks are going to say, `We're glad you're here.'''
