DOC.HEAD: Japanese Universities Sprouting Around the World
With AM-Japan 101, b0450
DOC.TEXT: Shoichi Okinaga says he believes that Japanese and American students learning together will promote understanding and friendship between the two countries, and the world will gain. ``So I decided to acquire colleges in the United States,'' said Okinaga, the wealthy president of Teikyo University, which has bought into colleges in Colorado, Iowa and West Virginia. Japanese plans call for spending at least $320 million to buy or build universities abroad. Okinaga said he plans to spend 10 billion yen, or $70 million, over two years to develop academic homes for Japanese students overseas, as well as to give foreign students more knowledge of Japan. A slower approach is coordinated by Toshio Yamaguchi, an influential legislator of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, who backs a $250 million plan to build a university outside Washington, D.C., with courses taught in both Japanese and English. Behind Yamaguchi is EIE International Corp., a Japanese conglomerate with such real estate holdings as the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in California, resorts and hotels on the Gold Coast in Australia, and an interest in Bond University, a project started by troubled Australian financier Alan Bond. Jiro Yaginuma, spokesman for EIE International, said the company also plans a private university in Europe and foresees an eventual link among institutions in Australia, Europe and the United States. Asked if profit was the motive, Yaginuma replied: ``Everyone can understand that this is not an instant profit-making project. It takes time to become profitable or even break even. So we are patient enough to wait until such time.'' Backers of the plans to put Japanese universities in the United States list high motives: to increase Japan-U.S. understanding, advance the ability of young Japanese in the English language, meet the growing desire of young Americans to study Japanese and develop internationally minded leaders of tomorrow. Yamaguchi said he was driven partly by his ``inferiority complex _ being an internationalist who doesn't speak English.'' His planned school is to be called Washington International University and will be located in Loudoun County, Va., opening for its first undergraduates in 1993. In the 1988-89 school year, about 24,000 Japanese students attended American colleges and universities, and Yamaguchi said many of them fail because their English isn't good enough. To help negotiate the language barrier, Washington International University will permit entering Japanese students to take two years of courses in Japanese while studying English. Americans could take their last two years in Japanese after studying the language. The push to establish Japanese schools in the United States comes as more than 30 U.S. colleges have sprouted branches in Japan or announced plans to open branches in the past few years, meeting the growing thirst for U.S.-style higher education. Japanese education has a reputation for producing top-notch high school graduates, but critics say universities don't produce enough people with foreign-language skills and, with the exception of top schools, do not demand hard work. U.S. universities, by contrast, are thought to develop more creative graduates, and it's noted that Japan has produced few Nobel Prize winners compared to the United States. Yamaguchi said he had visited Washington often as chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the lower house of Parliament and was impressed with the Virginia countryside, which he said ``reflects the American spirit of independence.'' ``Its natural and historical background, plus rich human resources in Washington and young people from all over the world, will create an ideal educational environment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez Repairs Near Completion, Summer Return to Service Expected
With BC-Valdez-Spill Revisited, b0716-b0717
LaserPhoto GO2 of March 14
DOC.TEXT: The tanker Exxon Valdez, its hull ripped apart a year ago on Alaska's Bligh Reef, is a ship without a name as it undergoes repairs. Fresh gray paint covers the name synonymous with environmental catastrophe. The $30 million repair job, which began last August, is about 70 percent complete, and the tanker should be released to Exxon in July, said Fred Hallett, vice president and chief financial officer of National Steel & Shipbuilding Co. It could be hauling crude oil again this summer, but under what name and where have not yet been determined, said Exxon Shipping Co. spokeswoman Carrie Chassin. Exxon Shipping president Frank Iarossi, sensitive to the vessel's virtually indelible association with the environmental disaster, has said the ship may be given a ``fresh start'' under a new name away from Alaska, perhaps the Gulf of Mexico. Nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil poured into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, after rocks ripped into the hull of the 987-foot tanker. A couple of boulders that lodged in the Valdez were removed at the shipyard and, after being examined by parties in the spill litigation, were released to Exxon, which had them ground up at a construction site, Chassin said. The single-skinned tanker is being restored to its original specifications, despite some studies showing that equipping ships with double bottoms or hulls would prevent or reduce spillage in the event of an accident. Exxon Shipping officials determined that ``retrofitting the entire vessel from an engineering standppoint was not feasible,'' Chassin said. ``Basically the whole bottom has been rebuilt,'' said Peter Zschiesche, business representative for the machinists union at the shipping company. ``The middle of the bottom, that's been ripped out, back to front. Then they went in and started putting those pieces back'' in 100-ton steel segments. Still to be completed is patching on the mangled starboard side, which bore the brunt of the grounding. When the repairs are completed, the bottom will be coated with 3,000 tons of inch-thick steel. The Valdez arrived last July at the shipyard, where it was built in 1986, after being towed 2,500 miles from Alaska. ``Literally all of her starboard side was gone,'' Hallett said. ``You could stand underneath the ship and look 70 feet up at the main deck. I don't think anybody has seen that kind of damage in peacetime and have a ship survive.''

DOC.TEXT: For some people, ``A Chorus Line'' was more than a musical. It was a way of life. Alyce Gilbert has worked on Broadway's longest-running show since the beginning, from its first preview performances at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater in April 1975 to its opening at Broadway's Shubert Theater the following July and throughout its 15-year run. Now, her job and those of its 58 other production people, 26 musicians and 34 dancers will end April 28 when ``A Chorus Line'' closes after 6,137 performances. Gilbert is the musical's wardrobe mistress, a quaint title for someone who must deal with four loads of dirty laundry every workday _ and twice on matinee days. That's not to mention her finding, getting repaired and keeping track of shoes, socks, buttons, glass beads, leotards, pants, jump suits, jackets and top hats during what usually is a 12-hour day or longer. ``Wardrobe is about continuity,'' says the woman who first looked after costumes at age 12 for a children's theater company in her hometown of Milwaukee. ``It's not design. It's about things staying the same or kept within a certain parameter.'' Gilbert has the responsibility of maintaining the show's costumes designed by three-time Tony winner Theoni V. Aldredge. She has had to make the replacement clothes look the way Aldredge intended them to look a decade and a half ago. That can mean a lot of problems. ``You're dealing with some things that are rather firmly rooted in the fashion of 1975 that don't exist anymore,'' Gilbert says. For one thing, dance clothes have changed. When ``A Chorus Line'' first opened, dancewear mostly was nylon Helanca. Now, it's Milliskin, made out of Lycra, a shiny, spandex fiber, that prevails. ``Everything in the world is made out of that now,'' Gilbert says. So the musical's nylon dance clothes have to be specially ordered. And then all the dancewear, except for the women's black leotards, has to be dyed. ``Theoni's colors are very specific,'' Gilbert says. ``All the women in the show wear some kind of red, from pink to lavender to burgundy to maroon. The men are dressed in blues, browns and greens. ``We took the bell-bottoms out of the pants in 1981. It took a long time before they went out of dance pants primarily because it makes your legs look longer and that's something dancers always love.'' Gilbert has witnessed not only a revolution in dancewear but a change in the shapes of the dancers themselves. ``It used to be a very long, thin chorus line,'' she says. ``Over the 15 years, it's become a much more athletic body. Dancers go to gyms. They pump. They do very distinct things to build bulky muscles which you never saw in 1975. It was not aesthetically pleasing then, but somewhere along the line, the public's eye changed and so did the choreographer's'.'' Gilbert's workday usually has begun at 10 a.m. in the basement of the Shubert in a catacomb-like space crammed with racks and boxes of costumes in every size and color. ``It's the buy-it-when-you-see-it-and-keep-it syndrome,'' she laughs. ``We've got a lot of weird stuff around.'' Here she starts the day's first load of laundry. The dancewear is washed after each performance in a cold-water detergent. The glittery finale costumes are pressed and checked for broken beads. Different dressers _ the show has five _ have ``bead-in'' calls to go over the finale costumes to replace beads. ``That costume has become a symbol of what Broadway is,'' Gilbert says. Director Michael Bennett originally asked Aldredge for red finale clothes, similar to what he had used in ``Follies,'' but she came up with her own unique design. ``It is based on everything being reflected,'' Gilbert says. ``Everything shines. The fabrics. The shoes. The men's are patent leather, the women's are satin. The beads are glass. When the light hits those clothes, they look gold. They look silver. They look white. It's amazing what vanishes from them in terms of wear.'' During the day, Gilbert deals with whatever has to be replaced or repaired. Toward evening, the stage manager wanders by and announces who will be on stage that night. ``A Chorus Line'' is a show in which understudies get a chance to perform frequently. That means hauling out finale costumes for the replacement dancers. About a half hour before curtain, the five dressers come in. The dancewear has been separated onto hangers, one costume to a hanger, and sent to the dressing rooms. While the musical starts, the finale costumes are set on racks at the side of the stage for the evening's splashy closing number. During the show, Gilbert and the dressers fuss with the costume worn by Cassie, the lead female dancer, and then get ready for the finale. When the dressers go to help with the dancers' finale changes, Gilbert goes, too. She personally hands out the top hats to them. ``You're dealing with 17 people and 17 hats that look the same,'' she says. ``We don't keep the hats with finale costumes because it's dark. It's easy to come up with the wrong hat if you're not focusing on that.'' The process is repeated eight times a week. ``You're in a rather unique position doing wardrobe, particularly in this show,'' says Gilbert, who got her start in 1968 doing shows off-Broadway. ``I've learned that dancers are really so gallant. They can be silly. They can be petty. They can be lots of things. But when they have to go out and dance, there's an extraordinary bravery. ``All dance ever really gives them is the chance to be able to do it. Anything else is extra.'' Gilbert took two 6-month leaves from ``A Chorus Line'' over the years to work on two other Bennett shows, ``Ballroom'' and ``Dreamgirls.'' She always came back. When ``A Chorus Line'' closes, she'll move over to ``Grand Hotel,'' the Tommy Tune musical that has lavish 1920s-style costumes. ``And then there will probably be other shows,'' she adds wistfully.

DOC.HEAD: `Mommy Track' Stigma Still Dogs Felice Schwartz
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: After nearly three decades of bushwhacking trails for women in the male-dominated workplace, Felice N. Schwartz has spent much of the past year fighting accusations she is a traitor. She hasn't capitulated. On the contrary, the dispute with some influential feminists seems to have sharpened. Schwartz is the founder of a prominent corporate consulting firm in Manhattan called Catalyst, which promotes sexual equality at work and was spawned during the feminist movement of the early 1960s. It now is one of the leading advisers on women's issues to large American businesses. Schwartz's connections give her access to the heads of companies ranging from Citibank to Sara Lee Corp. Last year Schwartz hurtled herself into the public eye by writing a widely read article that became associated with the buzzword ``mommy track,'' though she didn't invent the term and has repudiated it many times. She asserted in the article, titled ``Management Women and the New Facts of Life,'' that women's growing role in the work force has forced companies to become more responsive and sensitive to their needs to attract and retain the most talented. But the article, published in the January-February 1989 issue of Harvard Business Review, created an uproar among women. It was perceived as distinguishing two paths for management women, a fast one for the strictly career-driven and childless and a slower dead-end route for those who want to raise families. Other well-known women activists quickly distanced themselves from Schwartz and accused her of giving companies an excuse to put women down after many years of steady advances. They said her assertions amounted to a stark choice between career and family, reinforced sexual stereotypes and assumed the burden of child-rearing remained strictly a woman's domain. Schwartz, a 65-year-old grandmother and tough-talking corporate executive in her own right, has rejected those accusations, blaming them partly on misunderstandings and distortions of her position. She has faced the criticism with a mixture of defiance, anguish, frustration and humility, debating her feminist adversaries and articulating her position hundreds of times in speeches and interviews. ``The purpose of that article was to encourage corporate leaders to make progress in assimilating women at every level of management and to remove barriers to their advancement,'' she said at a conference in January, for example. ``I wrote of the need for employers to revise their thinking, their policies and their practices in order to meet the needs of employees who choose to combine work and family.'' Having to explain herself more than a year later shows how difficult the ``mommy track'' stigma has been to dislodge. Nonetheless, Schwartz said in an interview, she would not change a word of the article or where she chose to publish it. ``I wanted the Harvard Business Review because I wanted to reach corporate leaders. This was not an article for women,'' she said. ``I did not write the article for Good Housekeeping, Ms. or Working Woman.'' But the article provoked such concern from women that Harvard Business Review sold 11,000 reprints. Schwartz was besieged with press requests from women's magazines and foreign journalists from Venezuela to Australia. She did 75 interviews in two months, often encountering what she called the same misinterpretations of her arguments. Many times, she spent much of the time denying and disavowing the ``mommy track'' idea. Schwartz said her patience finally expired during a broadcast with a West Coast radio station, when she exploded at her interviewer because the woman admitted she hadn't read the article. ``That was a catharsis,'' she said. In some ways, the controversy has further enhanced her influence, which has grown steadily since she founded Catalyst in 1962 as a research and consulting service to help women re-enter the work force after raising families, something she did herself after taking an eight-year break to raise three children. In the past year, speaking invitations have multiplied from colleges, institutes and business conferences, Schwartz said. She said women ranging from MBA candidates to CIA employees have approached her with positive comments. ``I'm absolutely euphoric. It's opened discussion to issues that had been submerged,'' she said. ``What I want to do is encourage honesty and openness.'' Many influential professional women have expressed admiration for Schwartz's ability to reach into male-dominated corporate bastions so boldly, though they have mixed feelings about what she says. ``I think what she did was very good because it brought the issue to the table,'' said Deborah Biondolillo, vice president of human resources for the computer company Apple USA. ``I didn't happen to agree with her solutions.'' Schwartz has failed to appease her most vociferous critics, prominent feminists who think her approach is misguided, elitist, arrogant and destructive. Many still believe she has perpetuated the ``mommy track'' idea despite her denials. ``Her article was a very dangerous retrogression and acquiescence to sex discrimination,'' said Betty Friedan, a co-founder of the National Organization for Women and author of ``The Feminine Mystique,'' considered one of the most important books about the women's movement. ``I have not changed one iota in my mind my outrage at Felice Schwartz,'' Friedan said. ``She is simply not a feminist, not committed to equality. She has an employer mentality.'' Even some less militant proponents of women's rights are concerned that Schwartz has hurt their efforts to obtain professional parity with men. Some say she has further isolated herself by suggesting women disclose at job interviews whether they plan to have children. ``Women are still getting fired from their jobs when they're pregnant. I don't know why she thinks we have that kind of protection,'' said Judsen Culbreth, editor of Working Mother magazine. ``Putting this burden on women is just such backward thinking, just such 1950s, man-in-the-pinstripe-suit-type thinking,'' Culbreth said. ``I don't think she's meant to do this, but it particularly does damage to working mothers, who are going to have this question mark raised now in the minds of so many corporations.'' Both Schwartz and her critics have said the discussion is helpful. Still, Schwartz said, ``I am sure there are still lots of women who think I'm their enemy. That's painful after 27 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Money Shortage Produces Courage Deficit
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may not believe in his lofty poll ratings, but the Democrats seem to, and that is keeping them cautious _ or maybe timid. That's a label they have tried to affix to Bush, who says the correct description of his style is prudent. Call it timidity, or caution, or prudence, the tag applies on Capitol Hill as at the White House. While Democrats complain that Bush is trying to avoid politically risky positions, most of them are doing the same thing. They just aren't as visible. With Bush riding high in the popularity polls, their challenges usually are safe, rhetorical and standard. There are exceptions. Three leading Democrats in Congress have proposed three controversial policy and budget moves so far this year. None has drawn broad support at the top or among the re-election-bent rank and file members of the party that controls both House and Senate. Any or all of the three could serve as high-visibility rallying points for the opposition party. But they got faint praise and no endorsement from Democratic congressional leaders. The latest Democratic initiative is Rep. Dan Rostenkowski's budget balancing proposal, a combination of spending cut and tax increases he called ``both bold and balanced.'' It's all of that, a compromise that would compel each party to swallow some unpleasant medicine. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley warily described the Rostenkowski plan as very important and interesting. But he isn't going to risk leading Democrats into tax increases Bush could block and blame on them. The president said he was prepared to negotiate on the Rostenkowski proposal although he opposes some of its features, especially the tax boosts and a year's freeze on cost of living increases in Social Security. At the start of the congressional session, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed a cut in Social Security taxes that would give wave earners an election-year break while drawing down the trust fund reserves that mask the true size of the federal deficit. ``If we can't get behind an issue like this ... I'm not sure who needs the Democratic Party,'' Moynihan said as his proposal faded for lack of party support. That one clearly worried the White House, since the Democrats could have used it to force him into vetoing an election-year tax cut. Bush called it a subterfuge for a later tax increase and said it would put future social security benefits at risk. Early this month, Rep. Richard A. Gephardt, D-Mo., the House majority leader, combined a call for increased aid to Eastern Europe and direct aid to the Soviet Union with a denunciation of Bush for what he said was a lack of vision and leadership. The White House counterattacked with ridicule. ``I don't want to knock the man,'' Bush said last week. ``Maybe he'll come up with a good idea one of these days.'' Gephardt's aid proposal was swallowed in the political controversy. Praising all three idea men, Rep. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., told the House last week that ``they are driving the White House and the Republicans crazy.'' ``It is the U.S. Congress that is more often than not providing the leadership in today's government,'' he claimed. Or talking about it. Leadership takes more than proposals and speeches, it takes action, even if that involves a political risk. The Rostenkowski plan does. The Illinois Democrat, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said it asks ``for modest sacrifices by all Americans'' to balance the budget beginning in 1993. And each party would have to sacrifice some pet planks in its political platform. Should either balk, the compromise would collapse and budget stalemates would persist. Rostenkowski proposes a real freeze on federal spending for one year, including cost-of-living increases in Social Security, a 3 percent cut in military spending with the savings to go into deficit reduction and not new programs, an increase in top bracket income taxes and in oil and other consumption taxes. The tradeoffs would require each party to yield some pet issues, with Democrats dropping their refrain that Republicans are a threat to Social Security benefits, and with the GOP dropping its tax-and-spend charges against the Democrats. For the Rostenkowski package to get anywhere, the blame would have to be shared. That would take a level of trust that isn't showing now. Democrats are leery, seeing the ingredients of a setup in which the White House would negotiate on the plan, then reject a tax increase and accuse them, again, of being the tax-and-spend party. Foley said Bush must back off his no-new-taxes pledge in advance of any deal. ``The president has an absolute veto on this question,'' he said. Gephardt and Rostenkowski both said Bush ought to be willing to risk some of his political capital to take the lead in dealing with budget and deficit stalemates. ``I don't live by the polls,'' Bush replied. He questioned whether there was all that much popularity to be spent anyhow. ``I don't believe in it, is one thing,'' he said at a news conference. ``I don't believe in polls that much. ... These things come and go.''

DOC.TEXT: As they say, fact is stranger than fiction. Indeed no one could make up some of the things uttered by world figures in recent days. Herewith a wry look by a reporter not intimidated by world figures.

It comes to this. If Mikhail Gorbachev's thinking prevails, history will belong to the accountants. The Soviet Union took little Lithuania illegally half a century ago. Now, says the Soviet president, if Lithuania secedes, it will owe Mother Russia $33 billion in hard currency, mostly to pay for capital investment. That's like the warden dunning a departing prisoner for back rent. Leaving out interest compounded over 125 years, wouldn't the same logic entitle the government in Washington to demand billions from Mississippi, Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas, South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, Tennessee and Arkansas for their four years of secession? South Carolina has yet to pay a nickel for the holes it ripped in Fort Sumter. If Gorbachev is right, doesn't it follow that Zaire owes Belgium a bundle for all the time it was the Belgian Congo? In fact, won't most of Africa be forever in the debt of most of Europe for taking the trouble to colonize the continent? And, finally, would the heirs of the late King George III begin to get ideas about those impudent 13 colonies that left his bed and board 200 years ago? The possibilities boggle, and that goes with the changing territory these days. Years in costly research, the SR-71 Blackbird spy plane was retired because of budget cuts. On its last flight, it smashed all coast-to-coast records flying from California to Washington in 68 minutes, 17 seconds, which is faster than many commuters on both coasts can make it from home to office. Two old soul mates, whose palship once brought the world to the edge of nuclear war, now keep moving further apart. Fidel Castro complained that the Kremlin was undercutting world communism by ``slandering socialism, destroying its values, discrediting the party and liquidating its leading role, doing away with social discipline and sowing chaos and anarchy everywhere.'' The Moscow News counterattacked: ``Cuban women are in no danger of replacing revolutionary consciousness with mercenary spirit as long as they are allowed a choice of one bra or two pairs of underwear (but not both, and only the size available at the moment). ``The administrative and economic model Cuba copied was ours, imitated at a time when European socialism was drowning in a bog of stagnation.'' Translation: Just because you were dumb enough to copy us is no reason we should stick to a sinking ship. For days people wondered what a joint session of Congress was applauding when it heard President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia say: ``Consciousness precedes being and not the other way around, as the Marxists claim.'' The air was finally cleared by letters to the editor of the Washington Post from seasoned students of government: ``It was quite obvious to me that Havel was saying, `Hopefully, the parameters of being are impacted subsequent to consciousness. Basically, the infrastructure of the two will result in a meaningful relationship in the ongoing preplanning based on past experience.''' And: ``I have it on good authority that what Congress thought it heard when Havel said `consciousness precedes being' was `Confucious precedes Beijing.''' And: ``Congress was obviously itching to break for lunch when it applauded so hard upon hearing Havel proclaim that `nacho chips precede beans.''' And in these unpredictable times, the fathers of June brides were forewarned by the New York Times that caterers, dress makers and florists can sue and collect for late cancellations.''

DOC.HEAD: Mild Winter Could Mean Drought
DOC.TEXT: This year's mild winter could come back to haunt Americans in the form of a drought, the National Weather Service said Thursday. The March hydrological outlook, usually an annual report on potential for spring flooding from snowmelt, this year is more a chronicle of missing snow and dry soil conditions. Unless heavy precipitation occurs, the return of drought to major areas of the nation is imminent, the report said. Drought plagued much of the nation in the hot summer of 1988, easing somewhat last year. Pockets of dryness have persisted, however. Serious water-supply problems are a distinct possibility for much of California as well as in the Great Basin, lower Colorado, parts of the Rio Grande and in western and southern Texas, the weather service reported. Low stream flow, low soil moisture and low spring flood potential also cover a large area of the north central states, the report said. Parts of many central and western states have experienced abnormally dry conditions for two to four years, resulting on dry conditions deep in the soil. The threat of snowmelt flooding, meanwhile, is limited to small areas of the country. Flood threat is above normal in a strip of northwestern Montana and northeastern Idaho. But snow cover in the eastern two-thirds of the country is minimal and where there is snow it is below average, except in northern Maine and northern Michigan. Some portions of the central states have reported high streamflows. A notable exception to the dry conditions is in south-central Alaska, which has had a record snowfall. The melt there is still weeks away, but that is a region where ice jams have created flood danger in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Production Down
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 219,410 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 223,014, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 248,022 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 135,390 cars this week, compared with 136,330 a week ago and 152,572 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 84,020, compared with last week's 86,684 and last year's 95,450. Canadian automakers were to build 28,481 cars this week, up from 26,590 a week ago and from last year's 20,195. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 21,529, compared with 21,473 a week ago and 17,324 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Close Ties Between Name and Business Can Be Treacherous
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Parc in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: What's in a name? For Donald Trump, an awful lot. The developer has wrapped moniker and business empire so closely they have become one big, glitzy package of Trump this, Trump that. But his recent marriage problems show how building a business on a name can be risky if the name becomes the object of ridicule. The name Trump, a symbol of the big-spending 1980s, is synonymous with conspicuous wealth. High rollers play in his Trump Castle and Trump Plaza casinos in Atlantic City, N.J.; urban sophisticates live in $4 million condos in Trump Palace or Trump Parc in Manhattan; executives fly the Trump Shuttle between New York, Boston or Washington. The late publishing tycoon Malcolm Forbes and cable television titan Ted Turner also built namesake empires around their own star quality. But perhaps more than anyone, Trump's personality and business have kept his face in front of the cameras and his name in front of the public. Trump ``has done a magnificent job of building himself up,'' said Jack Trout, president of Trout & Ries, a marketing consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn. ``Unfortunately, when you live by the press, you can die by the press.'' Trump normally basks in media attention but has said he hates the splashy publicity about his breakup with wife and business partner Ivana. Even so, he insists that his business has benefited from the screaming tabloid headlines, an assertion that some Trump critics find even more repulsive. ``There's something demeaning and vile about his trumpeting that his marital situation is adding to his business,'' former New York mayor Edward I. Koch _ a longtime Trump antagonist _ said in a telephone interview. ``To me, it's incredible that he would denigrate Ivana Trump.'' Some believe the publicity swirling around Ivana, Donald and alleged mistress Marla Maples has hurt Trump's business. ``He's becoming a joke,'' Trout said. ``For a serious brand, that can be a big problem.'' ``You have to handle yourself extremely well, because you are putting yourself as a person front and center,'' the consultant said. ``You've got to be very careful with your reputation ... You can't do stupid things.'' Forbes, on the other hand, was careful and consistent about his image, Trout said. His divorce from wife Roberta, for example, occurred quietly. Forbes's sons, of course, face another kind of famous-name challenge as a result of his death last month at age 70. They must run the publishing empire they have inherited without the man who gave it character. Eldest son Malcolm Jr., known as Steve, is a bookish fellow who admits that he can't exactly follow in his father's madcap footsteps. ``I am certainly not going to try to imitate him,'' he told the Wall Street Journal in a recent interview. ``He would be disappointed if I tried to.'' While the late Forbes had a passion for motorcycling, hot air balloons and partying, bashful Steve, 43, collects presidential papers and manuscripts. Rather than clip his wings as Trump is advised to do by critics, Steve Forbes may need to let loose a little. Turner, head of a $600 million cable TV empire, seems already to have learned the lesson of handling a personal name-brand carefully. ``Is he a flamboyant character? Yes. He's had a very checkered career,'' said Gordon Crawford, an analyst with Capital Research Co. in Los Angeles who follows Turner's companies. ``He's also created the most valuable group of cable properties in the world.'' Turner, who successfully piloted his yacht to the America's Cup in 1977, has been called ``Captain Outrageous'' and the ``Mouth of the South.'' Between 1986 and 1987, he plunged his business $1.4 billion into debt, lost another $25 million on the Goodwill Games, separated from his wife and lost his house in a fire. Some say Turner seems to have mellowed, although his reference last year to abortion foes as ``idiots'' and ``Bozos'' drew wide publicity, as well as the ire of pro-lifers. ``He's becoming Mr. Corporate Statesperson; he's mellowing out,'' Trout said, noting that Turner's demeanor is now considerably less brash.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers to Review Oil Market
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers began gathering Thursday to review current oil market conditions and decide whether to revise the group's price and production policies. Ministers from Libya, Venezuela, Ecuador and Kuwait were among the early arrivals for Friday's meeting of a special panel of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. In advance of the talks, analysts predicted the ministers of the 13 oil-producing nations would not revise the price and supply guidelines set late last year. Ecuador's oil minister, Diego Tamariz, said, ``We will analyze the situation of the market and on that basis decide what to do in the second quarter of the year.'' He said the officials would study projections for demand and supply of OPEC crude oil in the April-June period before adjusting the production ceiling. Whether they change it or not, he said, ``all depends on the outcome of the analysis.'' Last November, the ministers set a production limit of about 22 million barrels of crude a day for the first six months of the year. It had been fixed at 20.5 million barrels in the last quarter of 1989. But several OPEC countries, led by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, are together pumping at least a million barrels a day above the cap, according to analysts. Despite surging production, prices have remained above the cartel's target of $18 a barrel due to strong worldwide demand and declining production by the United States and other non-OPEC producers. Prices are expected to soften along with demand in coming months, however, as temperatures warm in the United States and other major consuming countries. In recent weeks, several ministers have privately pressed for changes in the cartel's price and production targets. But they appeared to have drawn little support from others. Iraq's minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, was reportedly anxious to have a higher reference price. Kuwait's Ali Khalifa al-Sabah suggested in the Middle East Economic Survey that the quota system should be scrapped. He said it was unrealistic and often ignored by members. But, when asked in Vienna whether his idea would get much attention, he quipped, ``No, we need our security blanket.'' The formula used by the cartel starts with an overall output ceiling then each country is allotted a quota based largely on capacity. Without a quota, each member could produce freely. Sabah was quoted recently as saying his country did not have to go along with a quota when prices were above the $18 mark. Tamariz, asked about the overproduction, said OPEC needed to look at the different needs of its members. ``There has to be some room for flexibility,'' he said. Formal talks by OPEC's monitoring committee are scheduled to begin Friday evening. Only eight ministers are officially members of the panel, but all 13 OPEC ministers are expected to attend. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Says Dollar's Recent Rise Should Not Hurt Trade Picture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to include Bjt slug.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Thursday he does not believe the recent rise in the value of the dollar will adversely affect the nation's trade deficit this year. ``I hear a lot of talk about the dollar climbing,'' he told reporters after a speech to the National Newspaper Association. ``But if you go back over the last year and a half and look at it over that period of time, what you'll see is stability _ some days up, some days down. ``But you just go back and look at it since the beginning of 1988, you'll find we've had a stable dollar and that's what we've tried to achieve,'' he continued. ``We've had stability and stablility is what we strive for in all markets, markets that people can rely on.'' A stronger dollar could cause the nation's trade deficit to widen because it would make imported goods cheaper while increasing the price of U.S. products sold overseas. The Commerce Department reported Tuesday that the gap in the current account balance, the broadest measure of U.S. trade, narrowed to $105.9 billion last year, a 16 percent reduction from 1988. The reduction was due in part to an improvement in the balance of trade in the fourth quarter that came largely from a decline in the vaue of the dollar. The dollar has been strengthening in recent weeks, however. In his speech to the newspaper association, Brady renewed his call for a single market linking trades of stocks, stock options and stock index futures. The Securities and Exchange Commission now has jurisdiction over stocks and stock options, while the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is responsible for markets handling stock index futures. ``The sharp stock market decline of October 1987,'' he said, ``demonstrated dramatically how these markets, all operating by their own sets of rules, can interact to stimulate excessive volatility and reinforce the downward spiral.'' Brady noted that most overseas markets place regulation of all three in the hands of one regualator and said U.S. markets also could benefit greatly by ending the fragmented control. Without endorsing any approach, Brady mentioned three ways of achieving unified control. They were to merge the SEC and CFTC, give the SEC jurisdiction over all futures except those related to tangible commodities or shift stock index futures alone to the SEC. ``Many have recommended full merger as the most straightforward and the course chosen by countries abroad,'' he said. ``There are perhaps arguments in favor of the other approaches as well. What's important is that we get something done, and get it done now.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher

DOC.HEAD: In The Shadow of Drexel and Campeau, Smaller Companies Struggle
With BC-Debt Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Interco Corp. was a manufacturing and retailing conglomerate in 1988, turning out well-known brands of clothes, shoes and furniture and taking in more than $3 billion in sales a year. Today the company is a shadow of its former self, saddled with debts following a $2.8 billion recapitalization. The company is trying to cut deals with bankers while seeking buyers for its assets. Doskocil Cos., a food processor that took over the larger Wilson Foods Corp. in 1988, filed recently for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Doskocil bought Wilson for $133 million, assumed millions of dollars in Wilson's debts, then defaulted on a loan. The company, like Interco, has had trouble selling assets, and its lower-than-expected income hasn't been enough to pay bills. These companies aren't as well known as investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert or retailer Campeau Corp., both forced into bankruptcy court recently by credit problems. They are nonetheless casualties of the debt-dominated 1980s. Interco once made a broad array of products ranging from Converse sneakers to Ethan Allen dining sets. It did not go into debt by choice but rather to thwart a hostile takeover by a pair of unfriendly Washington investors. The company borrowed $2 billion to pay shareholders a special dividend and expected to foot the bill partly through asset sales. But Interco also expected business to be stronger than it turned out to be. Although divisions like Ethan Allen went fast, it hasn't been easy to sell some of its other businesses that are still on the block. Like most companies, Interco also did not anticipate the collapse of the junk bond market last year and the new caution toward acquisitions that followed. That caution has made banks more reluctant to lend money and would-be acquirers more hesitant about taking on new debt to buy other businesses. This has left companies like Interco strapped because they need cash. Robert Raiff, who follows Interco for C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., blames the company's lack of foresight for its problems. ``They're in a position that long-term won't allow them to operate without a very major restructuring of the debt,'' Raiff said. Interco wants to retain its Converse and Florsheim footwear manufacturers and Broyhill and Lane furniture companies as core businesses. The company recently persuaded lenders to relax the terms of a $244.5 million bridge loan payment. But even when that payment is made _ it is due in May _ Interco still will have a heavy debt burden. Doskocil's story is a case of a company going too heavily into debt to take over another company, then getting socked for higher raw materials prices _ in Doskocil's case, hogs _ and a tighter availability of credit. The company went $240 million into debt to buy Wilson Foods, expecting to repay part of that by selling assets. But like Interco, Doskocil has found it is no longer easy to find buyers, especially buyers who can get financing. The company recently reported assets of $474.1 million and liabilities of $414.1 million. Under Chapter 11, it has bought time to reorganize and try to stay in business.

DOC.HEAD: Salomon Acquiring Shearson Unit for $28 Million
DOC.TEXT: In another move to scale back operations, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. agreed Thursday to sell its mutual fund and individual investment services division to Salomon Inc. for $28 million. The sale of Lehman Management Co., which has about $2.6 billion of assets under management, will more than double the size of Salomon's money management operation. Salomon spokeswoman Macy W. Egerton said the firm now manages $2.2 billion. Lehman Management, known on Wall Street as Lemco, manages five equity mutual funds and more than 550 accounts for institutions and wealthy individuals. Shearson is expected to leave several business lines this year as part of an overhaul under parent American Express Co. Shearson is laying off 2,000 employees this month and has said it will focus on its core retail brokerage, investment banking, capital markets and asset management. The sale completes a dismantling of Lemco. Last August, Lemco sold its institutional money management business to a group of Shearson managers for $100 million. Shearson took a 10 percent stake in the new company, Lehman-Ark Management Co., which had $14 billion in assets under management. After the sale, Lemco was changed from a wholly owned Shearson subsidiary into a division of the firm. Shearson officials said the firm wanted to integrate the remaining parts of Lemco into its $93 billion money management businesses, but had difficulty doing so. Discussions on selling the unit began last November, they said. ``Shearson's overall commitment to its asset management business remains unchanged,'' spokesman Steven Faigen said. He said the sale was ``in line with the overall strategic focus'' in restructuring Shearson. Almost all of the 45 investment and research professionals and other employees of Lehman Management will become employees of Salomon Brothers Asset Management, the companies said. ``We are delighted to have the talented and experienced investment staff of Lehman Management join us,'' John H. Gutfreund, Salomon Inc.'s chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. After the deal is completed, the names of Lehman Corp., Lehman Investors Fund Inc., Lehman Capital Fund Inc., and Lehman Opportunity Fund Inc. will be changed to Salomon Brothers Fund Inc., Salomon Brothers Investment Fund Inc., Salomon Brothers Capital Fund Inc., and Salomon Brothers Opportunity Fund Inc., respectively. Salomon Brothers Asset Management, the subsidiary acquiring the Shearson unit, also will act as an investment adviser to the fifth company, SLH Growth and Opportunity Portfolio, which will remain part of the SLH Equity Portfolio. Shearson said assets in the funds total about $1.7 billion, while those in the institutional and individual accounts total $869 million. The acquisition must be approved by the boards of directors and shareholders of the five investment companies, the firms said.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Secretary Disappointed At Lack of Progress In Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Failure by the United States and Japan to act soon to eliminate trade barriers and strengthen their economies raises dangers to the entire global trading system, U.S. Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher said Thursday. ``If we do not act soon, we may throw away our last chance to save the world trading system from serious damage,'' Mosbacher told reporters at the Japan National Press Club. The two countries are negotiating greater market access in Japan for U.S. satellites, lumber and supercomputers, and the elimination of structural impediments to balanced trade in both nations. As Mosbacher described a ``sense of urgency'' in ongoing trade talks between the two countries, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other government leaders appeared ready to propose changes in Japan's economic structure that could reduce Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Local news reports said Kaifu held an emergency meeting late Wednesday with three key Cabinet ministers and set a weekend deadline for detailed measures for removing structural trade barriers. Mosbacher was dispatched to Tokyo by President George Bush to follow up on Bush's meeting with Kaifu in Palm Springs, California, earlier in the month. In another sticky trade issue, U.S. rice growers brought their campaign to open Japan's rice market to Tokyo. But a government agency ordered the removal of a small amount of U.S. rice displayed at an international food exhibition in Chiba, southwest of Tokyo. Food Agency officials said the display violated the Food Control Law, which prohibits rice imports for sale in Japan. Japan has said it needs to maintain self-sufficiency in rice to protect food security. Mosbacher told reporters he was ``extremely disappointed'' that satellite negotiations ended Tuesday in Washington without major progress. ``It is critical that we resolve this,'' he said. The United States, a world leader in satellites technology, wants Japan to purchase U.S. satellites. Japan says it wants to nurture its fledgling satellite industry. ``It's hard to believe this great nation, which produces so many goods so well, has to protect an infant industry,'' Mosbacher said. In addition to reducing barriers to specific products, the United States is urging Japan to undertake structural economic reforms, such as deregulation of its retail distribution system, reduction of land prices, and increases in public works spending. The United States, as part of an ``eight-point agenda for competitiveness,'' has pledged to boost research and development funds, reform its education system, reduce its budget deficit, and reform antitrust and product liability regulations. While noting progress in shrinking the U.S. trade deficits with other countries and in reducing the U.S. budget deficit, Mosbacher said ``Japan's overall trade surplus with America _ and the world _ has achieved a semi-permanent status.'' Mosbacher also was to host a meeting of five major Japanese semiconductor users to encourage them to increase their purchases of U.S. computer chips. U.S. makers have a 12.9 percent share of the Japanese market but are aiming at a 20 percent share. In speeches Thursday, Mosbacher said Japan was obligated to boost the U.S. share of the market to 20 percent by 1991, under a 1986 agreement between the two nations. Japanese government officials and producers maintain such a promise could not be assured in a free-market economy and that in the agreement Japan merely recognized the U.S. desire to reach a 20 percent share. During his four-day visit to Tokyo, Mosbacher also met with Kaifu, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, Trade Minister Kabun Muto and officials of the country's top business group, the Federation of Economic Organizations, or Keidanren.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela To Announce Debt Pact, Finance Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela is expected to announce Friday an agreement with creditor banks to reduce by up to 30 percent of its public-sector foreign debt, Finance Minister Roberto Pocaterra said. Pocaterra said late Wednesday that after a year of negotiations, the agreement will ``very possibly'' be Friday despite President Carlos Andres Perez's absence from the country. Perez is in Brasil, attending the inauguration of Fernando Collor de Mello. ``The reduction should be between 25- and 30 percent, almost double what Mexico got,'' said Pocaterra. The agreement would affect the $20.5 billion public-sector restructured debt. Venezuela's overall foreign debt totals $37 billion, the fourth largest in Latin America. Until now, banks had been unenthusiastic about reducing Venezuela's debt, pointing to its oil income as a sign of its ability to pay. Oil exports, which account for more that 90 percent of Venezuela's foreign exchange earnings, are expected to top $10 billion this year, compared to last year's $9.49 billion. Venezuela suspended capital payments last year, and is behind on interest installments. According to a government report, Venezuela expects to reduce its public debt by $11.2 billion by 1992. It has already signed up credits through 1993 amounting to $12.8 billion to finance its debt reduction plan. The report said Venezuela had presented the following options to the bank advisory commitee in New York, which represents 460 creditor banks: direct debt repurchase, with a 60 percent discount; two types of zero coupon bonds, including one with a 35 percent discount on debt face value; and new loans. Once an agreement is announced, banks will have four months to choose among the alternatives. In February, Mexico signed an agreement that cut its $48.5 billion debt to commercial banks by some $7 billion. Banks were given three options: reduce debt capital by 35 percent, cut interest rate to a fixed 6.25 percent or offer new loans equivalent to 25 percent of their outsanding loans to Mexico. About 40 percent of creditor banks opted for capital reduction, 50 percent chose interest rate reduction, and the remaining 10 percent granted new loans.

DOC.HEAD: Luxury Train Expands Schedule to Include New York and Philly
DOC.TEXT: A luxury train that pampers riders with seven-course meals and live entertainment is adding New York and Philadelphia to its schedule, operators of the American-European Express said Thursday. The Chicago-based company, which initiated thrice-weekly service between Chicago and Washington in November, also announced package deals with United Airlines and several hotels. And it said it plans to develop an even more exclusive ``executive'' class representing ``the finest environment that railroading has ever seen.'' American-European Express Inc. will begin twice-weekly service between Chicago and New York with a stop in Philadelphia on May 3, its president, William F. Spann, said in a statement. One-way fares between Chicago and New York will range from $517 to $775, depending on the size of the cabin, the company said. One-way fares between Chicago and Philadelphia will run from $492 to $750, the same as on the Chicago-Washington route. The package deals allow travelers to take the train one way, stay overnight at a luxury hotel and fly back on United Airlines at reduced rates. Each American-European Express train consists of three sleeper cars, a dining car and a club car that are connected to Amtrak passenger trains. Spann said the company was buying another sleeper car, diner car and an observation car for each of its trains to create the new executive class.

DOC.HEAD: Hadley Named Chief Operating Officer, Viewed as Successor to Krumm
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Maytag Corp. executive Leonard Hadley on Thursday was named to the newly created position of chief operating officer of the international appliance maker, a promotion that makes him a likely eventual successor for Maytag's chairman, Daniel Krumm. ``By creating this position, we are strengthening our management structure for the future,'' Krumm said. ``Len's appointment to his new post is a reflection of not only his considerable achievements, but of the confidence we have in him as Maytag moves into the decade of the '90s.'' Albert Taylor, a securities analyst who follows Maytag for the Chicago firm Duff & Phelps, said the appointment was no surprise. ``Hadley has been a longtime Maytag man and has a good reputation at the company,'' Taylor said. ``It also sets the stage for Hadley to be the likely successor for Dan Krumm.'' Krumm will turn 64 later this year. Hadley is 55. Maytag, based in the central Iowa community of Newton, expanded last year with the acquisition of the Hoover line of floor care products, and reported earnings of $131.5 million on sales of $3.09 billion in 1989. But the international expansion has created problems for the company, which had a 24.3 percent slide in its fourth-quarter 1989 profit as a result of sluggish British sales and high interest payments on its takeover debt. Hadley was executive vice president for Maytag and president of its appliance group, which includes Admiral, Hardwick, Jenn-Air, Magic Chef, Maytag and Norge brands. Hadley will continue to oversee North American appliance operations, including the Maycor appliance parts and service subsidiary. He also will assume responsibility for the Dixie-Narco group, which specializes in soft drink vending equipment and supplies leading syrup companies at home and abroad. Frank Vaughn, an executive vice president who reports to Krumm, continues to head Maytag's Hoover group. Hadley has been an executive vice president since February 1989 and was named head of the appliance group last June. The native of Earlham holds an accounting degree from the University of Iowa and joined Maytag as a cost accountant in 1959. He has been a member of the board of directors since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Retailing Company Joins Saks Management in Buyout Proposal
With AM-Saks Facts
DOC.TEXT: The management of Saks Fifth Avenue, in partnership with a Japanese retailer, has offered to buy the upscale department store chain from its London-based parent BAT Industries PLC, it was announced Thursday. Terms of the proposal were not disclosed. Saks management said in a news release that the joint bid with Tobu Department Store Co. Ltd. was fully financed and spokesman Peter Rosenthal would not elaborate. Arthur Martinez, a senior American executive of BAT, said in an interview that the offer is one of several that have been submitted for Saks. He declined to identify the other bidders or disclose amounts offered. But he said the company is pleased with the quantity and quality of the proposals. The initial bids are being reviewed and the list of suitors will be shortened. General Cinema Corp., owner of The Neiman Marcus Group of stores, previously has been reported as a bidder. Final bids will emerge in late April or early May, said Martinez, senior vice president in charge of retail operations for BATUS Inc., BAT's U.S. holding company. Retail industry analysts have said the 46 Saks specialty department stores would fetch a price roughly equal to the chain's annual sales, which totaled about $1.3 billion in 1989. In the view of many analysts, Saks is the most desirable retail property on the market today. Saks is one of several holdings, including Marshall Field & Co., that BAT put up for sale last year to try to thwart Sir James Goldsmith's hostile $22 billion takeover bid for the British conglomerate. The Saks management buyout plan envisions a global expansion of Saks, which specializes in higher priced designer and ready-to-wear apparel and caters to affluent customers. Current management would oversee operations in the United States while Tokyo-based Tobu would expand Saks in Asia. Eventual expansion into Europe also is planned. Melvin Jacobs, chairman of New York-based Saks, said the idea of branching out overseas has been under consideration for some time. ``Our arrangements with Tobu fulfill the potential for Asia. We believe that the strategic partnership which we have formed with Tobu will ensure management's continued attention to serving the needs of the U.S. consumer while providing an opportunity to expand Saks into Asia,'' Jacobs said. He said Saks management also intends to ``forge a similar strategic alliance for Europe.'' Makoto Nezu, executive vice president of Tobu, said, ``As America's leading luxury store, Saks is in a class by itself, and for some time we have been discussing the possibility of working together outside the United States.'' Tobu, part of a big Japanese conglomerate, is in the midst of a major expansion, including work on a new flagship store in the north of Tokyo. If the joint bid succeeds, a substantial portion of the new store will be used to introduce Saks to Japanese shoppers. Saks, founded in 1924 and bought by BAT in 1973, operates 46 stores in 20 states and employs about 12,000 people. Its flagship store, which is being expanded, is located on Fifth Avenue in mid-town Manhattan. Additional Saks stores will be opened in Denver in August and in Portland, Ore., in September. A new store in Chicago, to replace the one there since 1929, will be opened later this year. BAT, with interests in tobacco, retailing, paper, insurance and other financial services, last year decided to dispose of an estimated $6.6 billion in assets in an effort to fend off an unwanted takeover bid from Hoylake Investment Ltd. Martinez said several bids also have been submitted for Marshall Field's and final proposals are expected for that 24-store chain in the spring. Final offers already are in for BAT's Breuners, a West Coast furniture and home furnishings chain, Martinez said. Final proposals are expected shortly for Ivey's, a regional department store chain mostly in the South. The proposed takeover of BAT by Hoylake, a group led by the Anglo-French financier Goldsmith, has been under scrutiny by British and American regulators. U.S. state insurance regulators are looking at the proposed deal closely because of BAT's ownership of Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles. The bid has been suspended pending the outcome of the regulators' review.

DOC.HEAD: BAT Reports Progress in Defensive Strategy Against Goldsmith Bid
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC reported progress Thursday in its defensive strategy against a hostile bid, saying the sales of its U.S. stores should be completed by June and announcing the terms for the spinoff of a large British retailer. There has been some concern that the British conglomerate would have trouble selling its retailing businesses in the United States because several other major retailers are on the auction block. The $22 billion hostile bid for BAT by Hoylake Investments Ltd., an investment group headed by the Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith, has been suspended pending the outcome of a review by U.S. insurance regulators, expected in the coming months. The U.S. regulators are seeking to determine what impact a change of ownership would have on BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles. BAT's defensive strategy, announced in September, is aimed at enhancing the value of its shares through a major restructuring. The restructuring involves selling off its U.S. retailing businesses, spinning off its Argos retailing business in Britain, combining its British and American paper companies and spinning them off as well, and buying back up to 10 percent of its stock. The company intends to focus on its remaining tobacco and financial services operations. If given the regulatory green light, the Goldsmith group is expected to bid again for BAT, and may even pursue a takeover of what is left of the conglomerate after BAT completes its defensive restructuring. BAT's shares were unchanged at the equivalent of $12.94 apiece on London's Stock Exchange Thursday. Hoylake's suspended offer came to $13.69 a share. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy said the group's restructuring plans, which include the disposal of its U.S. department stores, are ``proceeding well'' and should be completed by June. Management of BAT's Saks Fifth Avenue on Thursday announced a buyout offer for the 46 upscale department stores had been submitted. The Saks management bid, made jointly with a Japanese retailing company, was one of several proposals received. General Cinema Corp. of the United States also has identified itself as a bidder, said a BAT spokesman in London, who declined to be identified. He said other bidders were confidential as were the amounts of the offers. BAT also has received bids for its other U.S. department stores, including the Chicago-based Marshall Field's stores, the spokesman said. BAT said it would turn Argos, the British toy, jewelry and electronics retailer, into an independent, publicly held company by giving existing BAT shareholders one new Argos share for every five BAT shares they hold. Trading in the new Argos shares is scheduled to begin April 6, pending approval of the move by shareholders at an April 5 meeting, BAT said. Argos, with 254 outlets, had after-tax profit of $99 million in 1988, the most recent year for which information is available, on sales of $1.2 billion. BAT said it would announce in mid-May the terms for the spinoff of the combination of its paper businesses, Appleton of the United States and Wiggins Teape of Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Specialty Department Store Chain Founded in 1924
DOC.TEXT: Saks Fifth Avenue's management and Japan's Tobu Department Store Co. Ltd. Thursday said they submitted a joint buyout proposal for the 46-store chain. Here is a brief history of Saks: _ Saks was the brainchild of Horace Saks and Bernard Gimbel, who independently operated stores in New York City in the early part of this century. The two merchants decided to open a fashionable specialty department store catering to the carriage trade. The store on Fifth Avenue opened Sept. 15, 1924. _ From 1924 to 1969, Saks expanded and built a national recognition as an upscale retailer, mainly of fashionable apparel. _ Bernard Gimbel's cousin, Adam, became president after the sudden death of Horace Saks in 1926. Under Adam Gimbel, branch stores were opened and the flagship Manhattan store was redecorated in the opulent Art Moderne style from the 1925 Paris Exposition. _ Adam Gimbel retired as Saks president in 1969. At the time, there were 21 Saks stores. _ Saks in 1973 was bought by BATUS Inc., the U.S. holding company of the London-based conglomerate BAT Indusries PLC. _ Under BAT's ownership Saks has grown to include 46 stores, operating in 33 markets in 20 states. States in which there are Saks stores include Arizona, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Louisana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Texas and Virginia. _ The flagship Fifth Avenue store was proclaimed a New York City landmark in 1985. _ BAT announced in September 1989 plans to sell Saks, its other retailing operations plus certain other assets as part of a strategy to thwart an unsolicited takeover attempt by an investment group led by the Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. The $22 billion bid for BAT has been suspended pending the outcome of a review by U.S. insurance regulatory agencies, expected in the coming months. _ Saks management announced March 15, 1990 that it has submitted a bid for the chain. The buyout proposal was made jointly with Tobu Department Store Co. Ltd. of Japan. Terms were not disclosed. _ BAT confirmed on March 15 that the management buyout plan is one of several bids submitted for Saks. General Cinema Corp., owner of the Neiman Marcus group of stores, previously has identified itself as a bidder. Final bids are expected by late April or early May, BAT said.
