DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge, Crop Futures Gain On Export Talk
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices posted sharp gains and grain futures closed moderately higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk that the Soviet Union was in the market for more U.S. grain. The late rally in the soybean pit erased much of the losses registered earlier in the week and prompted speculation that prices may have to move even higher to persuade farmers to part with their soybean stocks. ``The daily demand is exceeding the daily supply and we really haven't gotten up to price levels that have stimulated the movement in supply to meet that,'' said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Analysts and traders said rumors of Soviet interest in U.S. corn and soybean meal supported the markets, which had been moving higher for most of the day after bouncing off their opening lows. Speculation that the Brazilian government may impose a new export tax on soybeans and soybean meal sparked further buying, they said. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.84{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 3\ cents higher with March at $2.47 a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.44 a bushel; and soybeans were 7{ cents to 13{ cents higher with March at $5.86 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Announces First Schedule Expansion In Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines on Thursday announced its first schedule expansion in two years, boosting daily flights by 100 to 1,417 and beginning service to Panama, Costa Rica and several U.S. cities. ``We needed to get our arms around our operational difficulties,'' Stan Hula, Continental vice president of schedule development, said of the airline's ``no-growth mode'' in the past two years. ``We think we've got those problems licked. There are a number of things coming together for Continental that is causing us to be able to expand.'' He pointed to Department of Transportation statistics which showed customer complaints about Continental were down 96 percent since 1987 and on-time arrival performance for Continental was the third best among the nation's airlines in 1989. Hula also credited an improvement in Continental's financial condition for the schedule expansion. Although the airline lost $56.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, the loss was $43.1 million less than the October-December period the previous year. For all of 1989, Houston-based Continental, a subsidiary of Texas Air Corp., showed a $3.1 million profit. Twenty-three planes are being added to the Continental fleet, including jets that were bought from sister carrier Eastern Airlines and returned to Continental after being leased to Eastern and Pan Am Corp., Hula said. He had no details on fares on the new flights. ``There will be some pricing initiatives,'' he said. ``We will be very competitive throughout the summer with all of our fares.'' Beginning May 15, Continental will operate flights from Houston to Panama City, Panama, and San Jose, Costa Rica, giving the airline the largest number of U.S. flights to Central America, Hula said. Continental already has flights to Belize, El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras. ``We look to expand in Central America even further as time passes,'' Hula said. ``The changing conditions in Panama obviously make this service possible. The improving political climate has a great deal to do with our interest in Central America.'' In the United States, Continental is starting late-night service out of Houston with a dozen flights leaving at 10:30 p.m. ``These flights bridge a gap between evening travel and the overnight `red-eye' flights,'' he said. ``While 10:30 p.m. may seem late to many people, we believe there is sufficient demand at this time of day to warrant the implementation of a new `bank' of flights.'' Elsewhere, new service is being added from Cleveland, Ohio, to Louisville, Ky., and Norfolk, Va. From Newark, N.J., service is being added to Greensboro, N.C.; Norfolk, Va.; Columbia, S.C.; and Antigua, West Indies. Those flights start May 1. Hula said the additional flights could prompt non-union Continental to hire nearly 1,000 new workers, including about 200 pilots and 600 flight attendants.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T, Unions Discuss Early Retirement Plan
DOC.TEXT: AT&T and its unions Thursday discussed plans to offer early retirement to non-management employees for the first time in the company's long-running campaign to slim down. American Telephone and Telegraph Co. had no details on who would be affected, how many workers would be eligible and what incentives would be offered because talks were in an early stage, said company spokesman Burke Stinson at AT&T's Basking Ridge office. Stuart Crane, an analyst for Gruntal & Co., speculated that fewer than 10,000 people likely would be affected by the expanded workforce cuts, although it was unknown how many actually would accept early retirement. A spokesman for one of AT&T's major unions, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, said he could not comment on the substance of the talks. However, the idea of offering enhanced pensions to induce retirements ``is obviously something that we're not opposed to,'' said the spokesman, Tom Hickman. The company's other main union, the Communications Workers of America, said it had no comment. The efforts are another step in AT&T's efforts to cut overhead costs and consolidate its operations, said Stinson. AT&T has shrunk its workforce steadily since the 1984 breakup of the Bell System. The company's workforce has shrunk to 281,400 _ including 173,500 non-management workers _ from 373,000 at the time of the breakup. Last year, a special retirement plan for managers prompted 12,500 to depart out of 35,000 who were eligible, said Stinson. The arrangement added five years to each manager's age and tenure, and boosted pension payments by 15 percent for five years, or until a retired worker reached 65. A total of 25,000 jobs were cut last year, some through attrition. As AT&T transforms its network into a computer-driven system and employs new digital and solid state technology, it has increasing numbers of workers with less to do, said Stinson. More switching and operator services are done by computer. Equipment installation and servicing has become easier with the addition of high-tech digital equipment. ``The AT&T system is one gigantic computer with distributed intelligence,'' said Crane. Also, competition brought by the Bell System breakup forced AT&T to pare away extra layers of employees, which it could afford when it was a monopoly.

DOC.HEAD: Personal Bankruptcies Rise Faster in New England Than Anywhere In Nation
DOC.TEXT: Personal bankruptcies have jumped by 31 percent in New England, more rapidly than any other region, reflecting a softening regional economy that also has taken its toll on banks and businesses. Analysts say bankruptcies, once considered by some the refuge of high-flyers who play the game and lose, are becoming the resort of New England's average Joes, who get caught between pervasive layoffs, a daunting debt load and plunging real estate values. ``I'm not surprised by the fact that this is happening. All of a sudden the door is closed,'' said Edward J. Powers, who studies New England as a consulting economist with William Witter Inc., a New York-based pension fund management company. ``A lot of people here are two paychecks away from bankruptcy, even though this is supposed to be a conservative region.'' In 1988, personal bankruptcies totalled 25,417 in New York and the six New England states, figures from the U.S. District Courts show. In 1989, that number rose to 33,294, an increase of 31 percent. New Hampshire led the list of the seven states, with an increase in personal bankruptcies of 55 percent, while in Massachusetts the increase was 50 percent. On the other end of the scale, Vermont actually showed a decrease of 4 percent. Compared to New England, the next highest increase in personal bankruptcies was seen in the district including Alabama, Florida and Georgia, where the figure rose 27 percent from 63,139 to 80,271. Personal bankruptcies have risen only 12 percent nationwide, to 616,753, court figures show. In ordinary times, personal bankruptcies stem most often from a major medical illness, said Judy Kent of the American Fiscal Services Association in Washington, D.C., a financial services trade association which compiled the figures. In addition to bad budgeting, divorce and job loss can also lead an individual to file proceedings, Kent said. In New England, however, the rise in personal bankruptcies comes as the region hurtles downward from the boom years in the 1980s, when its four main industries _ high-tech, construction, defense, and financial services _ took off. Those industries have largely contracted, with revenues falling off and widespread layoffs announced. ``We had the fastest rise (in personal bankruptcies) in part because we had such a booming economy for so long,'' said Wayne Ayers, chief economist with the Bank of Boston. ``When things slow down, they often slow down with a vengeance.'' ``There hasn't been a rise in major medical illnesses in New England,'' said David Wyss, chief economist for Data Resources, an economic research group in Lexington. Rather, Wyss says, the region is seeing more bankruptcies because of the soft real estate and job markets here. ``It's the average Joe who is caught up in this: relatively young, with little or no assets, and who borrowed heavily to buy his first home, and now he's caught,'' said Wyss. In Massachusetts, the unemployment rate has gone from 3.5 percent in November 1988 to 5.3 percent in February 1990, a rise mimicked throughout the region. ``A lot of people had, of course, acquired consumer debt and household debt, and when you lose your job you can't pay it. They cannot pay the debts they undertook in better times,'' Wyss said. Major employers such as Wang Laboratories Inc., Digital Equipment Corp. and General Electric Co. have laid off thousands of workers, and the financial services industry has cut back 20 percent of its jobs in New England, Powers said. Those layoffs have led to job losses at barber shops, restaurants and clothing stores, Powers said. Bankruptcy happens, he said, ``in high pockets of unemployment, where people are overwhelmed. When the downturn surrounds them inside their region, how can you sell anything? It's just very difficult.'' Changes in law have also made declaring bankruptcy less financially painful, analysts said. The deals each debtor strikes still depends on how creditors, litigators and judges assess the depth of his fiscal desperation. But now, in many cases, people can keep their house and car, Powers said. Analysts agreed declaring bankruptcy had also lost some of the disgrace it carried years ago, though they acknowledged it was a process most people wanted to avoid. ``In Japan people commit suicide rather than file bankruptcy. It's the ultimate disgrace. It's called seppuku,'' said Powers. ``Whereas over here, it's not immoral or disgraceful anymore. It's part of the culture now.'' ``There has been an increase in the willingness of people to go bankrupt,'' said Wyss of Data Resources. ``There is not as much stigma. They can continue to work and probably get a new credit card tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Gives Away Gifts for Late Flights
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's promise to compensate everyone on the flight if his shuttle airline is late turned into a bonanza for hundreds of passengers as fog floated over airports in Boston and New York. But officials of Trump Shuttle say the foul weather on the first two days of the offer guaranteed the success of the promotion. Trump Shuttle announced the guarantee offer Tuesday _ one day before fog set in at Boston's Logan International Airport. The airline, which links New York with Boston and Washington, guaranteed passengers they would receive a choice of premiums if any of its hourly flights arrived more than 15 minutes late. LaGuardia Airport in New York was closed to incoming flights for about 3{ hours Thursday morning, halting the shuttle's 6:30 a.m., 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. EST flights from Boston and Washington, said Bruce Nobles, president of Trump Shuttle. Outgoing flights were allowed to take off in the meantime, and the shuttle was back on schedule by 9 a.m., he said. ``This wasn't a catastrophe,'' Nobles said in a telephone interview. ``Mr. Trump is very happy with the promotion. We are so comfortable with the product we will guarantee that product.'' Trump, the billionaire developer who also owns casinos and hotels, bought the shuttle service from Eastern Airlines for $365 million last June. Pan Am Corp., which operates a rival shuttle service, said Tuesday it didn't plan to match the on-time offer. A Pan Am spokesman said Thursday that three of its flights from New York to Boston were late Wednesday. On Wednesday, eight Trump Shuttle flights from New York to Boston between 6:30 a.m. and 1 p.m. were delayed for more than 15 minutes by heavy fog. But Boston-to-New York flights ran as scheduled. Nobles said about 2,800 passengers were affected by the delays Wednesday. He said he had no estimate of how many were delayed Thursday. The on-time guarantee gives delayed passengers the choice of a 5,000-mile bonus on the frequent-flier program run by Trump Shuttle, Eastern and Continental Airlines; a free one-way companion ticket for Trump Shuttle that can be used any weekend; or a $20 American Express restaurant certificate. The offer is in effect through March 31. Nobles was quick to point out that Trump Shuttle caused none of the delays. But he also noted that the airline knew when it launched the promotion that ``we can't guarantee that the weather will be perfect.'' Nobles said the airline did not yet have an accounting of what gifts passengers preferred. He estimated that half the passengers opted for the frequent-flier miles, which was what the company had anticipated, with the others choosing either the companion ticket or the restaurant certificate. For Wednesday's delayed passengers, Trump Shuttle could pay approximately $18,480 in restaurant certificates and around $72,996 in free companion tickets, he said. Off-peak weekend tickets on the shuttle are $79 one way. Nobles said the payoff would not be hard to handle and would fall within company projections.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Paying Shoppers To Compare
DOC.TEXT: In the auto industry's never-ending search to find new ways of selling cars and trucks, two makers are paying customers to do what comes naturally _ comparison shop. Nissan Motor Corp. is offering $100 to anyone who test drives one of its Stanza sedans _ but they only get the money if they end up buying a Honda Accord or Toyota Camry. Chrysler Corp. in February offered $50 to anyone who bought a car after test-driving a comparable Chrysler product _ no matter what company made the vehicle. The smartest shoppers could have pocketed $150 _ if they bought an Accord or Camry in the last two weeks of February and simply drove a Stanza and a comparable Chrysler product. The Nissan promotion began Feb. 12 and ends April 30. The cash offers are the latest stunt in the ongoing trend of comparison advertisements in the auto industry. Automakers no longer use ``Brand X'' in advertising _ they name names. A Federal Trade Commission rule change in the mid-1970s allows direct comparisons if the claim is substantiated. Perhaps the best-known comparison advertising battle on the auto scene is between Chevrolet and Ford trucks. Chevrolet aired a ``Ditch of Doom'' advertisement last year in which a Chevrolet truck plowed through a muck-filled ditch, shifting into four-wheel-drive while moving. Occupants of a Ford truck had to stop, get out and slog through the refuse to lock front-wheel hubs, giving the truck four-wheel-drive capability to get through the trench. Chevrolet's latest series, dubbed ``Ford County,'' said Chevrolet trucks outsold Ford trucks in Ford County, Ill. That was just true enough for Ford to seize on the claim. Ford acknowledged in ads that for a month or two, Chevrolet outsold Ford in that county. But for the previous 12 months, Ford said, its trucks outsold Chevrolet trucks nationwide, including Ford counties in several states and in Chevy Chase, Md. Along with the obvious goal of more sales, comparison ad campaigns are designed to lure people into showrooms, said Jim Wangers, president of Automotive Marketing Consultants Inc. in Vista, Calif. ``Most of the retail people feel, `If I can get them in and get them on my grounds, I'll sell them,''' Wangers said Thursday. ``There is a percentage of the people who they can close (in a sale) if they can get them in.'' Chrysler and Nissan dealers could use more traffic in their showrooms. During the first two months of the year, Chrysler's total vehicle sales of 305,985 were down 1.4 percent compared with January and February last year and Nissan's total vehicle sales were 89,974, off 16.3 percent. The Nissan offer works like this: a potential buyer test drives a Stanza between Feb. 12 and April 30 and fills out an evaluation form. The dealer reviews it, keeps one copy, sends another to Nissan headquarters and gives one to the consumer. If the consumer takes delivery of an Accord or Camry within seven days of the Stanza test drive and attaches the purchase order to the copy of the Nissan evaluation, the consumer gets the $100 by mail from Nissan in four to six weeks. If the consumer buys the Stanza, said Nissan spokesman E.C. Mueller, there's no cash reward. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said the results of Chrysler's $50 test-drive program, which ran only in February, were proprietary information. ``I don't have any inside knowledge,'' Wangers said. ``but a program that is that simple, if it was working, they would keep it.''

Higher Japanese rates would enhance returns on yen-denominated investments and tend to bolster demand for yen. Robert Morrissey, a senior currency trader at the Bank of Boston, said the Bush comment in a speech to the National Association of Manufacturers renewed speculation that the White House and the Federal Reserve might be at odds over interest rate policy. Bush told the manufacturers lower rates remain a priority of his administration, saying ``We need to keep interest rates down.'' Meanwhile, Morrissey said the Japanese discount rate rumor reinforced the selling pressure on the dollar. Nonetheless, the dollar managed to close in New York at a higher rate against the yen than on Wednesday. DOC.HEAD: US Trade Official Says `Zero Progress' Led to Breakoff of Talks with Japan
DOC.TEXT: Talks with the Japanese on a key trade dispute involving purchases of American satellites broke off this week after ``zero progress'' had been made, a disappointed U.S. trade official told reporters Thursday. The official said that no further talks would be held unless the Japanese budge from their current position. ``The talks this week have been dancing in circles without getting anywhere near the destination and the music is about to run out,'' said the official, who briefed reporters on condition that his name not be used. Satellites are one of three U.S. product groups that have been targeted for the removal of trade barriers by the Japanese. If significant progress has not been made by June 15, the administration has the power to retaliate by imposing higher tariffs on Japanese products. The official said that discussions in the other two areas _ American lumber products and supercomputers _ were apparently making some progress but that the discussion on satellites was ``the sore thumb. It is sticking out.'' The talks on specific products, being held under a toughened portion of the trade law known as Super 301, are one of the key avenues the administration is pursuing in an effort to reduce the huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Japanese negotiators met with U.S. officials in Washington for two days on the satellite issue earlier this week. The talks moved to wood products on Thursday and were to address supercomputers early next week. The satellite talks marked the fourth time negotiators had met on this issue since last summer. The American side is seeking assurances that the Japanese government, which is responsible for the bulk of satellite purchases in Japan, will stop favoring Japanese firms in the bidding process. The negotiator said that the United States is willing to exempt research and development efforts by the Japanese who want to promote their own space industry. However, he said Japanese negotiators were insisting that virtually all satellite projects fell under the definition of basic research. The U.S. trade official said he had told his Japanese counterparts that another meeting on satellites would be a waste of time unless the Japanese position changed. ``We made zero progress at this meeting,'' he said. ``If they call up with a new proposal and it looks like there is some meat there, then we will meet again.'' In addition to the talks on satellites, supercomputers and wood products, the administration has launched discussions aimed at removing more broadbased barriers to trade in both countries. The next round of talks on so-called strucutral impediments are scheduled to be held in Washington on April 2 and 3, but so far little progress has been made in these discussions. President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met in Palm Springs, Calif., recently with both leaders pledging renewed efforts to reach compromises in the various trade disputes.

As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $10.16 billion, or 0.31 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .52 to 186.20. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.62 to 391.24, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.20 at 338.07. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.91 to 438.06. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 362.27, up .90.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Bans Sulfites on Fresh Potatoes
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday it will extend a ban on the use of sulfites to include fresh potatoes because of severe allergic reactions to the preservative, including four deaths. The FDA banned use of sulfites on fruit and produce on salad bars in 1986, but potatoes were excluded from the ban. After strong industry lobbying, the FDA decided to study further whether the ban should extend to potatoes. An industry spokesman said the ban would have little impact on consumers but would hurt many businesses that prepare potatoes for use in restaurants. The agency said it has received nearly 1,000 complaints of adverse reactions to sulfites since 1985. Most of the reported reactions were mild, including dizziness, cramps or wheezing. But, occasionally, reactions can cause breathing difficulty that can lead to death. Four deaths have been reported after consumption of sulfite-treated potatoes, the FDA said. Up to a million asthmatics may be sensitive to sulfites, the agency said. The new ban, published in Thursday's Federal Register, will go into effect in 30 days. Bruce Silverglade of the Center for Science in the Public Interest applauded the ban on sulfite-treated potatoes, saying it was ``long overdue and indicative of a new outlook on these types of problems'' by the federal government. Sulfites are used on peeled potatoes to keep them white and firm. The preservative usually is added after potatoes are cut up for distribution to fast food and other restaurants to be cooked as french fries and hash brown potatoes. The ban will prohibit using sulfites on these potatoes before or after they reach the restaurant. Robert Mercer, president of the National Potato Board, the promotional arm of the industry, said the ban ``won't mean too much to industry'' because there are alternatives to sulfites, though they are more expensive and less efficient. He also said ``it won't mean much difference to consumers.'' The FDA said it also may ban use of sulfites on frozen potatoes that are distributed to restaurants. This use is not common, the agency said, and when the preservative is used for this purpose, these products are required to be labeled as containing sulfites. However, a restaurant patron who is sensitive to sulfites probably would not see the label and could be at risk, the FDA said. Six sulfites are used as preservatives: sulfur dioxide, sodium sulfite, sodium and potassium bisulfite, and sodium and potassium matabisulfite. When used in prescription drugs, wines and packaged foods _ including packaged potatoes _ the preservative must be noted on labels. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the ageny had no plans to consider banning sulfites in canned or dehydrated potatoes. The industry maintains there is no alternative to sulfites for these products, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher
DOC.TEXT: Three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,269.3 billion from $3,264.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,074.7 billion from $4,072.6 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $807 billion from $805 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 7 percent, which is at the upper limit of the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,239.2 billion, a 6.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,045.2 billion, up 3.4 percent, while M1 rose 5.2 percent to an average of $797.6 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $12 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $74 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $115 million the previous week. The figure was the lowest since such accounting began in February 1984. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $660 million in the two weeks ended March 7, up from $389 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $301.3 billion in the two-week period ended March 7, up from $300.6 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline futures prices surged Thursday, boosted by reports of refinery problems and new government statistics that confirmed a decline in the nation's gasoline stocks. Analysts said the reports focused on possible problems at Exxon Corp. refineries in Louisiana, Texas and New Jersey and led to concerns about possible disruptions of gasoline supplies. Initial reports later proved to be exaggerated and apparently related to routine maintenance, analysts said. Exxon did not return telephone calls seeking details. Meanwhile, the Department of Energy's report on the nation's petroleum inventories supported Tuesday's figures from the American Petroleum Institute that showed declines in gasoline and heating oil stocks last week and a rise in crude oil inventories. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline shot up 2.09 cents to finish at 57.94 cents a gallon after a 0.98-cent rise on Wednesday. May unleaded gasoline gained 2 cents to 62.94 cents a gallon and June rose 1.65 cents to 62.65 cents a gallon. Heating oil also had a strong day despite continued warm weather in the Northeast. April heating oil closed at 54.98 cents a gallon, up 0.96 cent, May advance 0.98 cent to 53.43 a gallon and June ended at 52.95 cents, up 0.77 cent. Crude oil futures, pulled along by strength in product, also advanced. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S crude, rose 33 cents to $20.38 cents a barrel. May rose 36 cents to $20.68 and June went up 35 cents to $20.80 a barrel. Analysts said a meeting of OPEC's monitoring committee scheduled to begin Friday might have added some strength to the crude market. ``There was some short covering prior to the OPEC meeting although most traders don't expect anything positive or anything at all to come out of this,'' said Andrew Lebow, senior broker and analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. OPEC ministers are expected to review the group's price and production policies in light of current market conditions in preparation for May's full conference of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Sugar Futures Surge On Fears of Fewer Brazilian Exports
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and sugar futures prices rose sharply Thursday, partly reflecting fears that Brazil's new president will seek higher taxes and restrictions on exports of some of the country's major commodities. On other commodity markets, grain futures advanced; petroleum futures rose; copper surged while precious metals were mixed; cattle futures retreated; and pork futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 9 cents to 13{ cents higher on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in March at $5.86 a bushel. Analysts linked some of the buying to rumors that Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello, who took office Thursday, planned to seek an export tax on Brazilian soybeans and soy products as one of many measures aimed at stabilizing the country's foundering economy. Such a tax would raise the cost of Brazilian soybeans closer to that of U.S. soybeans on the world market and could discourage Brazilian growers from marketing their crops quickly. Collor de Mello was scheduled to announce his economic proposals Friday. The late rally in the soybean pit erased much of the losses registered earlier in the week and prompted speculation that prices may have to move even higher to persuade U.S. farmers to market their soybean stocks. ``The daily demand is exceeding the daily supply,'' said Bill Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Indications of new export business also supported the grain and soybean markets. The Soviet Union was believed to be in the market for U.S. corn while China was said to have bid for 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 3{ cents higher with March at $3.84{ a bushel; corn was } cent to 3\ cents higher with March at $2.47 a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.44 a bushel; Sugar futures made new 8{-year highs on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange on rumors Brazil may eliminate or reduce exports to divert more sugar to the country's fuel alcohol program. Signs of new demand from Turkey and Eastern European countries also supported the market, which is in a delicate supply-demand balance. Sugar futures settled .23 cent to .39 cent higher with May at 15.93 cents a pound after trading as high as 16.02 cents during the session for the first time since mid-1981. Copper futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange on fears that the 4-day-old strike at the Southern Peru Copper Corp. could force cancellation of copper shipments. Copper ended .05 cent to 3.05 cents higher with March at $1.2805 a pound. In New York, gold futures settled 20 cents lower to 10 cents higher with April at $399.60 a troy ounce; silver futures were 0.2 cent to 0.5 cent lower with March at $5.079 a troy ounce. Futures on refined oil products climbed sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, leading crude oil higher, on news of minor problems at two Exxon refineries and an Arco oil pipeline shutdown in Texas due to flooding. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 16 cents to 36 cents higher with April at $20.38 a barrel; heating oil was .63 cent to .98 cent higher with April at 54.98 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1 cent to 2.09 cents higher with April at 57.94 cents a gallon. Stronger cash markets supported pork futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while cattle futures fell slightly on position evening ahead of Friday's monthly Agriculture Department report on cattle on feed in the seven largest cattle-producing states. Live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .30 cent lower with April at 77.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent to .40 cent lower with March at 82.60 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .43 cent higher with April at 52.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent lower to .32 cent higher with March at 49.97 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines Announces New System for Discount Fares
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, announced Thursday a new structure for its advance-purchase fares, raising some and dropping others based on mileage. Spokesmen for two big competitors, United Airlines and Continental Airlines, said those carriers were studying American's move and hadn't yet decided whether to match it. ``Our plan eliminates peculiarities in the existing fare structure, which sometimes makes it more expensive to fly to the next state than halfway across the country,'' said Michael W. Gunn, American's senior vice president of marketing. ``We are simplifying the formula so all affected markets receive equal treatment.'' American spokeswoman Mary O'Neill said about half the fares will be going up and half going down, although the amount of reductions will generally be larger than increases. Off-peak fares will be cut as much as $31 while peak fares will drop as much as $40. Increases will range from $2 to $41, the airline said. Most of the higher fares are on long-haul routes while the cuts come on shorter trips, Ms. O'Neill said. The new fares take affect on April 17. The new structure applies both to American's 14-day and seven-day advance- purchase fares. Fourteen-day fares are the carrier's cheapest and are non-refundable, while seven-day fares are 20 percent higher but carry only a 25 percent cancellation penalty. Regular fares remain unchanged. Under the new system, a round-trip ticket bought 14 days in advance for the 189-mile flight from San Jose, Calif., to Reno, Nev., will drop from $203 to $183 for peak travel. The off-peak fare will fall from $203 to $158. A similar ticket for the 466-mile Buffalo, N.Y.,-to-Chicago flight goes from $260 to $251 for peak travel. The $218 off-peak fare stays the same. Examples of increased fares include the 1,378-mile trip from Dallas-Fort Worth to New York, with peak fares rising from $384 to $412 and off-peak fares jumping from $343 to $358. A Los Angeles-to-New York flight, covering 2,459 miles, goes from $468 to $492 for peak travel and from $426 to $428 for off-peak.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Concerned Over Slowing Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday voiced concern about the nation's slowing economy and called for industry and government to redouble efforts to boost U.S. competitiveness and reap a ``growth dividend.'' ``There is a great deal we have to do to keep this expansion going,'' the president told a group of newspaper executives. ``The economy at this moment isn't as robust as I'd like to see it.'' ``I don't want to stand here with some Pollyannish attitude about the economy,'' he said. ``There are some signs that worry me.'' Bush brought up troubling signs of economic weakness both in his meeting with out-of-town newspaper publishers and editors and in a morning speech to the National Association of Manufacturers. At both forums, however, Bush indicated the signs of weakness come against a backdrop of a generally sound economy. ``This is a marathon, it isn't a sprint,'' he told the manufacturers, commenting on sluggishness throughout the industrial sector. He told the trade association that changes in Eastern Europe and Central America ``mark the triumph not only of free ideas but also free markets'' and so present new trade opportunities. In his afternoon session with news executives, Bush said congressional approval of his proposal for a lower capital gains tax as well as educational reforms he has proposed would help make the nation more competitive. ``If we're successful, then we're going to have not a peace dividend but a growth dividend,'' Bush said, using the same phrase he had used earlier in his NAM speech. He told the manufacturers: ``We can't produce the products needed to capture world markets by focusing on results one quarter at a time,'' he told his audience. The nation's economic growth slumped to an anemic 0.9 percent in the gross national product in the final three months of 1989; many economists also are projecting a slow first quarter of 1990. American manufacturing has been in the doldrums for months. ``There are doubters, and I can understand that some worry about a slowdown,'' Bush said. Appearing before Congress' Joint Economic Committee on Thursday, White House budget director Richard Darman said the economy's poor performance in the final quarter of 1989 would add $6.2 billion to the projected budget deficit for next year. The added red ink would be in the $12 billion to $15 billion range if the economy rebounds only gradually, he said. Before the new economic performance figures became available, the administration had estimated that the shortfall for fiscal 1991 _ which begins next Oct. 1 _ would be $100.5 billion. The higher the projected deficit, the more difficult it will be for Congress and the White House to agree to enough budget savings to obey the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. That legislation sets a $64 billion target for the projected 1991 deficit. Bush said there have been recent signs of economic improvement, noting the U.S. trade deficit, although still high, has been declining. ``We must move aggressively to open markets, not just in Japan but around the world, and expand our share of global trade,'' Bush said. He told the manufacturing trade group that U.S. industry's resolve would be tested ``as the dramatic new changes in the world produce new challenges in the world market.'' ``We must prepare now to meet these challenges. My administration is committed to an agenda for growth. It is founded upon investing in our future _ and every sound investment has its yield. America's yield is the `growth dividend.''' Bush's comments were a play on the phrase ``peace dividend,'' which has been used recently to describe the defense savings expected to accompany the reduction of East-West tensions. Bush also prodded Congress to meet an April 1 deadline to produce a budget resolution for fiscal 1991, a deadline congressional leaders say will not be met. He said the budget committees should ``fulfill their legal responsibilities ... It's time to act. It's time to bring the deficit down.'' And, even though he told a news conference earlier this week he was not feuding with Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan over interest-rate policy, he told the manufacturers, ``We need to keep interest rates down.'' Greenspan has sought to keep inflation down through higher interest rates. Later, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole urged the business leaders to establish programs to help troubled youngsters and to involve at least 10 percent of their employees in helping at-risk youth. ``Nothing can match the benefits that come from a one-on-one relationship between a troubled youth and a caring role model,'' Mrs. Dole said in a speech after Bush's appearance. Mrs. Dole is expected to form a commission soon to frame ``national competency guidelines'' to make sure the workforce is equipped with the right skills for the changing economy. She urged business leaders to involve local educators in the commission's report.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Say Michigan Firms Bilked Maine Mill By Bribing Worker, Wife
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 12th graf to CORRECT Chernow sted Gleason
DOC.TEXT: Scott Paper Co. allegedly was cheated out of up to $1 million by two Michigan businessmen and three companies that bribed a Scott engineer and put his wife on the payroll for arranging purchases of needless supplies at inflated prices, a federal prosecutor said Thursday. William M. Engelman, 52, and Gerald M. Chernow, 49, both of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., were named as defendants in a 21-count indictment alleging that Scott's S.D. Warren mill in Westbrook was bilked from March 1984 to June 1987. Engelman and Chernow face charges of conspiracy, mail fraud, and the use of interstate facilities in furtherance of private bribery. Also named as defendants in U.S. District Court were three companies owned or controlled by the two men: Modern Research Corp. and Lincoln Technical Service Inc., both of Troy, Mich.; and ABC Chemical Corp. of Detroit. ``Engelman and Chernow, acting through the three corporations and with two other alleged co-conspirators, engaged in a commercial bribery scheme which caused S.D. Warren to purchase substantially overpriced products in quantities exceeding S.D. Warren's needs,'' the U.S. Attorney's Office said in a statement Thursday. An indictment returned by federal grand jurors on Wednesday alleges that a former S.D. Warren maintenance engineer, David Hilt, received merchandise, gift certificates and money orders from the Michigan companies in exchange for setting up purchases of expensive roofing and maintenance equipment that the mill did not need. The supplies were marked up from 10 times their cost to 20 times their cost. Purchases were arranged through salesman Jack D. Lieberman at Modern Research's branch office in Miami, Fla., the indictment alleged. Eventually, Hilt's wife, Ellen, was put on the payroll of Lincoln Technical Service, which paid her thousands of dollars in checks that were based on the amount of materials S.D. Warren bought from Modern Research, prosecutors said. Neither Engelman nor Chernow were immediately available for comment late Thursday, according to a woman who answered the phone at Modern Research's office in suburban Detroit. An S.D. Warren spokesman declined comment. Although the Hilts and Lieberman are named in the indictment, with David Hilt and Lieberman described as co-conspirators, none of them face charges. Federal authorities planned to order Engelman and Chernow to appear in court once an arraignment date was set. ``Assuming they come voluntarily, there will be no need to arrest them in Michigan,'' said First Assistant U.S. Attorney Jack Gleason. If convicted on all counts, Chernow and Engelman could each face 105 years in prison and $5.25 million in fines, Gleason said. Modern Research and Lincoln Technical Service could each face $10.5 million in fines, while ABC Chemical could face $6.5 million in fines, the prosecutor said. The 46-page indictment says Modern Research sells chemicals and maintenance supplies, and ABC Chemical buys, processes and sells those products, often to Modern Research. Lincoln Technical was said to provide engineering services, and it is listed in the Troy phone book as having the same address as Modern Research. Philadelphia-based Scott allegedly lost between $750,000 and $1 million in the scheme, which was the subject of a two-year investigation by federal prosecutors and postal inspectors.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Lawyer Said in Letter That She Pressured Regulators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th pvs, bgng: Waxman's law, to UPDATE with thrift office comment; moving general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for savings and loan financier Charles H. Keating Jr. bragged in a 1988 letter released Thursday that she had successfully pressured federal regulators. ``You have the (Federal Home Loan Bank) board right where you want them and you should be able to reach an agreement ... which will completely satisfy you,'' Washington lawyer Margery Waxman wrote in the May 10, 1988, letter. Waxman, who was referring to an upcoming meeting with board officials, told Keating she had ``put pressure on'' M. Danny Wall, chairman of the bank board and then chief regulator of thrift institutions. House Banking Committee Chairman Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, who released the letter, said it strongly suggests ``the fix was in at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.'' Banking panel aides refused to say how they obtained the letter. Wall, who quit earlier this month after harsh congressional criticism of his handling of Lincoln, said he was ``just stunned by the tone of this (letter) and its implications.'' In a telephone interview, he said he never met with Waxman about Keating, adding ``It's a lawyer trying to justify a fee.'' Waxman's law firm, Sidley & Austin, denied in a statement that it applied political pressure to the bank board or its employees. The only pressure it exerted, the statement said, was advising the bank board Keating was considering filing a law suit. The Office of Thrift Supervision, which succeeded the bank board as S&L regulator, said the letter ``is riddled with errors and false conclusions.'' Keating is chairman of American Continental Corp., a holding company that owned Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif. The S&L failed in April and is expected to require the nation's costliest S&L bailout, about $2 billion. At the time the letter was sent, Keating was fighting federal efforts to rein in his institution. Bank board examiners based in San Francisco had recommended that the government seize Lincoln and Keating had appealed to authorities in Washington. ``As you know, I have put pressure on Wall to work toward meeting your demands and he has so instructed his staff,'' Waxman wrote. ``They all know the Wednesday meeting is crucial to their future. If they mess up this time, it is all over.'' Wall, however, said, ``I would not under any circumstances threaten anybody with their job. That is not my character. That is not my way of doing business.'' The letter was written five days after a divided bank board decided to move the Lincoln case from the jurisdiction of its San Francisco office to Washington and on the same day Wall had a telephone conversation with Keating. Waxman outlined what she expected to be the result of the meeting, including a new examination of Lincoln and memorandum of understanding between the institution and regulators, which was executed five days later. ``San Francisco is finished,'' she assured Keating. ``Thereis no going back to San Francisco and nothing can be done to follow up their exam.'' In the new exam, she said, ``nothing will be done ... that you are not aware of in advance.'' Also, she told Keating that bank board personnel ``will not be able to enforce any violation (of the memorandum of understanding) ... without going to the board first. ... This will give you two bites at the apple _ before the board and in court if necessary.'' ``The letter, written in strong declarative language, tracks with amazing accuracy the actions taken by the board _ actions which were interpreted publicly as clamping down on Lincoln,'' Gonzalez said. ``In reality, as the letter carefully explains, the actions were to be shams designed not to punish but to allow Keating an escape route.'' The letter indicates it was telecopied to Keating in Phoenix. Its existence was first disclosed in stories in Thursday's editions of the San Francisco Chronicle. ``It's clear from the law firm's memo ... that Keating had undue and unprecedented influence on the board,'' said Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa, a Republican member of the banking panel. ``This memo would appear to put Wall at the center point of directing in a powerful, if not coercive, way his employees to abide by his decision to go easy on Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower; Stocks Up Moderately
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar remained slightly lower against the Japanese yen early Friday while stock prices gained moderately. The dollar was changing hands at 152.40 yen at late morning, down from Thursday's close of 152.47 yen. The Nikkei index of 225 selected issues, which rose 319.51 points Thursday, gained 62.28 points, or 0.19 percent, closing the morning session at 32,733.92. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, speaking at a regular news conference Friday morning, said he was ``displeased'' with the yen's weakness and added that the situation was ``fairly serious.'' Shinji Tanaka, a dealer with Mitsui Bank, said the market's underlying sentiment toward the dollar remained firm. ``Trading was relatively quiet as a hike in the nation's discount rate faded away, at least for now,'' Tanaka said. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno, just back from a nine-day European trip, told a news conference Thursday there was no change in the central bank's fundamental stance of monitoring the effects of its last rate rise, put into effect last December. There has been persistent speculation that Japan's central bank will again raise its official discount rate by as much as 1 percentage point from the current 4.25 percent. The discount rate, the interest rate charged on loans by the central bank to commercial banks, affects other domestic interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to enhance yen-denominated investments.
